Perched high above the more modern streets below, Bukchon Hanok Village is best visited during the summertime at dusk, basking the low buildings and their details in a soft glow. Per other reviewer comments, some locals don't like the attention and have signs begging people to be respectful and quiet; a request I was happy to oblige. However, given the world's most populous nations have yet to travel to Seoul en mass, my best advice would be for those unhappy with the noise some tourists can bring to sell up now. Regardless, there are plenty of great photo opportunities for the curious traveller, as well as some shopping opportunities and cafes hidden throughout.  A good access point is from Samcheon-Ro, which runs north-east from the eastern side of the Gyeongbokgung grounds. Follow the sidewalk maps and signs until you find a narrow, steep staircase disappearing between the cafes and houses (Google maps: 37.584644, 126.982128 .) Climbing the staircase you'll soon reach a street overlooking Samcheon-Ro below, with views back to Gyeongbokgung. Follow the signs carefully and you'll soon find yourself amid streets of stunningly restored and maintained homes. Follow the streets in an easterly direction before gradually following the twisting, turning narrow streets downhill in a southerly direction. A dusk visit will also avail you to some great dinner opportunities as you approach Yulgok-Ro.

This is a a place with nice buildings and architecture, but as it is also a residential area, the residents were not happy with tourists visiting this place and had banners and signs put up saying they dont welcome tourists. There were also signs to say we have to speak softly. There were guides nearer to the main street, you can get a map from them to aid in your walking

Perhaps it was a hot summer day, we were dehydrated and hungry, the visit to Bukchon Hanok Village was not the best experience in Seoul. We walked and walked, and came upon some small alleys with traditional houses, that was it!!! It was interesting to see many visitors, dressed in traditional Hanbok, and taking poses in the 100 degree weather. The highly rated Ginseng Chicken Soup restaurant was a disappointment, too hot, lack of taste, and varieties. What menu choices? the restaurant only served one dish during our visit.

Backdated post: May 2017.  Loved admiring the architecture of the hanok houses. Amazing wood work and the tiles were so pretty. Its VERY hot in May, recommended to go in spring or in autumn. Take a map from one of the guides and guide your way through.  Along the road once you are out of the area you can find the famous O’Sulloc cafe where they sell all things green tea.

The village itself is wondetful, it has beautiful plants, lovely houses, and architecture. But this is a residential area, and the residents are not happy about the tourists disturbing their peaceful neighbourhood. There are some gentle signs on the houses by the government to keep quiet, but the residents have put up flags that say: Get out, you are not welcome! These really degraded my experience, but if you talk quietly, it's definitely a must see.

Visited here as part of a private tour...just me, my daughter and the guide. It's a quiet change from the larger more commercialized tours. Worth it if you have a historian as a guide. There were some locals starting to gather to protest against the large tour groups due to the noise. But there are also a lot of local shops geared towards tourists.

Hanbok rental can be a bit more pricey than at the Palace around 10,000krw for 1 hour, however, It’s better for pictures here and you wont have to do much photoshop to cut out strangers from your photo :D go there around 9am, no one and no tour is there yet! Btw, keep the noise at the lowest level please, I did feel really bad for those people who lived there since there were a lot of tourists around after 11am.

This place is one of the best place to take picture and having an image of living in the old Korean. The houses are so pretty but when I went there, there are a few house that's under construction (which is the government help the people to maintain their house). And this place is sooo crowded. If you want to have a very good picture with less people you should come early morning.
You can walk for some hours and learn more about Korea, there are nice houses, doors, little stores and coffe

What's not to like? It is interesting, free, sandwiched between other sites you are likely to visit and a good place for a nice stroll. It is much more pleasant and less crowded than the more frantic, packed Namdaenum market.

This village offers you a way to look into past history housing. People still live in the houses so you have to be quiet and be respectful when you are walking around. The doors in some of these homes are gorgeous! Bring an umbrella if you are coming during summer months.
One of the tourist attractions that offer Korean culture. Many historic old buildings of Korean cultural heritage sometimes have art performances here.
There’s not much here to see. It’s worth a 30 minute visit if you’re in the area. There is one street where you can take a picture.

Step back into time, the architecture in this village is one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. The streets are a little bit hilly so I don't recommend going here in the summer like I did, it was super hot.

I don’t regret going but I will probably skip this/will not recommend visiting this area to anyone. Its actually a residential area and there is a very big sign to say that tourist are not allowed in the area. I just don’t feel welcomed at all in this area. Although I know there are very nice shops/cafes in the area I just don’t feel like wandering around the village. Do not have high expectation if you go!

Bukchon which means "Northern Village" is found north of two famous landmarks in Seoul, Cheonggyecheon stream and Jongno. The Palaces surround this village (Gyeongbokgung, Changdeokgung and Jongno Shrine). In this village, you would be able to admire hundreds of Koreas traditional houses, called Hanoks. Aside from this Hanoks operating as cultural centers guesthouses, restaurants and tea houses for tourists to get to immerse themselves in the Korean culture, a lot of this Hanoks are still residential homes so make sure not to loiter and be too loud while going around the village.

It was fun to walk around this neighborhood, but I felt kind of guilty that people live there and have to post signs telling others to be quiet. They post it in English and what I guessed was Korean. Tourists from other parts of the world were so loud, but you can't post in every language of the world. Some fun shops crop up randomly between the homes. Beautiful homes, fun, historic feel. But tread lightly and quietly.

You can walk around the streets and look at all the cute shops that the area has to offer. I found a place where you can drink some traditional Korean beverages. It is a little bit expensive but the drinks are great so I would just go for it and enjoy the experience.

I don’t regret going, but it was a waste of time. There really isn’t much to see or do, and the people living in the village are very vocal as to how much they hate that you are there. In prominent display are signs specifically complaining about and admonishing tourists. Who cares though because it’s not really a cool place to go.
This is a hilly part of Seoul amidst two royal palaces. Clean and safe but seems that - according to many notes on houses - the residents do not feel very happy about the many and loud tourists.

This is a really large area and we had the pleasure to have a private guide showing us around! The village itself was "closed" this day refering to "tourist-hours" and it felt calm and serene :). Take your time, it is quite a bit of up and down walking. As we were guided by a girl we met at a gym who lived in the area, we were shown the local library and some other places where people lived "at the side" of the tourist routes, wich was unpayable!.  The vew over Seoul from the highest point is Amazing!
what should I say, yes it's old and traditional houses but imagine that a hundred year old house with a Lamborghini inside. nice house but not a must to see in Korea

I was expecting more but it was just nice. You should get a map from the tourist info guides (red t-shirts) before going in, the map has got recommended walks withing the village. From a Tourist Information Office near Anguk Station I also got a map of the area. Insadong Street and Changdeokgung Palace are close by, I even walked here from Gyeongbukgung Palace. So it's not a wasted journey if you do not find the village that interesting as there are other tourist places to visit within walking distance.
I expected more, but wandering through the streets it wasn’t very impressive and definitely not a must see for me.
Having ancient houses in a modern city is an amazing combination. Love the view of modern seoul from an ancient village. Lot of Interesting thing to explore and take nice pictures.
Beautiful and good photo op. Nice quaint cafes and tea house along the roads. Go for this teahouse in the picture, offers some serenity & serves flavorful tea

The walking journey from Gyeongbokgung was very tiring and hilly. Lots of tourist didn't follow the advise to keep their voice low. Noticed several posting on the wall indicated the tenant not welcoming tourist to their village.  However, I enjoy looking at many beautiful doors each houses have.
a village with amazing folk houses used by local Korean as dwellings; I agree that the residence were disturbed by tourists. I would suggest tourists visiting Namsangol Hanok Village instead.

actually i don't stay in city of seoul quite long time & always went to countryside in my short tour in last autumn. but i take this bukchon hanok village. easy to reach here & area was quite big actually. some place was crowded but some quite. good for viewing historical korea house. spend a day here to walk around & take picture. enjoyable.

Seoul is a cosmopolitan city where you can still see traditional buildings. You just need to be able to manage some streets with incline. Since the area is a residential one, tourists need to respect the privacy of the residents. It’s a good place to take pics of the facades of traditional houses.

First, you should get a map from the tourist info guides (wearing red t-shirts) and follow the recommended path. Don't rely on Google Maps as it will lead you to the wrong place. While visiting this area remember that this is a residential area. Enjoy the area quietly and respectful towards the residents.
I was amazed by this place, because it was preserved by the community/the people living on this village. It was a nice experienced roaming around with the Korean Traditional costume.
What a great place to visit. Spent one evening in a traditional guest home. What a unique experience. The whole area is really very different. A one of a kind place to see.

spent about 1 to 2 hours there.  This is a residential area so do be quiet and not be a nuisance to the residents there (not all welcome the prying eyes of tourists into their personal homes)  Beautiful architecture. Would recommend hiring some traditional dresses for more authentic pictures but we were too hot and sweaty to get into those.  But besides just looking at the resident's houses, there isn't very much to do there. But still worth a visit.  PS : There is a self-proclaimed Michelin star Ginseng Chicken soup there near the entrance. It's a fake! We tried it and were disappointed. And my husband checked the Michelin guide and it's not there!

A very quite place, beautiful architecture, it is a place as a example for traditional Korean neighborhood , please respect the local and do not make noise.  You can pay and access to the observatory,  It is a must during any Seoul visit, also the you can walk around the neighborhood where you can find good shops, cafe, bars.

We found this place thru Air bnb. Very traditional lodging from the Jeosun dynasty. Reminds me of the traditional ryokan of Japan. The property is situated on a hill slope and built like terraces. There was a cellar basement room, 2 bed rooms, sitting room end a kitchen and toilet. It was made mainly of wood.  We slept on futon mattresses. Quite comfortable. The place was comfortable with air con in each bed room plus the basement. The home was in traditional renovations of main wood and wooden floor. The modern part was the bathroom toilet and kitchen. The feel and experience is really authentic and we are happy with the choice of having this accommodation in our first of 3 segments to soak in the korean culture and history.  From this home we can walk to gyeonbakkung palace which is anotger historical sight within the city. There is also the subway station. Around the whole village, there are many little shops offering a wide range of shopping and food beverage options.  The only downside i believe is walking back to the home after a full day outing! It's quite a climb but manageable on paved little roads. Take a look at some of the pictures posted. This place is really very popular with many tourist and even TV crews spotted outside our home. Some tourist even thought we lived there and asked if they could come in but we had to decline as it was not our but someone's private property.

Get yourself a map before you enter the place as the road is very confusing. Luckily, there are tourist information officers with red shirt where you can spot at some places. Ask them of the famous spots so you won't waste energy to roam aimlessly. Toilets are hard to come by in the area. There are cafes and shops around, as well as some houses that are open for public free of charge. Make sure to respect the residents and do not cause any disturbance and loud noises.

Really liked Bukchon the first time I visited but not this time. It was very touristy both times so nothing new but it was the banners around the village through which locals expressed their anger at tourists and how they are suffering through tourism which put me off. While I understand how constant flows of noisy, disrespectful visitors can be oppressive, it's really something they need to work out with the tourism authorities to find a solution rather than hang out insulting messages. Also at the end of the day, it's no big deal. It's quirky and quaint but the hanok buildings can be seen in other areas outside of Seoul. So if you are going to be going off the beaten track in S Korea it's not really worth visiting Bukchon. Its location between the 2 most popular palaces in Seoul make it an inevitable stop though. So if you do visit, be prepared for an unfriendly reception and try not to piss the residents off more by talking and laughing loudly (as we saw some inconsiderate visitors do).
This is authentic hanok village, beautiful houses, small restaurants and boutique shops. However this is a residential area and they don't like tourists.

Interesting place with many shops, restaurants, cafes. Generally it is possible to see some street activities also. Other than all these, you can see nice traditional houses, also many art galleries. Prices in all those shops are above the average level in Seoul. Also, in my opinion, no need to join any guided tour for here, even it is free. Just good weather is required.

Seoul must change a great deal from the old days, so it's kind of fun to walk among the old building from the bygone area, narrow streets have some interesting cafe and shops, Korean folks still live here, please speak low, try not to make any noise, not to disturb their daily normal life.

If you want to have a glimpse at South Korea's traditional architectural style, visit Buckchon village, with its narrow streets and extremely beautiful houses (hanoks). A piece of advice: since the area is inhabited and since there are lots of tourists coming to this place, try to express your admiration quietly, not to disturb the residents.

There are many shops, cafe, restaurants in this area and the pretty old houses!! People are actually living in the old style houses, so you should have a respect to residents when you are going around. There are some overview spots which you have to pay but the view is pretty!! The streets are up and down, so it will be better to wear comfortable shoes!!
Went on a late afternoon on a cold day. Very hilly be prepared to walk. Enjoyed it though, will coming back.

When in Seoul, you must visit this lovely village. Clean , neat , well laid out. The houses of era gone past. lovely botique shops. You may be lucky to spot women dressed in traditional wear strolling on the roads & lanes. An enchanting experience

The place is wonderful well kept and pristine, but please understand this is a residential areq where ypu are free to roam please keep quiet and dont litter in the area... the people living in the area are annoyed of the noise in the area.

Visited June 2018. This is a low priority attraction. The best part of this attraction is the del monte mango ice cream popsicle at the nearby convenience store at a street corner. I don't remember the name of the store. For 50 cents, it was the cheapest and best mango popsicle ice cream I've ever had. Real mango flavor. We looked for this ice cream popsicle every where we went in Seoul and bummed we couldn't find it anywhere else. Bukchon Son Mandu dumplings restaurant was really good too.

Pleasant stroll through the neighbourhood. Mobile tourist information (people in t shirts with maps and recommendations ) available along the streets. Certainly not undiscovered, but a charming neighbourhood to spend a couple of hours exploring. We shopped for gifts here. The cafes and bars are quirky and interesting. Cool glasses shop in a converted workshop. Fun boutiques with interesting fashion , though surprisingly a number of them had no changing facility to try on the clothes. There is more of this neighbourhood than I was expecting. Charming traditional buildings, some open to the public for free, with quick craft activities to experience. Lovely tiled roofs and cute passageways, some pedestrian access only streets. Lovely Saturday afternoon. Lots of visitors wandering around in (hired)traditional dress, looked like there were enjoying the experience.

Walking there was a fantastic experience, for ambience and architecture. Lots of people rent traditional hambok clothes and stroll free there (this gives up an interesting flavour to te scene). The owners of the houses are not happy with the huge ammount of tourists every day,. but have definitely to cope with that..
Very nice place to visit. Easy access via train. Be cooperative to the villager so that they will allow us to visit this very nice place. We rented hanbok to go around.
The walk was a beautiful but left us bit in down as on many places one can find posters asking tourists to leave - it is a residential area that is crowded by people yelling and taking pictures
A quaint village in the heart of the city. Must see place if you want to experience traditional Korean culture and architecture.

It was a nice leisurely walk we took but everywhere around the village are signs to reject tourists and signs to say keep quiet. There are residents residing in the hanoks and i think tourists are really a bother to them. So try to keep the noise level down and move along fast. Don’t take too long to snap your fotos or selfies as well. Oh this is where the drama Goblin was filmed, but I didn’t bother to go find the exact alley and wall. Was trying to move along and finish my tour asap so as not to bother the residents. If you have time and is travelling solo, then mayb you can slowly explore.
If you like the historical place then you need to see here a folk village. it is very interesting to know how korean live back then.
Definitely worth stayin here at a traditional Hanok. It’s worth the experience. The hanok cultural centre is very informative and the manager there was quite enthusiastic

Small remnants of a village can be found here in the center of Seoul. Try to have a Seoul map with you because korean people are not able to speak even a little english but they are extremely kind and polite.
Its really a sight seeing placing. Beautiful architecture and friendly business owner. U gotta walk the slopes.

Although it was nice to see the village and the houses, I personally didn't think it was a must see or do. If you have a limited amount of time in Seoul then you can skip this village. It's just a bunch of traditional houses that most locals still live in. If your really into taking pictures at a traditional village then go ahead but be aware that not everyone's house want people in-front of it.  I only recommend if you have a lot of time or extremely interested in an old town.
Typical old village with ancient houses, not many activities to do here. The view is also not really impressive. Can skip if you don't have enough time

A decent view of old Korean houses, many which are still residences. I have a mixed feeling about this place - as much as I want to walk around and see more of these olden architectures and there are official tourism officers roaming around to help in directions, we saw banners than hinted that tourists aren't that welcomed. I can fully understand - if you are a resident, you wouldn't want to have tourists roaming in your neighborhood, taking pictures and making noises!
- cultural experience we even rented Hanbok to take photos from the Hanok Village - a place where historical places / houses are preserved

Stayed just next to Bukchon Village which I can highly recommend as you will not have a ton of tourists there early morning so if you are an early riser and wants to get in some nice photos before the crowds come, you should stay here. Overall, the traditional area is pleasant, and scenic. plenty of small cafes and craft shops. Taking a stroll here is a must if in Seoul.

The streets and buildings are well preserved and served as residences for the locals. A lot of photo opportunities. However the locals seem to dislike the throngs of tourists flocking to the area and have put up banners stating their displeasure with visitors.
This is a nice area for seeing traditional South Korean architecture. Be sure to take pictures, but be respectful of the people here as well!
Just rows of houses of the rich with hanok architecture. Make sure you drop by the tourist information office to get great tips. Then connect your walk to samcheodong for shopping and food.

i love history and the houses here are just so beautiful. i want to get in to see how it look inside.  it is very tiring to go up and down the street. it is uphill and downhill.  there are many shop where you can buy clothes and everything.  restaurants and coffee shop not to get hungry.  when you are up you will be able to witness a beautiful view, just relax and enjoy

This should be the #1 Must Visit place in Seoul! I enjoyed most this part of city than other places,even more than those palaces. Historic, charming places with beautiful streets,houses,shops,etc.. if you miss this place, be sure that you didn't visit Seoul really!
Many of beautiful old houses with some handcraft workshop where you can take a look to their traditional things. People in the village are very friendly and welcoming.
Well preserved and interesting neighborhood - a time-capsule place. It's in the middle of a modern city, but you feel like you are in another century. Beautiful views.
The Area is nice,and the buildings are beautiful, but you may find the expectation and reality of the crowd didn't match. I recommend to go there not on a peak season. so we can get great pictures

About 15 mins by subway from downtown and a nice traditional place. Lots of pop up stores and skin care shops. Nice view on top of the hill and be ready to walk. Tiring but worthy. If you plan to visit the palace probably shouldn't plan anything else for the day...

We stayed in a hanok during our stay in Seoul and as such, this place is not a particularly interesting place for us.  However, it is conveniently located between the 2 must visit palaces - Gyeongbokgung & UNESCO site Changyeonggung - and offers lots of choices in terms of cafe and eateries. So we headed over to Bukchon after visiting Changyeonggung, took a stroll around looking for an eatery, had a meal there while passing time before the free guided tour time at Gyeongbokgung.  It's worth a visit as there are interesting cafes set in their traditional houses to spend a cosy afternoon with friends or a 1 hr stroll in between the palaces but if short on time, I would recommend giving the place a miss.

Bukchon is an interesting olden residential town with quite a number of eateries, shops and visitors centres there. It is a cool place to take pictures of the ancient looking streets and walking through the steps (there are lots of steps!!) in the cool weather, is nice, I can't say that for summer time though :P  We managed to find cheap hanbok shop which provides Hanbok for rental for photo taking (selfies) at low cost, most of the shops charge extravagantly, and as we have quite a few of us, we didnt want to waste the money, so opt for the cheaper ones. Nonetheless, good experience and we will recommend to anyone who wants a taste of wearing Hanbok :)
Walking along the streets of Bukchon Hanok village will brought you back in time. It might be a little tiring as the street is upslope. Do wear comfortable shoes.

We were just walking around, for a few hours, even if it was very cold and we were freezing. The upside of such weather is that there was few tourists.  Buildings are interesting, traditional, many of them have beautiful, detailed paintings on the door. It's nice that people still leave here, you can see children walking back from school, people doing their daily jobs, it's not an artificial place created only for tourists.  We were invited by one woman on her hostel's terrace, and could see Bukchon from above. It's quite hilly, so there are many places with a nice view.  I would recommend the visit if you want to see some tradition, take a look in the past of common people, not necessarily kings and nobles.

This is a nice area to explore in conjunction with the visit of some of Seoul's palaces. Perhaps not quite as nice as Insadong though to find good food, but plenty of little restaurants nonetheless. It is often very crowded though, so don't expect a quiet traditional Korean village, at least on the week-end.
I visited Bukchon in my 3rd visit to Seoul, and it was one of the best experiences I had. beautifully maintained classic Korean style neighborhood and must see.
Had a lovely day here wandering around. Great to see the contrast between the big modern city and traditional Korean village. A definite must!
Avoid the crowds while not getting in the way of those living in these wonderful homes. The architecture of these old homes is most impressive.

After visiting all city palaces don't miss this historical neigbourhood. Good for strolling in galeries, arts, shops, restaurants in the heart of Seoul. No visit to Seoul is complete without this place. Spend here some hours starting early morning and having you lunch as well.
We enjoyed strolling along the small streets of this Korean traditional house village in Seoul. Very lovely to look at.
Great place to understand the culture of Korea and take photos of traditional Korean houses (Hanok) in this vibrant city.

watching sunset here is one of the most memorable time for me in Korea. sitting in R coffee shop (near the edge of the hill) and had a very nice, heartwarming conversation with So Young-the lovely shop owner. her tea is so good and she boils it 3 times for me :)

The Bukchon area is a great peep into the traditional Korean Hanoks, houses inspired by the Japanese style. The best way to tour this is to take the walk from Anguk st Exit 3 all the way up and then downhill till you reach the education Museum then take a right to reach the Korean Folklore museum and then to the Gyeongbokung Palace. Also at the end of the trail you will find a small shop which sells nice Dreamcatchers and Mini Cacti for a good price. Alternatively you could walk straight down across the road from Education museum towards Anguk St Exit 1

Because of a few mistakes in planning, we ended up spending an afternoon here, and were so glad we did. This is a hidden gem that most visitors on short visits won't get to as it takes some effort and walking. Beautiful architecture, interesting back story, lovely one-off shops and Doo Roo, an exquisite non-chain coffee bar that's so toasty and cozy!

The picture that everyone sees of this place is really a small street. It is always filled with people so it's hard to take a good picture. Walking there, try to ask for directions from the volunteers in red. This is a nice place to take a stroll and see a less busy side of seoul. I recommend coming here first before Samcheungdong as you will end up in the middle of that street and you can take a walk downhill

Came to view the hanok houses which are beautifully restored, quite a nice walk from Exit 3 of Angkuk station on Subway Line 3. Can imagine it would very warm in summer but now being winter, the walk uphill was comfortable.  Loved peaking into some of the beautiful courtyards housing local businesses which allow you to try on traditional hanbok, take some photos while they shared about the korean culture for a fee or do it like me just walk through the village on your own and let your instinct lead you through the winding paths.  There are plenty of cafes, restaurants, shops to keep one engrossed and you can easily spend a few hours here.

Best to visit early in the morning because it gets crowded closer to mid-day. Interesting narrow alleys, clean; traditional Koreans houses have beautiful wooden doors. Most homes are private, but there is an interesting compound that is open to the public. Two other sites : National Folk Musuem and Gyeongbokgung Palace are walking distance from Bukchon - interesting 15 - 20 minute walk.
Its history is 600 years long, but the area is so well-preserved and so full of tourists, art shops and guest houses etc. that it felt like a very nice walk in the Korean version of Disneyland.

Our taxi dropped us off this 100 year old Korean exhibition house either a scenic overview of the Bukchon village, unfortunately we were not allowed inside the house because we were not with a guided tour. But fortunately they allowed us to enter & view the house from the garden -- to officially open in 2 months. This was a home of a Korean surgeon & now bought by the City of Seoul. Yes it's worth a visit then walk to G-Palace . Ginseng chicken soup Restaurant was our lunch stop in this area.

If you want to escape from the heavy urban mood when in Seoul, this could be one of the places to be. Unless it's summer season, Bukchon can be really quiet, especially in the mornings. On busier days there are usually many street musicians and you can also buy some handmade crafts. There are lots of coffee shops, desert cafes, restaurants and galleries around the place. It's one of those sophisticated areas of Seoul, that is always warm, welcoming and a little bohemian. Please note, that it's actually a residential area!

I had a quick walk through Bukchon village at night in Seoul. My intention was to return again in the daylight, but even in the evening, it was beautiful, and gives a glimpse into the past. The narrow streets and old, well restored houses are a delight to see.

Seoul and Korea are full of history often unknown in the West. On a sunny Saturday, I strolled around the Bukchon Hanok village. This is a wonderfully restored series of hill streets, taking you back nearly 600 years to traditional Korean villages. The streets were traditionally the residential quarter of high-ranking government officials and nobility during the Joseon Dynasty (in the 1400s). Beautifully restored and with expensive residences with great views over the city, the small traditional homes nestle closely together on steep streets. Great to spend time walking, shop browsing and enjoying very good coffee in the numerous Korean-Western coffee houses.

if u fan of Lee Min-ho & watch Personal Taste drama this is the place u must come. U can feel korean drama when come here. The location is very beautiful. Tips: please used the correct shoes when walk here as u need to walk and walk and walk & some climb the road.
Walking around the small street of Bukchon is a must when visiting Seoul. It one of the only few remaining locations where you could see the traditional houses.
Made a lot of photos of my GF there, place is just great, Very atmospheric. Also can recommend stay there for a night in one of that ancient houses (its available)
Really? What's the big deal? Yes, you can see the glimpse of old neighbor hood, but it really didn't do it for me. I definately would not recommend people, i'd rather visit one of the palaces.

The traditional houses (Hanok) were really beautiful and many interesting shops lie within the little aisles. Do note that this is a residential area and minimise the noise level as it will affect the residents. There were guides from the tourist information centre who walk around to assist the tourists. No smoking is allowed and the guides will ask you to stop smoking if spotted, which I appreciate as non-smokers do not enjoy their experience at this beautiful village being tainted by the smokers. Be prepared to walk lots of slopes and stairs. You can get a map from the tourist information centre, the staff were really friendly there.

A very charming and rustic neighbourhood with a great variety of restaurants, cafes and little nice shops! Good to shop and stroll, with very traditional houses. It's like a wanderland away from the busy and crowded shopping district of Myeongdong.

The two best pieces of advice in visiting Bukchon are: Ignore many of the “recommended walk routes” you find, particularly in guide books. They would be better called “If you walk in and around this general perimeter we’ve laid out, you’ll see Bukchon”. Go to the “Images” option of most search engines and type in “Bukchon”, you’ll find alternative, much more detailed (and perhaps better) walking route maps.  Get an early start (getting to Bukchon by 8:00 – 8:30 A.M. is recommended). The area is surprisingly small and the streets very narrow. By 10:00, it’ll start to fill up with mini tour groups and other tourists with cameras to the point that any pictures you take will be mostly of other people taking pictures. This is especially true for the north-west section of Bukchon. [If it’s just you and the occasional resident walking their dog or walking to school, you’ll know you’re there at the right time]. If you’re staying close by, it might be a good idea to visit it until crowds start to show up, then leave and pick up where you left of the next day.  Finally, not to be preachy but keep in mind that you are, for all intents and purposes, in these people’s front and back yards.

I visit this place so many times, and every single time the experience proves to be different. On days when you're lucky, there ain't that many tourists or students, so you can roam around in peace while making the most out of the rustic ambience. Do give the croquette shop a try (there's only one along the way so you will definitely spot it! :))

This provides an insight into the traditional Korean Hanok housing. Highly recommended to take a stroll through the many and little alleys for a close look at the Hanok housing. Don't be afraid to walk through the alleys which can be rather quiet. A few of these housings have been turned into commercial with homestay hotels and shops. So do take some time if you wish to take a glimpse of the interior of the Hanok houses.  It is a real hilly walk at some areas, especially at Bukchon-ro-11-gil but at that highest point, you get to see the rooftop of the Hanok housing...real beautiful.  Wear good shoes/ sneakers.
Lovely place with traditional Korean houses, but you'll need to walk quite a bit. Good for photography. Nice view :)
Here we can see the traditional korean house, small street left right traditional korean house with some art shops...and cafe in beginning of street....i like this area very much !
Like the title says. 15 minutes is enough. It's just a suburban area with a couple of authentic but modern renovated....

Very disappointing. The photos in the tourist guides looked lovely but the reality was thousands of tourists and because this is still a residential area all the streets and lanes were filed with parked cars (can only assume they were paid to park elsewhere when photos were taken or photoshopped out of the pictures in the guides) we stayed 20 minutes, took obligatory photos and left.

It was like you were being transported to the time Dae Jang Gyeum, the lead actress in the Korean Soap,Opera Jewel in the Palace, had the chance the wear the Hanbok, charming, I feel like an empress, i got the glimpse of how the past was for the Koreans, their houses was about the same with Filipino houses,

We felt like this area's charm was exaggerated. Pretty but not much to do besides take a quick stroll and maybe grab a bite to eat. Various guidebooks had advised us to spend several hours there, but we didn't understand the appeal.
My wife and I enjoyed getting lost in the small streets and pretending to be in a different time. You just have to block the hordes of tourists. Not to be missed to get a taste of traditional Korea.
It is fun to walk around the area. Especially the little craft shops inside or the small cafe's. It is close to the palace!

Quaint little village with small alleys and interesting architecture. If you have the time and money, visit or try out the classes and attractions offered. If not, just strolling thru them with give you a view of old Korea. Most tourist maps will provide you a detailed path/ journey in experiencing Bukchon without getting lost. Wear comfortable shoes as some areas are steep and requires some effort walking or climbing u stairs. Food establishments are located towards the south part of the attraction.

We spent a few hours on an afternoon walking around the recommended tour from the information centre. Absolutely beautiful original style Korean architecture. History is everywhere you look here. There are also a couple of cultural centres you can visit and check out the local art and craft. The whole family enjoyed this walk. It is a little hilly in spots, but just take it easy and it is fine. I would definitely visit this place again if ever back in Seoul.

It was nice to see the lovely homes. Definitely bring your walking shoes, and be prepared to be walking drenched in sweat if you are going in the summer, as we did today. Looked like there were quite a few options for food and other refreshments. While walking around, we saw a sign for the Institute of Traditional Korean Cuisine, however we were sad to find it was closed. In fact, many little shops and galleries looked closed due to it being Sunday. We did go into the home of Go Hui-dong who was Korea's first artist who painted in the Western style. A staff member gave us a little tour of his home which also featured his artwork.

we wanted to go to bukchon because the pictures looked great. however, we should have stuck with the pictures. the real thing is so-so. not sure if we went to the wrong side of the bukchon village but there were also other tourists with us and so we were confident that it was the correct place.

This is a neighborhood in Seoul that includes numerous houses that are hundreds of years old and are beautiful to visit. Keep in mind that this is a neighborhood where people live, so as the signs advise, keep the noise to a minimum.

The streets are of the ancient past, however, very much renovated to add the modern feel. Hence to me, it has lost its ancient feel a lot.  I walked for 15 minutes and was done. The rest of shops along the surrounding streets are almost 100% western and modern shops like café, coffee, souvenirs.
Did not really find anything very interesting on my trip to Bukchon. Therefore would not be revisiting when i am in Seoul.

Nice area to just stroll around. The Bukchon hanok village has a lot of narrow cosy streets with traditional "hanok" wooden houses. Recommend to go up in Bukchon observatory (3000 KRW pr person). From there you get a good view over the hanok village roofs and across to N Seoul tower in Namsan.
Beautiful village with amazing old houses. Have a tranquil walk around, and take in the age-old scenery.
different style of the traditional korean house are right here. but you have to walk up and down to see all different house, sport shoes is better

Bukchon is a traditional Korean village, composed of several neighborhoods. It is composed of several narrow alleys. It has more than 600 years of history, allowing the visitors to experience the atmosphere of the Joseon dinasty. Some of the recently renewed houses can be visited for a cost.
It is like a city within a city and most of the homes are preserved with the old ways of building. Lots of shopping too! Make sure you have comfy shoes on for this tour.
Nice stroll around old houses although some of them seemed very modern! There are many nice shops from local designers and a few nice cafes albeit very expensive!

Its Nice if you were to visit early mornings otherwise this place swell by noon time with large crowd of Camera touting tourist from all over the world !! Wonderful Traditional Houses You must look out for the Old Quiant corner where you find traditional simple food is being served !! Delicious

This beautiful part of Seoul is best seen on a nice cool sunny day. Lots of uphill walking, so wear your most comfortable sneakers. I walked all the way up til I can get a good view of namsan. The houses were beautiful and the shops around were awesome. Bukchon, together with samcheong ro can occupy your whole day. So many things to see and do.

Tourists can go to this place before going to palaces. This is near to Changdeokgung Palace. There's a simple reminder for tourists to keep silence as a respect for the residents. Very nice place to take pictures.!

Visited Bukchon on an unusually warm day during early Spring. Other than the warm weather, the walk around Bukchon was interesting. The traditional houses are built closely-knitted and you wonder how it feels to live so close to your neighbours but I got a chance to step into a open house and surprisingly the internal compound was very surreal, cooling, private and cosy. On top of the traditional houses, there are plenty of quaint shops to keep your eyes and wallets busy. My girlfriend and I enjoyed our first trip there so much that we visited again during our 8-day stay in Seoul. On a good cool day, you can leisurely walk from Gyeongbukgong Palace to Bukchon. A must visit place.

Exploring quaint streets full of traditional housing and monuments and just so tranquil. Easy walking for the most part with some small sections that are up hill but the views are worth it. It is a 10 min walk from Insadong shopping street.
It's a hideout in within the busy city. Traditional Korean houses can be seen in the area. Be prepared to go up slopes n also walk in a huge area. Wear comfortable shoes!

I enjoy getting lost in Bukchon area. I enjoy the tranquility, the culture, the history of what Seoul once was. If you are lucky and get to experience a little Bukchon home stay, that probably is the best decision you would possibly make during your visit in the wonderful city.
I love wandering through this historic area of Seoul. The houses are beautifully restored. It should be on everyone's list to see how people used to live.

This is my 1st visit to Seoul and over the 2 days visit I've gone back twice to this place. It is a place for people who appreciate old traditional buildings. I love wondering on every paths as many of them are unique and different in their own ways. One of the Hanok has crafted creatures on their balcony, another have plants in traditional pots outside their house, very Zen & peaceful. There is a shop called Granhand, love his creations of different scents. It's of natural scents made from plant extracts of quality ingredient, very different feel from the branded eau de toilette over the counter. Amongst the Hanok one of them are opened to public for a minimal price of KRW15000 entrance fee comes with a nice herbal tea at the end of the tour of. This house belongs to an owner who reside in Latin America and this is their summer house. I was told this house worth USD$4M. If i ever come back again I will live in the Hanok guest house instead of hotels.

Nice walk up the hill to see the old style Korean housing and view over the city. on the way - tiny little shops and boutiques and coffee shops. Definitely worth of visiting and strolling through the narrow streets.

Don't be afraid to just wander about; go into alleys and such. The place is bustling with tourists so I doubt you can get lost. Climb uphill, like all the way up. The view looking down to Insadong is really scenic. Take a selfie in between quieter alleys with lesser tourists, try to capture the details of the hanoks. I bet you, the pictures will turn out unique and picturesque.
Beautiful, quiet with many lovely stores and cafes. Great for a stroll, a bite, people and building watching. Worth the visit!!
It's an utterly picturesque neighborhood & you will really feel the place, it is very well preserved & will give tourist a very good snapshot of what authentic Korean living is.
I would say avoid this as it is mostly a tourist trap, with shops all over the place. Instead visit the Namsan Hanok Village, it is quieter, cleaner and is pretty much the same thing.
walked with two young children...everyone enjoyed the day. stopped to buy souvenirs, ate street food, took tons of pics of architecture...wish we had known about guest houses in area!!

What a great use of time if you want to see something that takes you back time 700 years. What fascinating architecture that you can touch and sense. As you walk the streets and view the houses, you are able to step into some of them and and see what the elite class considered their homes. There are not many places where you can see and touch history.

This was probably my biggest disappointment in Seoul. Yes, the houses are somewhat old-fashioned, but you can see similar architecture all over Korea. Personally, I felt like I and the other tourists were being very intrusive - it is a residential area, after all. I'd only check it out if you happen to be in the area, and even then I wouldn't stay for more than a few minutes.
Hanok Village in the big city of modern Seoul. Should join the "Bokchon Hanok Village Walking Tour" for the first time to check out the important points.

Going here really does feel like stepping in a different place and time, so very different from Seoul's modern buildings. We had a free walking tour from the Korea Visit Org (highly recommended, the guides speak good English and are very friendly -- plus it's free) and it was enjoyable.  Only thing is the entire walk can be very tiring, especially the uphill areas. My two elderly companions didn't enjoy it as much because of all the walking. Wear good shoes, maybe trim your itinerary a bit if you're short on time. This is a place best made for slower walks and absorbing the scenery.

Let me just say that having lived in Seoul for two years, I developed a walking tour route for when people visited. This attraction is part of that tour that can be lengthened or shortened as needed. The general route was: Begin at City Hall, walk up through Gwanghwamun Square visiting the Cheonggyecheon Stream and a possible visit to Hangul Museum under statue, continue to Gyeongbukgung Palace. Time permitting walk up through Samcheongdong into the Bukchon Hanok Village, continue down to where the tour ends in Insadong. This is enough for just about a full day of touring and requires A LOT of walking.  One of the interesting things about Bukchon is that it is in a sense a 'living museum.' People still live here and these are still active houses. Looking down the narrow streets over the roof lines really gives you an idea of what Seoul might have looked like long ago.  Being one of the major tourism spots in Seoul, there are a lot of tourist trap type shops and cafes. But, all round this area are some really great traditional tea shops and even little art galleries tucked away. It's worth doing some exploring. As touristy as it is, it is not as bad as Insadong and tends to be far less crowded.  Well worth the walk up for a vist!

This is absolutely fantastic! Bukchon is a traditional Korean hanok village in the heart of Seoul. The hanok houses are so beautiful, and I couldn't stop taking photos. It is possible to go inside some of the houses, and you can also buy morning or afternoon tea and just enjoy the atmosphere of this amazing place. The streets are quite steep, but it is definitely worth making the effort to navigate your way through them. And you'll find some great views over Seoul too. I would highly recommend a visit to Bukchon.

Bukchon is a place to go if you are into something different, unique for photography. You feel like you kind of step back in time a bit there with the architecture. Traditional village and some unique shopping can be done there.

been to this place the morning before our flight going back home (manila). though im satisfied seeing the hanok, but i would love to experience going inside and see how traditional houses were arranged. unfortunately, we were not able to follow the tour map and were not able to reach the highlight of the hanok village (where the abundant hanoks are located). dont forget to try a mango dessert at philippines dessert cafe. :)  how to get here? we took a train from myeongdong. the nearest subway station is Anguk (orange line, line 3). take exit 3, walk few meters and take left turn for Gyedong-gil (road/street).  For tour map, visit this site and print the map: http://www.visitseoul.net/en/article/article.do?_method=view&art_id=58509&lang=en&m=0004004004001&p=04
The area is nice filling with coffee shop and nice shopping area. However, I am not very impressed for the old town part. It is nice to visit but don't expect too much.

I stayed in a traditional house and slept on the floor for 2 nights. It was a little hard for my old bones but I enjoyed the experience. It was fun to walk around the neighborhood and see all the old houses. note:( I was there in April 2013, not 2014 but was not given that choice).
I was ready to go home almost empty-handed. Then I came by Bukchon hours before my return flight... Very interesting things you could buy for your loved ones back home!
Next time I go back would like to stay in a Traditional Korean wooden home, kitted out with all the latest hi teach amenities. Worth a walk around. Good restaurants around.

Whenever you visited an old village, one would think it is a show case. In this case, this is real life though the building dated back some 500 years ago. They have couple of houses open to visitors to see inside.  It is only available to visit before sunset to give residence some privacy. The area outside the old village is also very interesting with cafe and restaurant', also very near to president residence.

Long walks during winter time is killing with the wind blowing pretty strong but we have a wonderful time at the Bukchon Hanok Village. Took lots of pictures and there are many shops to buy little cute items for yourself and as souvenirs.

Lots of traditional homes still preserved from the olden days. I went here on mid May and it was still chilly. So bring your jackets during any season. You have to walk a lot from the station and the place is quite hilly so sneakers are recommended. The neighborhoods are a mix of traditional and modern houses. People live inside. Lots of flowers blooming on early summer. The roads were quite narrow and scenic. Excellent for pictures. It was great cultural experience. If you don't care about culture, don't bother with it. You might find it Uninteresting.  I was very tired of walking towards the end of my journey there, so I rested in a Cafe And had some shaved ice cream with red bean paste and rice cake. The portion was big but still it was overpriced, in my opinion. Actually, everything in there is more pricey than anywhere else. It's a stylish little town. And I bet the merchants know tourists go there so it's expected, I guess.  Despite the cold weather and aching feet, I still really enjoyed my trip there. Definitely recommend!!!! ♡

I just like the idea of an old heritage village wherever it may be. Luckily Seoul has it with Bukchon. It's a nice feeling to get lost in here. Surprises await for wanderers alike. Here we wore traditional silk hanbok and tried imagining how it is to live in ancient Korea. Great experience!  Dislikes - Hmnn... Sometimes we got into a private property or we struck a dead end. I hope more signposts would help DIY travelers like us who do not depend on tours. Other than that, the place is amazing!

Yes, I'm a Lee Min Ho fan, so I made it a point to find the Sanggojae in the Bukchon Hanok Village where Lee Min Ho shoot for the Perfect Match koreanovela! The village is perfect for architecture enthusiasts who want to get a taste of the old Seoul. Perfect for a visit after your tour in the Gyeongbokgung Palace.

The area is quite hilly and it's difficult to explore more than the main street (which also goes up hill). The houses are old and many of them require you to use stairs to enter or to visit the basement. So my experience there was short and unsatisfying. We did try some local snacks and they were good.

This is one of the beautiful places in Seoul where travellers may wish to consider. I loved the traditional looking houses and it makes me feels like Iiving in a warmth environment. Going to this place is not difficult and it is about 300 m walk from Anguk station with tourist information signage to guide along. If you crave for coffee while walking to Bukchon, you may wish to pamper yourself with a cup of Americano coffee from "unlimited coffee" and I am sure you will like the aroma.
All the small houses and road are very interesting. You seems to travel back in time and walk on the streets that history walk on. Just like going to Paris or other old Europe city.

Strolling through the streets of Bukchon you will get a completely different feeling from the one you can get in the other neighbourhoods of Seoul. Bukchon has an ancient and charming look but maintains the fashionable, hip and cool bars and cafés that are typical of the city. You can go shopping here, but also eat in an authentic small Korean restaurant or have an afternoon break on a rooftop, while watching the sun set. Definitely worth a visit!

We climbed up from Samcheong side (Kyeongbok Goong east gate), following the map given by the red moving tourist info girls. Make sure your legs are ready for the extremely steep staircases. Definitely not for elderly and those who are afraid of height.
We though we were going to visit an old village but we ended up looking at people's houses. It is an actual residential area where people decided to keep the traditional design..

Visit early in the morning around 9 a.m. before the hordes of tourists descend on this village. You can see the interesting architecture of the houses, especially the roofs and the doors/gates. There are museums within the village--some are for free. On the other side are small quaint stores.

Bukchon hanok village is a combination of old and new buildings, with some cute stores. There are also several little museums that are independently run, and lots of residential housing. There were good photo opportunities, but overall, it wasn't quite as charming as I'd hoped. I did like that it's still functional, though. Note that this involves a lot of walking, including up steep hills. It's not really handicapped accessible. There were fairly clear signs and also Seoul tour information people who could give directions and provide maps. Overall worth an hour's stroll.

This area has many traditional korean houses, and it is well organized with plenty of tourist offices and good maps with recommendations on the houses, views and businesses in the area. Get one before you head out.

Strolling the streets of the Bukchon Hanok Village is like stepping into Joseon Dynasty Korea for a while. The traditional houses are beautiful and kept in pristine condition considering their age.  I suggest getting a map in your language since the streets felt a bit like a maze or labyrinth at times; although, there are so many people around, it would be nearly impossible to get lost. There are some really fantastic views of the city from this area as well; so, it makes for some perfect photo ops as well.  Some of the hanoks have been turned into tea rooms, museums, and art galleries. This would be pretty much the only way you could view the interior of one of these historic homes; because the rest are still private residences.  Go when the weather is fine and you have a few hours to stroll.

We went to walk around in Bukchon and visited the Hanok Village on our very first day in Seoul, which was just walking distance from our bed and breakfast.  We fell in love with this old village immediately even though the whole village only consists in a few blocks, we can easily trolling through all these little narrow streets admiring the very well kept Traditional homes, the colors and the designs of these home are so amazing, from walking around these streets in this village, sometimes we catch a glimpse of Namsang Seoul Tower, seeing the contrast between Old and New.  Also don't forget to stop by and take a Tea break at Bukchon Best Prospect Tea Museum, they served very good tea even though the price is a little expensive, but it worths it. Tea and coffee's culture are huge in Korea.

There are people dedicated to help tourists that you could ask for directions and they'd also give you a free map.  The place is hilly. You'd only see the facade or the roof of the traditional houses. Good for taking pictures. I found no other activity to do here.

actually, lots of this area is private are which is owned by citizen. but the government opens for public as a tourist destination. so, they suggest you not to make noisy sounds. you can see the typical of old style Korean house. my friend who was my guide said that this area is quite expensive. so, all the house might have expensive price. don't forget to take a map at the tourist information, because they give a direction how to explore this place. only few place in the Bukchon that have free entrance. if you want to see inside the house, you have to pay 10.000 won. if you want see all around Bukchon from 3rd fl., you have to pay also (but i forgot how much is it). i've found nothing special in here, just to improve knowledge about the Korean tradition. Bukchon is very near to Gyeongbokgung. so, after visit Gyeongbokgung, try to walk to find Bukchon.

It's actually a bit over-rated because the place is swarming with tourists, particularly the two main streets with the old hanok houses. Some of the teahouses are nice but overpriced. The walk through Samcheongdong and into Bukchon is nice though.

We walked here from Changdeokgung Palace and looked for a place for lunch. Found a pizza place, very good. Then walked around the historic homes with the traditional tile roofs. Walked up hill and down hills. Could see Seoul Tower in the distance. There were stores for shopping also. Very picturesque.
Quaint little houses and streets, somewhat akin to old Korea (although also somewhat touristy). Certainly worth going for.

Since you are in Korea, this is a must visit place for tourist. Quite a long walk to the main place from the station especially during the hot weather. Wear comfy shoes and clothes. Nice spots for photography but can get quite crowded since the paths are narrow. There are some cafes around if you're tired after a long walk but they could be more expensive than your lunch meal.

Bukchon Hanok Village is unique because it is mostly residential. It is a quiet and calm area which is definitely worth visiting if you're only staying in Seoul. If you have more time in Korea I would highly recommend the Jeonju Hanok Village which is much larger and more interesting (it has lots of cute cafes and boutiques too).  Pick up a map from the tourist centre and do some exploring in Bukchon :)

The visit to Bukchon was one of the more enjoyable aspects of my 5 day trip.  If you are yearning for a respite from the city and all that shopping, it's worth visiting Bukchon.  Recommended that you wear very comfortable walking shoes as there's lots of walking to do (think up hill and down hill as the roads are very steep), bring a bottle of water and a camera!  The place is very scenic with lots of traditional Hanok houses/roofs!  Did not spend much time walking around as it was summer and the sun was scorching hot! Took a rest at a cafe but would love to come back in the winter!

We went here looking for a specific restaurant, so we did not explore too much. It was hot and the place is hilly, but it's a unique neighborhood in a modernized city. Tourist information people hand out maps if you are hopelessly lost (which is easy to do) and it's imperative to keep quiet as it's a residential area, but it was a nice stroll.

Took some time to find the village. From the route that we took, we have to get up a flight of stone steps before locating the village.  The traditional houses are very beautiful. Especially when you can find rows and rows of it. They had inhabited houses, so we took care not to make too much noise. A lot of the houses we found are unique and we took some great shots.  However, the area is filled with tourists. If there had been less tourists, I think it would have been a more relaxed stroll in the village.

This is one area not to be missed if you are in Seoul. A stroll through the streets of this lovely Korean village, with the traditional homes still being lived in, is an absolute treat for any traveler.

I would highly recommend taking the time to see this area  There is an info office on one of the main streets where you can pick up a map and an itinerary and it shows you around most of the area and gives an insight into the life of the villagers who lived there and worked for the palaces surrounding the area, its very interesting and awesome views from the top of the city

I went there on a Friday afternoon. I didn’t read up much on this place before I go so I was expecting it to be a fully developed tourist location. However, most of it is a local living neighborhood. It is nice to walk around this neighborhood slowly, as it got a lot of traditional houses and the view are stunning.
This is a very accessible place to visit on foot. Delightful architecture and glimpses into inner courtyards with view of distant hills. September 2012 was a pleasant time to stroll there

A must visit in seoul, where the traditional old quarter situated in the middle of modern glitzy seoul. A comfortable stroll next to the palace and Insadong area. Can easily spend about an hour or two. Has the lovely korean traditional houses. We'll preserved. If lucky can visit some inside and take a look. Has some lovely cafés and art galleries.

May be nice for Korea; but doesn't compare to other historical districts in China or Japan. Very easy to find, just walk out of the subway and walk down the street. There is maps in the subway station. And the information desk provides maps to use for walking. I do like just walking around and plenty of nice shops and restaurants. Just not that special for historical district.

Interesting to see the mix of old (traditional houses) and new (latest model of cars). You walk up and down the hills to visit real people's residences. Get a map at the information center. The map points out 8 suggested spots in this area for good picture talking. We had a very nice lunch in this area and had a nice stroll in the neighborhood after meal. Follow the map and read the information provided. It is worth a visit.
A great hike where tradition meets modernity. Gives you a glimpse into old Hanyang. Look out for the photo spots.

A place that is good for evening walk and taking photographs. Not much to see here, only traditional/modern houses.  Make sure you grab the map at Bukchon tourist information so you know how to explore it right. Bukchon is a big area, get lost among the alleys and enjoy the view! But if you go here during the winter, make sure you wear something to keep you warm.  There're a lot of local restaurants nearby, make sure you try one of these ;)

Be prepared to walk and if in winter, then dress very warm. A web of small streets with a variety of shops to browse in. When hungry, there are numerous cafés and restaurants to try. We had traditional Korean cuisine in a restaurant with no English name and hence will not be able to write a review on it. However it was hearty hot pot black sauce teibokki that was great on a zero degree day! We had amazing waffles in a Cafe Dal along Samcheongdong gil, an adjoining road.
the most beautiful place .... traditional places !! .... thats korea .... not just kpop and dramas .... this is the real south korea !

This area is full of little nice but surprising museums : chicken museum, embroidery museum, amulets museum. We even got the unplanned opportunity to learn how to paint on wood and get a tea ceremony. So don't hesitate to try some of those little museums , you never know what awaits you inside !

Outside Anguk subway station and around a corner, Bukchon has many of the traditional Hanok still standing.  We went on a snowy day where the flurries added a sweet icing to the cake, perfect for photos.
Very authentical residential area. It gives a good impression of local customs as well. there are maps available to guide you through the villlage

This is a real village that people live in. And it looks straight out of the old Korean dramas! There are free maps of the roads, and there are many little homes that offer you to make a Korean craft (paid). Or you can walk around and just take pictures. Also there is an artsy hipster like area where there are art, hand-craft items shops and little coffee shops. Very cute. What's also nice is that there are about 9 picture spots that are truely nice.
This is really not much more than a pleasant walk. Make sure you get a local map from the local tourist guides - you can't miss them dressed in all red.

korean traditional houses right in the heart of busy seoul? surely you don't want to miss it! i think it's one of the best site in seoul. it's very near from changdeokgung palace, and you'll still have times to explore other sites nearby. i really love the architecture of the houses, but please be silent, for people are living in those beautiful houses. there was a backyard in a house with adorable exterior. i'm not quite sure what place it was, weather it was a cafe or just a backyard, but it was really-really charming. my advice: be prepared to hike the hilly pavement, and prepare your camera batery full.

I visited this place on last Sunday and it was very nice. If you want to see traditional Korean houses - Bukchon village is the best place. To go there you can take subway. Get down at anguk station. Form anguk station, it is at walk-able distance of 5-10 mints. For more clear directions you can also take help of help-desk near anguk station  Things to see here : - traditional Korean houses and roads. - In few place you will see some workshops for different activities. You can also enjoy over here. - There are few shops which sells some traditional things of Korea like ornaments.  Overall place is very good for one time visit.

Although it did make for a good walk around to explore, I always all that amazed by the hanoks themselves. Lots were new, and some were still being constructed. I didn't feel very much like I was "back in history" like many others claim. Different experience for everyone I guess, just not a great one for me.
Nice place to feel the past while being in the future. House are very nice and very authentic. Please respect that people are really leaving in these houses.

Walking through Bukchon is a very refreshing experience. You get an eclectic mix of shops, and there are also many small boutiques and boutique hotels there. There are also coffee places and tea houses for you to get a cuppa to soak in the atmosphere. All this makes a walk through Bukchon a different experience from other parts of the city.  From Bukchon, you can also get a panoramic view of Changdeokgung, and there are many arts and crafts shops there too. Go to the tourist information at Changdeokgung to get a walking map of Bukchon.

Bukchon Is an alley, where you can find the Hanok village, its not the real village but a re creation of what their traditionbal house looks like. I like the alley, where there are locals shopping for Korean made trinkets, there are also restaurants there that offer affordable meals

This is as authentic Korean village and entire experience was delightful! We lunched at a tiny family owned cafe...The language barrier was overcome by the welcoming warmth of the owners! The homes are lovely and the overall feeling was simply awesome!

Had an amazing time wandering the alleyways of Bukchon and peeking into various shops. Samchongdong street has an overabundance of 'super cute' coffee shops, but the Sujebi restaurant with a long of Koreans waiting to get in as if it was a meatpacking club is a gem - they serve traditional handmade noodles.
Was so tired after climbing the stone steps all the way to the top but you will see very interesting Hanok guest house. More picture taking!

Bukchon Hanok village is a sampling of ancient Seoul. Famous artisans and well connected families supporting the palaces used to live here. The area is near Gyeongbok Palace, Changdeok Palace and the Jongmyo Royal Shrine. I spent an entire day walking between these three places since I like to hike. It's possible to see women in traditional Korean wedding dresses using these street corners for photo opps on weekends. Steep hills and a few cobblestone roads make running or hiking shoes with ankle support a wise choice for touring these places.

Bukchon Village is an interesting place to explore and you can find many traditional Hanok over there. Good for taking pictures!  I had written a blog on Bukchon Hanok Village you can read it at http://loveanqila.blogspot.sg/2013/09/travelogue-bukchon-hanok-village.html or www.loveanqila.blogspot.com under the travelogue tab.

This place is very organized. There is a small information center before the walk starts. Just ask around where the information center is. They will give you a map and then you can follow the map to walk around all the typical Korean streets in the area. It can be quite hot if you go in summer time, however there are coffee shops you can stop, which makes is very enjoyable.

Have to say that I love this place! I love wandering around the village. There are many restaurants, cafes, shops and private houses but all are in traditional style. Verybeautiful. I also love the atmostphere here, quiet and peaceful. I visited many famous places in Seoul, but all other places are busy and noisy. Come to Seoul everybody should visit this place. But don't forget the map in case you get lost!

A quaint little, well maintained village behind the gyeongbokgung palace. My suggestion? Once you are done with visiting the sights one has ticked in this village, just close the map and walk around the streets with the aim of getting to Samcheong Park. The walk itself will be worth it and once you get to Samcheong park, do the trail which leads to the wall and view Seoul from the top of a hill.

You will find many traditional homes and guest houses here. My favorite was a cafe with the hours of operation listing "9 am - whenever". I come from a city where things shut down at 6pm for the most part and most people go home after work. Too see shops like this was a treat along with the historical backdrop.
The little alleyways full of traditional workshops and homes are beautiful, and this is a welcome respite from the hustle and bustle of nearby Jongno and Insadong.

This is my second visit here (my 1st was in September 2012), and this time I made sure I covered the area (see my earlier review). I think September is a better time (maybe even October) because one gets to see the greens turning colors with the autumn coming. Last year I even spotted a pear tree. Make sure to come in the morning when the sun is not so high up because it sure gets hot when you walk around admiring the houses in the quite hilly area, houses that have been maintained and live in. Get the map from the tourist information center as you walk from the metro exit towards the Bukchon area. You will also be informed of the house number where Korean dramas have been filmed i.e Lee Min Ho in Personal Taste and Jung Yong Hwa in Heartstring - just the outside people:(

Walked around Bukchon Hanok village for hours, taking pictures and loving the pretty traditional houses. We only found one of the eight photo spots but it didn't matter, still got to enjoy amazing views ^^ Be prepared to walk up and down a lot, this place sure has a lot of hills

If I were to move to Seoul, this is where I'd stay. Love the quaintness of the whole suburb with its mixture of new and old from residences to shops to museums. Will probably need 3 days to complete the whole suburb and take in the sights, not counting the palace visitations! Bukchon sits between 2 palaces. The area is pretty hilly where the houses/hanoks are and a gentle hill where the main shopping street of Samcheong-dong is. If you're looking for local designs and quirky what nots, Samcheong-dong is the place to go.

This place was a little hard to find. The tourist info office was closed when we arrived at the area around 9am so we had to ask people in the street for directions. which is a bit of a task because few can speak english. It's a good place to see. We went inside a private house where the girl guide explained the traditions of Hanuk houses. (charged us 10000 won).

This would be a good place to visit if you want to see the traditional houses of Korea. Most of these houses have people living in them so we had to make sure not to make too much noise while we were visiting the place. There was a couple of houses where they actually allowed you to go in and take pictures but I guess it's all up to the owners. There are museums and workshops inside too but we didn't manage to visit them all as we didn't have enough time. Would definitely come and explore more again if I had the time.
See korean traditional houses and the best view of Seoul here. Experience the old world charm and snap beautiful pictures of old houses and alleys.

Beautiful old hanoks mixed with new ones makes this a special area. Filled with artisan pottery and textile shops along with tea houses, gardens, coffee shop, boutiques and restaurants. It is particularly lovely in autumn when the leaves have turned.
Wish to visit the inside of the house rather than looking at the over from the roof tops. The free walking tour guide was very helpful.

This neighborhood is awesome, though I wonder how the residents feel. It's great to just explore all of the various tiny (and I mean tiny) roads. Just be respectful and mindful that people do call this place home.  I recommend that you go on a weekday to avoid a sea of visitors. I actually went twice. The first time was great because it indeed was a weekday. I decided to return on my last day in Korea to capture a few more photos. This time, it was Buddha's Birthday (a national holiday) and the place was crawling with people posing for photos. Not ideal if you're trying to capture that quaint residential feel.

A must see in Seoul and good to do this along with the palace tours as it is just east of the main palace. Similar to hutongs in Beijing, these are the traditional Korean style residences perched in alleyways on a hill in Seoul. Great for just wandering and having a coffee break at one of the bohemian coffee shops that artists have around the area.  They usually have tourist volunteers on some popular corners where you can get a map and they show you the popular walking routes. You could do this in 1 hour, but definitely worth checking out for your first time visit to Seoul.

love this place.... the place is really huge, if you really want to visit all 8 photo spots, remember to wear your most comfortable walking shoes, winter sonata fans, the high school in which the bae yong jun and choi ji woo met is in this area as well  Too bad i went on a rainy day, and I got lost, though we holding a map and asking the locations of the photo spots from the locals, we still got lost, nobody seems to know where the photo spots located

Well maintained, elegant and pretty, this in an area of intrigue. Beautifully landscaped, touristy and endowed with museums and workshops but it is still real place where locals live. A must see! Allow at least four hours. There are numerous places to eat and drink.
So, this is what Korea looked like before. Worth a look. But be prepared for the uphill climb. Thought could go in the houses but they're residences! So keep quiet.

A visit to one or more of the royal palaces, a wander amongst the shops and restaurants of Insadong and around the Bukchon neighbourhood makes for a very good day out in Seoul.The Hanok houses are beautifully maintained and you can pick up a map from one of the Information booths in the area which sets out a walking trail around the area.
A nice neighbourhood to have lunch or afternoon "Koppi" in. Walk up the maindrag from the ... Metrostation. Do then go into the sidealleys if you want less tourists and more living quarte to SEE.

Visited a few Hanok village. Thought this was excellent. Korea Tourism office, near Angguk Station Exit 3, has a walking trail (you can still get lost as it is not very detailed) which will take you through all the good spots. This is a living Hanok vilalge. Some hills to climb. Average fitness is required, I think!

Great market to see. Many people speak English. Great mix of old and new. You can see traditional Korean dresses for sale mixed in right next door street food! Reminded me of a county fair in the United States!

There are tourist information assistants walking around to provide information and guide in this area. Perfect place for phototaking, the traditional homes are beautiful and there are private houses for korean traditional tea. Cafes and shops - excellent to hang out on a lazy afternoon. Very close to Insadong, which we walked to after visiting Bukchon.

Here you will see their old traditional Hanok Village. There are about 8 photo spots where you can snap beautiful pix with stunning backgrounds! Along the way, alot of cafe and waffles shops. Drop by for a tea :)
Quaint little neighbourhood. It's actually an old residential neighbourhood. There are also many small cafes around (try their patbingsu! shaved ice). Overall a nice place to visit
