there were lot of cafes and small places to shop, and you can get to the Bukchon Vallage (Korean traditional houses) they are very nice, and people are living in them. there were a lot of people rented the traditional outfit and walk around - cute & fun!

This place was quite nice and the old buildings were beautiful. However, I'm not sure if it's because I had high expectations or something, but that was about it. There wasn't too much. There weren't any houses open to the public to see (at least not where we went). It's also not that big.
In the middle of bustling modern Seoul, some people elect to live in traditional houses in traditional surroundings. Well worth a stroll (1-2 hours)
Take a map, it can get a little confising! Lots of old style buildings alongside the new. Take a hat and prepare to spend a few hrs on foot :)

Wonderful place.If you go during the week it should be quiet and peaceful. I thought it would only be a few streets but actually the area is fairly big with lots and lots of hank houses to take pictures of.The view from higher ground are also excellent.

Not quiet what I expected. The houses looked nice but that's about it really. Also didn't help that it can get very crowded being a tourist destination, making the whole experience a bit underwhelming. If you're close to the area then go for it but I wouldn't go out of my way for this one.

This was a fantastic neighborhood to simply get yourself lost and wander up and down the streets. In my opinion, it's the best way to travel.  Please be mindful of your voice level to respect the people who live in this neighborhood. Most of the people who were visiting this area were loud and obnoxious with their selfie sticks. There are signs everywhere reminding all who are visiting the to keep their voices at a minimum.  Just outside this residential area are little streets with shops, art galleries, restaurants and cafes. This is also a great place to explore.
very excited to find out about the traditional village near Gyeongbokgung. It's like time capsule going back to Joseun dynasty. Enjoy strolling at the village, feel peaceful here.

Nice place to visit. Be prepared to spend a few hours there. A lot of walking is needed as you need to walk up a sloppy road leading to the village. On the way the road is lined with trees and beautiful scenery below and from afar. A lot of art work can be seen everywhere. The houses are mostly traditional Korean houses though some are renovated and look new. There are residents living in those houses , thus it is advisible not to talk too loud or disturb them. Good place to take photos. Not many seats are available for you to sit and rest but there are cafes around for you to relax and drink. You can even rent the traditional Korean dress ( hanbok ) for photo taking.
Picturesque little streets filled with restaurants, tea houses a a few shops. Nothing special apart from a nice stroll. Not far away from the city centre.

Great area to wander around. Go off the main roads and get yourself lost a little, you'll easily find your way back. Plenty of cafés and places to eat. It's very popular, so be prepared for plenty of company, particularly at weekends. Lots of couples in traditional hanbok dress add to the atmosphere and the views of the old hanok houses against the background of high rise modern Seoul are fabulous. Walking out of Bukchon, you're only a stones throw from Insa-dong.

The Hanok Village in Bukchon is Korean traditional houses. It is famous and one of must go to visit attractions in Korea. The Hanok Village is on the top of the mountain, so you need to walk a long and steap road. Although you will feel tired, it is worth when you arrived at the Hanok Village. A lot of tourists dressed Korean traditional clothes – Hanbok, they took pictures in this beautiful places like a Korean. I am regret that I did not rent hanbok to try. It will a good experience. Also, I saw a foreign TV show came to there. They introduced the Hanok Village and interviewed the local resident to introduce the history of the village. Walking along this road, you found the air is fresh and the hanok is total different from each other. Each house have their feature and culture. I really recommend this place to take a visit in Seoul. However, our voice should as low as possible. We should not disturb the local residents.

Really nice to walk through these picturesque alleys with its nice little homes. But it can be quite busy there with tourists taking selfies everywhere and not even respecting the property of the people living there.

Had a little walk around here during the day. Very lovely but quiet busy. You can use the hop on hop off bus to get here which we did. There is also a lovely park surrounding which was nice to walk through. Good examples of olden style dwellings - there were written information plaques but I do not recall English - though I may be incorrect.
Be prepared to walk up and downhill when you tour around this area.It is quiet and you can have a glimpse of the traditional Korean house.

What I found interesting is, this village is located in the city, integrated with other element of the city. It is surprising when you walk in the pavement with a busy traffic and the next turn you take bring you to the traditional taste of Korean home.  I learned that this area is visited by tourist massively, but I was there late afternoon so I only encounter 2-3 people, which is amazing. This is basically a residential area, so you should respect them and keep your voice low.
Traveller MUST visit this village. Very unique and traditional place of Seoul. I love every minute in this place, feel very tranquility and calming
Very beautiful area that's full of tourists. Nice area with great views. Be prepared for the tourist crowds

Quaint and picturesque traditional village. Plenty of people rent the traditional costumes and walk around taking photos. Rather crowded but fun to wander around. There are several museums around, apparently, offering insights into the cultural background. Do remember that this is still a residential area, so they request tourists to keep their voices down.
If you want to see how korean traditional houses & village looks like, you visit here bukchon Hanok village. There are over 900 houses packed.
It's like going back to the past with all the older yet very well maintained homes of Korea. great street to visit!

This cluster of traditional Korean houses is located between the Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung palaces. Bukchon literally means 'northern village". Some of these residence blocks are centuries-old. The Bukchon Traditional Culture Centre located in this area plans and operates a variety of cultural programs. A walk through Bukchon Hanok essentially means a walk through meandering alleys. Thoroughly enjoyable and pretty!

We visited the village early morning as a stop gap whilst waiting to start our Secret Garden Tour at Changdeokgung Palace.  So glad we decided to stop by as it's such a gem. Not at all what we were expecting, but so much better, a great mix of old and new. Great little shops and cafes, had some nice restaurants too. Just a shame we didn't have more time.....  Would definitely visit again, would just make sure we made more time. Lovely way to spend a couple of hours.
We had a lovely couple of hours walking round all the hidden little streets.Some good shops and very reasonable priced.

I've heard so much positive about this place but when i arrived there it wasnt much. Its basically just a hill with traditional buildings. It's worth taking a visit when doing Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung Palace since its between those two, but do not plan to spend much time here.

Take the time to visit the "old Seoul." High atop hills, with a great view of the city, you can wander up and town narrow streets, looking at old home and buildings of the ancient architecture. A MUST SEE!

We asked directions at the tourist information booth and was given a map of Bukchon where he highlighted the best places to go.  On arrival at the village there was a coach tour getting off so it can get busy as it is a popular tourist site. There are many signs telling people to keep the noise down as this is a residential area. However this did not stop people talking loudly or posing for photos on the doorway of someone's house.  The village mixes the old traditional houses with some newer style. I felt like I was intruding into their neighbourhood and they must get pretty tired of the tourists gawping in and taking photos of their houses. The only people that seem to benefit are the shops selling gifts and the cafes and restaurants.

The area of Seoul is lovely - and unique. Most of Seoul is in the process off renovation and Bukchon still has some of the old feel to it. Jump into the alleys for proper food. If someone is beckoning you into a hole in the wall sort of restaurant, go in. You will be in the right place. The pictures on the wall will assist you in choosing something to eat and you will love it. Best food anywhere
By sort of old I meant a little more than 100 years old. That in the scheme of things not really old but still a nice hour of walking and some shops

We LOVED it! If you do not see anything else in Seoul this is definitely something to do. The feeling, the little shops, the beautiful streets... so sweet in the middle of the city. Do this. Short but sweet.
If you visit korea you cant miss this place i stay 2 night here and to me is not enough i wish i have more time
I really liked the atmosphere of the "village", it's quite calm compared to downtown Seoul. Really pretty.
Very easy to do a little walk about here, streets connect to lots of little restaurants and then you are close to the Palace to so that after.

Great place to visit to see the traditional building styles and methods of yesterday. Its a relatively small spot so it won't take long to see a lot. Keep in mind this is a residential neighborhood and apparently the residents are not huge fans of the crowds. You'll see a lot of people here taking pictures.

You can choose to go with a tour or like me - walking free and easy!  It is a great area full of hanoks (traditional korean houses), boutique shops and cafe. I was planning to spend half a day but turned out enjoyed for a good 5-6 hours walk with breaks in between. It was great to take a break with some ice tea and Korean snacks in a hanoks cafe.  For photography lovers, you may take more than half a day like me. It was great walking round to take photos along small alleys, definitely a great trip! I enjoyed getting lost in the village although I had a map with me.  For those who love to stay in old houses, there are lots of guest houses too  For the cafe lover, absolutely a place to go with traditional atmosphere with some Korean tea and snacks.  For those who go with tours, please lower your voice because this is still a residential area with residents. Unfortunately many tourists were still making lots of noises - even the tour guides were loud, not exactly respecting the residents.  Tips: Please visit early and plan for your route if you want to avoid the crowds, I managed to avoid it.  Also, you may want to bring/ purchase electronic fan if you travel during Summer like me.
Many traditional house (hanok) in there. We can also try street food in some stores. Little bit crowded but not a problem

2 years ago, I tried to come here from Samcheongdong and omg it was so steep. This time I tried from Insadong/Anguk stn and it was so easy. Get out from exit2, wait for the green bus no.2 at the stop across the street from Starbucks and get off at 북촌한옥마을.돈미약국 (Bukchon Hanok Village/Donmi pharmacy) to save 10 mins of walking up the hill. From the stop, cross the street and just follow the crowd. From the photospot no. 4(if I remembered correctly) which is the observation point, you can walk down to Samcheongdong using steep staircase or the not too steep/far walkway. After that you can roam around the street. if you turn right you will shortly arrive at Kyeongbok Palace. If it's too much of a walk, after you reach the ground, just cross the street and take the bus to the palace or the main road for subway stn.

If you are interested in getting "lost" in a folk area in Seoul, Bukchon Hanok village is a good chance to do it. You can see how a Korean village did look like, how the ceilings are/were made, the entrance doors of the houses and so on. I would recommend to visit the "sample" of old house shown in the Bukchon Traditional Culture Center.

I highly recommend this neighborhood. This is the only neighborhood in Seoul where you can see traditional Korean houses. Some of the traditional houses have been turned into art galleries, coffee shops and museums where you can experience traditional Korean culture (tea ceremony, arts and crafts, etc.)

Bukchon Hanok village is a must see while in Seoul. Easy to get to and fascinating to walk around. I wouldn't spend a lot of time here but it is worth seeking out - just do it quietly, the locals who live there don't appreciate noisy tourists!

Go here if you're interested in their cultural houses. There's a lot of walking and there are steep areas that at some point, my parents would just wait for us instead of walk all the way up the kinda steep walkway. It was a nice walk along the houses. It can also be considered a fun mini hike if you're up for that kind of stuff. The view of the sunset and mountain is beautiful from here.

I enjoyed walking and taking photos ans also bought local traditional cloths for around 20 000 for myself and the same for my wife. Children version cost 15 000. Also enjoyed fried rice with hit sauce, and rice drink!

If you like taking picture, or you interested in Korean traditional houses, you won't disappointed. You can see a different "Seoul" from here, The village is quite big, you can walk up and down hill, to take a pictures. one thing I was not impress, is too many tourists, can not take a good photo with no people.

I visited this area once in the summer and again during Chuseok in the autumn with family. It is a lovely and interesting neighbourhood to walk around.  Although it is easy to get to, you must keep in mind that it is all uphill. This can be difficult for anyone with a bad knee or anyone pushing a baby stroller.  It's also a short activity (perhaps an hour max of looking around) so it would be worth going to the palace nearby to make a nice day of it all. There are many cafes and shops nearby for refreshments too.

When you come to Seoul, Buchon Village is the little place that really traditional and if you love korean drama, this place is really like location for Korean Drama. But please do not make a noisy since this village still home for korean citizen.

A glimpse into village life. Would have liked to have a look into more homes beyond the gates. They look quite spacious. Interesting exploring the alleys and shops. Good craft beer cafe to finish the visit.

This is a very relaxing attraction where you can walk streets to see old traditional Korean houses. They were very well maintained. As you walk up the hill, the Seoul skyline begins to emerge in the background. This is a great photo spot!  There were two helpful "information" givers, who provided maps of the area and spoke great English! The whole attraction took us about an hour. Signs throughout remind visitors that Bukchon is a residential area, so keep your voices quiet.  Check this out if you like beautiful architecture and scenery. Probably not the #1 Seoul attraction, but definitely a cute spot to visit!

This is definitely worth to visit. I don't expect these traditional Korean buildings are preserved so well. When walking along all the lanes of this area, I felt history is around me. Also, there are few shops to on those beautiful traditional clothing and took beautiful shot with the background of old Korean building. So happy! Of course, suggest to go there during weekday because it is a very popular sport for tourist.
Nothing special at the place except for korea traditional houses. Namsamgol hanok village still the best i visited at seoul.

Lovely walk around this area. Cool buildings, nice doors. Cute shops some galleries, a private observatory which we didn't go to. Some nice photo opportunities. Busy with other people taking selfies and generally getting in the way. Nice place, I think the people who live there must get really annoyed with tourists, from the signs on the walls and doors telling others to be quite etc.
This place is so cute! Loved every corner! Walk in the middle of residential area and next there are more streets full of shops and small restaurants. Very nice.
Is near Sophia guesthouse I look around nice village town. A lot shops to look around. Night time is the best to shop around.
Again another place to get that Hanbok on! There's one alleyway that has great houses. resto not so good but tourist info people always ready to assist!

The traditional houses in Bukchon are beautiful and you would encounter small shops selling trinkets and restaurants offering local delicacies. However, take note that you would do a lot of uphill and downhill walks around here which may not be recommended for old people and with health issues. P.S. Bring a bottle of water. Trust me, you'll get tired from all of that walking.

After visiting the Changdeokgung palace (please refer to my earlier review of this place as well) as part of our full day city tour, which is just a short drive away from here, our guide brought us here for a short walkabout to immerse in another different aspects of the Korean culture and lifestyle.  It was about 10.45am when we arrived and the weather warm and sunny. There is a small road with shophouses located on both sides of it (i.e. cafes, restaurants, retail and souvenir shops etc), and according to our guide, this place is very famous among the Japanese tourists, possibly because they are the ones who help to spur "tourism" activity here and true enough, in our walk around here, we saw many groups of Japanese tourists.  As we walked deeper into the small road and into the lane where houses are located (of which some have been converted to retail and business operations). The walk was uphill on stone and rocky pathways. The houses here were very nice and lovely that depicted their long past history (of course some have been reconstructed or rebuilt and one do need to pay to admit).  Most of the houses were well maintained and one could easily experience the Korean's enriching culture and history.  As we walked higher (actually the walking trail was a full circle walk uphill and downhill and back to where we started), we saw more houses, unique shop houses, hostels and they were very beautifully decorated with flowers. When we reached the highest point, we did have a good bird eye's view on the vicinity and could even see the palaces from here, besides the mountains!  It's a worthwhile visit here definitely as one could immerse in the unique ambience of the lovely Hanok Village of the past in present time. Although the walk can be challenging for some (at certain section, it was quite steep), just take your own sweet time and pace and you will still be able to complete the walk and see lovely things. If my 80-year old mum can do so, everyone can too!  However, do take note of the following to make your walking trail fun and enjoyable:  Do wear pair of comfortable/short shoes here and there will be lots of walking (especially walking uphill); Bring along drinking water, umbrella and hats during summer time; and Do keep the volume of talking low as there are still many residents staying here to avoid disturbing them.  Highly recommended.

We signed up with Seoul Tourism Board free walking tour and we were assigned a English speaking guide Jennifer. She was very detailed and showed us the Village and even corners where no tourists knew. It was refreshing to find such as quaint place in the heart of Seoul city. I highly recommend you visit this place. Just a word of advice: Please be mindful that there are local residents living in midst of this village so please be considerate to the surrounding and the level of noise that you might be creating.

This are has lovely old traditional houses and gives you a feel for what the city must have been like in the past. There are lots of nice little shops and galleries around the little streets. Many of the old houses can be visited for a small fee.

We had read about this location and didn't fully comprehend what it would be like. Be sure to pick up a map at the visitors center and watch the film. Then just wander around. It becomes quite obvious that this is a special place.

So stumble out of the subway and even if you get a bit lost like us you will eventually stumble across the village. People actually live in this village so please respect their privacy when trouncing around. Be mindful of your voice.  There are plenty of options to look beyond the gated doors of traditional homes.  Classic is seeing a lot of Asian you study going for Cosplay, wearing traditional costumes in the crazy heat.  We came along in Autumn and it was still very warm. Can't imagine how uncomfortable it will be in mid summer  Well worth the visit. Once back on the main drag grab yourself a traditional tea in any of the great tea rooms

The area is very cool. Go to the main information centre first, they will give you a map with suggested routes. It is best to follow the routes as determining the best route yourself could get tricky.
We walked through the narrow streets enjoying the pretty houses which were well looked after. The small shops and people gazing was in abundance. Definitely worth a visit.

It was very close to the Gyeongbokgung palace and I'm glad that i went there. You need to walk uphill to get there, but you will get a really nice view over the city. I really like the pictures i took there. But you should keep in mind that people still live in these houses. One of the houses is open for visitors and they also sell some souvenirs. There are also many souvenir shops or food stores in this area.
This was one of my favorite spots in Seoul. Traditional houses, good restaurants and great shopping.
The narrow streets with the small wooden houses are beautiful and good for pictures. It is really worth the walk from Insadong shopping street. You should love it if you love art.

A nice short walk from the Palace and well worth going to for the good array of cafe's. When you decide to view the old style houses you will have a reasonable hole up the hill so not suitable for seniors on a wet day

In Bukchon you can get a very close idea how were the wealthy neighborhoods in Seoul 200, 300 years ago. Remember this is the middle of Seoul and people live in these houses... It is a nice stroll and some times uphill, so use comfortable shoes.
It is nice to walk around the area to see the more traditional architecture, where people are still living there.
After a long and tired walk u will arrive at this place, Its nice place to take a photo here with some unique traditional village
A lovely suburb with cute traditional houses and a view of the modern city down below - a unique experience.

Take a road map provided as you can find them along the street and just follow the steps given and you find yourself visiting these beautiful traditional houses without spending money on tour guides to bring you.

Best thing to do is visit the tourist office first for a detailed map of Bukchon including a walk visiting all the highlights. Some parts are really pretty with traditional houses, some parts are not too interesting. Cobble stones, art, greens, little shops, restaurants. You're asked to walk around respecting the residents.

The walk from the palace leads u to many nice quaint cafes & interesting little stalls/flea markets, after the right turn, all along the way. Was so distracted n mesmerized by everything. Direction sign as to where the villAge begin is unclear as the building along it looks similar but just relax, get lost, get soak in.. it's worth the walk. The village is at the end of the road. The village itself is another great experience 👍🏻 will definitely return

It's not easy to locate the traditional Korean houses but no worries there are walking tourists information which let you know how to go there. Bukchon area is fun to visit...don't miss Bing-Bing shaved ice...the best one I ever tasted during the visit to Seoul. Also please make sure not to make a lot of noises during walking surrounding the houses - there are notices everywhere.....I just couldn't imagine myself living in this area with nonstop curious tourists walking around especially if the tourists could not read the notice due to language barrier.

The surrounding area is very different with the modern city of Seoul, it is closed to UNESCO - Changdeokgung Palace Complex. You can feel traditional Hanok and palace is so peaceful. You don't find any luxury and brilliant building, but you can find how ancient Korea dynasty lifestyle, worth to go.
Street of traditional Korean residential houses left in the North of Seoul City. Not exactly old but still shows old Korean residential houses live in.

The village houses are owned and stayed by actual modern day Koreans so all the tourist just walk along the roads to take picture of the wooden doors and stone walls ... It is a hilly area and your photos almost cannot be exclusive as there are many others taking pictures as well

This is a cute area for good pictures especially up on top of the hill looking down. Pretty small area, but nice to look around and take a visit to the small shop that looks like an old fashion house.
It's a village of preserved old traditional Korean houses. You can go around but it will get boring because they look all the same but its good to have some photo opp in one of the houses!

We lovee this place, the houses, the tea houses, the mountain view at the end of the road was simply amazing. There's not much good restaurant nearby, note that we don't prefer eating at tourism areas. We were there from the morning and starved by the afro, couldn't find proper good korean meals and managed to walked down to angguk and went inside the crowded alley and found a great korean diner.

It's nice walking around here as you see a more historical side to the city. Note that some of the streets are actually residential so you can't make too much noise. The closest station is Anguk and we combined this with a tour to the palace.
Is a short walk of my day. But I have a wonderful meal during lunch. Never felt regret to dropby this place. Many of them can speak a little bit of english and chinese, so i wont felt lost there.

If I'm not mistaken, my friends and I walked around in circles for about an hour just trying to find the exact area where most people go to take pictures of. Navigation is not easy as well, even with maps provided. Many steep pathways and stairs to climb, but overall, all of us enjoyed our time here.  We got to experience the cultural village, take beautiful photos, as well as mingling with a local roadside vendor which sold idol products. However, take note that this place is a residential area and lower down your volume at all times! Don't be inconsiderate to others.

Visited in July16. Will require lot of walking to cover entire village. Pick up a map from info booth right at start of village that wil show the best route you can cover. You can see Traditional homes here and they look beautiful.

Bukchon, literally mean North Village. It is basically surrounded by Gyeongbokgung Palace. Changdeokgung Palace and Jongmyo, and not far from Insa-dong too. Group them together for a day visit of Korean traditional houses and palaces is truly memorable for any history lover!

While a stroll through Bukchon Village may feel like a trip through the ages, the neighborhood is not frozen in time. Some of the hanoks are still private homes, but others have been converted into tea houses, coffee shops, cafés, art galleries, inns and museums.  Although it seems like its nothing much but I think I spent like 2 hours walking around the neighborhood. Just admiring the beautiful houses and the serenity it seems to bring being around there.

Bukchon is a residential area and I had a good walk here with my friend. The traditional Korean houses here are so beautiful and you can take loads and loads of pictures around here. There are a lot of tourists around. You can get a map for the route to walk around at the tourist centre near to Anguk station exit no. 2. Definitely buy something cold to eat or drink if you come here in Summer!

This was such an interesting experience. It's a long walk, going up and down the hills but it's quite worth it. The houses are very nice. Each house is different from each other but somehow tied up together and become architectural masterpiece. And it's amazing to see how the Koreans embrace their culture by still living in these houses. Highly recommended.
You might try to wear the Hanbok there and take a photo in their village it has some craft workshop. Near Insadong if you want to stop by it while in Insadong

Nice walk to just see how these old houses have been preserved and continue to used as residences. Walked through in the afternoon although I believed it would probably be more interesting with little cafes opened later in the evening and better sunset views...
Very interesting place. But be mindful. It is a residential area. So, keep you voice as low as possible and try not to anything not belonging to you.

Walk in the narrow street to have a sense of how traditional Korean houses looked like, however its a residential area so its changing and some irrelevant buildings are also there. Good for taking some nice shots

We were really looking forward to exploring this area but when we got there it was so crowded and quite lacking in atmosphere. We stopped for a snack and a drink at a cafe and the prices were a total rip off.

A nice experience. Lovely to see the local houses and how koreans lived traditionally. It's very quiet. You walk up and down hills and stairs. Each house is different from the next and yet somehow all tie together. There is even a craft studio where you can make your own crafts. You don't need much time here- it's a quick stopover.

Even though some are of Bukchon is becoming too much commercialized like Insadong, many parts of Bukchon remains traditional. I would recommend visiting this place to anyone who travels Seoul. Stop by at Bukchonok restaurant which I recommended in my other review.

It's actually Korean traditional houses and there are really people living in it, so you cannot make loud noise. Quite a lot of people during that time. You will need to have a strong leg muscle to walk around Bukchon Hanok Village.

It is very special experience to live in a traditional Korea house. It is simple furniture and decoration. If you have come with an elderly, the Korea bed is too low for an elderly. Rather than this, everything is ok.
Very nice part of town if you want to connect with original culture. Houses are you spectacular and there are many old shops.

After visiting Changdeokgung Palace we take a walk to Bukchon Hanok Village. Its a nice place to discover the traditional Korean houses. You can see some korean workshop (bukchon chogo, bukchon jeotdae, ...).
It's a nice contrast between the old village and traditional houses, with the modern city in the backdrop. However, too crowded and noisy when i intended for a relaxing stroll! !!

Personally I don't really get the point. You can't see inside any of the houses. Crowded with tourists. The only marginally interesting part was the view from the overlook point. It free so if you are nearby, but would not go out of my way to see it.

Traditional rows of houses. While there are many notice and reminders hanging around indicating to keep noise level low due to they are people actually staying there, most tourists did not heed the advice. I think it will be a nuisance for me if I am staying there. Haha. By the way, we walked to here from Samcheongdong (would only suggest this if you have ample of time)

It is a very quirky place to be, lined both with modern shops and renovated traditional-style houses. It is essential to step into the alleyway offshoots and spend some time at an interesting cafe. Don't arrive until at least after 10 or 11am or else everything will be closed. Come in the afternoon for Bukchon at it's most lively and bustling.

A good place to take photo when you are here, It's best you get a map from tourist counter and walk not only Bukchon but some other places too. This place is residential area, so basically can't make too much noise a lot of keep quiet sign around the place.

Beautifully preserved old houses that are still being lived in. Some of the owners have used the location of their homes to offer tourists stunning views of the Seoul skyline (they charge and entrance fee). Worth walking through these several streets. On the weekend you can see young Koreans dressed in traditional customs walking around.

The Bukchon Hanok Village is an interesting neighborhood for wandering. The shops and restaurants here are smaller in size, but very nice and the quality of food and products is quite good. As one might expect in a older village, the streets are winding and full of hills, up and down. If you are looking for a great workout, this is your place! If you have trouble getting around, this is NOT your place. If it is raining or crazy hot it would be better to do this another day. You will need good walking shoes and an umbrella - not for rain, but for shade! If you are visiting during the summer heat, this neighborhood would be best visited early or late in the day.

It is a beautiful place to walk around and get a feel for the traditional houses and see with what care people take care of it and live in history. For me it was a good display that modern and old can live side by side without being out of balance. A minus can be that you have steep climbs. I went there with no expectations and what I saw was simply put beautiful.
Village with traditional Korean houses. Interestingly, it is in the heart of Seoul's most expensive district.

i must say this is one of best attraction in Seoul. The alleys are filled with traditional Korean houses that was so amazing to see. Unfortunately, you can't see inside the house because it is personal residences.

Went here with my family and I must say this village is one of the best area to visit in Seoul. You will see lots of houses which is transformed into shops and next to it there will be an alley leading to a traditional style house which people still live in it. Very nice and very interesting place to go for a walk.

as people still lives in this area, we tried to keep quiet during our visit here. but the most loud one is either chinese tourist or local people themselves -_- nevertheless bukchon is amazing. even the house is still preverse in traditional style, their doors, gate, ornament etc is very interesting. its kind of hard to get photo (alone) because of sea of tourists, even in weekdays also close to insadong, just across the street

This neighborhood of streets and alleys are filled with hanoks, traditional-Korean houses, that either serve as personal residences, guesthouses for people to stay in, or shops. I found the Bukchon Cultural Center one of the days and was able to make one of the art projects they had with a third-generation artisan. She was so skilled and quick that I was thankful for her. The urban explorer loved this, going down alleys to dead ends, turning around and having to go another way, happening upon a mural here, a cool coffee shop there, a lovely restaurant that served a bibimbap dish that was tasty, and so on...I'd go back to Seoul to explore this area more!

Loved the whole Bukchon area as it had several quirky cafes and shops mixed with traditional handicrafts, traditional houses (Hanok) and was such a mix mash of sights and sounds. There were many dressed up in the hanbok (Korean costume) to take photos also. Do climb (yes the slopes can get pretty steep here) to the vantage points for awesome views of the Seoul tower and mountains.

Bukchon, meaning North Village (north of the Han river) is a collection of traditional hanoks, houses of Koreans in the past. They are wonderfully preserved and people still do stay in them. As it is a residential area, do keep noise to a minimum, and let yourself get transported into the past. Try to find the eight photo spots - do not miss number 6.

There will be a lot of walking but you don't think about it when you admire the traditional Korean houses. There is a tourist info where you can get a free map with suggested routes. There are also small shops, cafes and restaurants if you feel like a taking a break or grabbing a coffee or smoothie to go.

Buckchon is a traditional Korean village made up of clusters of "hanoks" or traditional Korean homes. Stroll along the alleys and feel like you are back in time ( more than 500 years ago). The architecture- the old roofs, doors, and windows, and the beautiful courtyards are unique to this village.

I liked taking photos but that's about it. Maybe I just wasn't able to explore it properly? We followed the arrows though. Go here before or after Samcheongdong! If you're coming from Samcheongdong, look for the stairs going up to Bukchon.
Beautiful houses and quaint streets with great views of Seoul. Quite steep streets so can be tiring in a hot day . In the streets below there are high level shops and galleries, very affluent area.

This ancient city is a must do in seoul, it still has the essence of the ancient town with a touch of modern, here you will find a lot of wooden houses mix with concrete, along the town you will get free wifi in some places.  They have several places where you can rent the typical dress of Korea to take pictures for 10000 won.  Try to visit the observatory at the tea museum.
people actually lives here and it gets quite annoying when there are a lot of people. a great place to take pictures

Well worth an early start. We arrived at 10am on a Monday and it was already swarming with other tourists. Their noise paired with sea of selfie sticks and photo shoots impacted greatly on what would otherwise be a sceinic and pleasant stroll.

You walk up the hilly streets among the hanoks. Then you turn around and see the view of the modern city in between the traditional hanok walls. On the way down you get a glimpse of Gyeongbokgung Palace. This is why you travel 5000+ miles to Seoul.
I enjoyed shopping in this trendy district. The food and handmade shops are excellent. There are a lot of good finds and plenty of places to explore!

My fiancée and I spent about an hour or so walking through the streets in the Bukchon area. There are lots of old / traditional Korean houses there and next to no car traffic (only residents driving to and from their homes I suspect).  Unless you are here early in the morning there will however be lots and lots of other tourists in the area - so many that I sort of feel bad for the people who live here. You will find signs everywhere reading "Please be quiet" or "Please don't stand on the stairs".  You'll also find some galleries selling art (figurines, paintings) and shops selling perfume, soaps, candles etc. in this area.  There are a couple of nice palaces in walking distance from this old town as well, hence visiting this area is well worth the trip.

Quiet and charming, this is such a beautiful cultural village with wonderful clean streets and nice shops along the way. I definitely recommend here as to myeongdong and since it is opposite of Anguk and Invading and smack in between the two top palace in Seoul, this makes a wonderful stop
I loved the old style houses and numerous people wearing Hanbok. If visiting in summer, try to come in the evening instead of during the day as it is too hot.

People see the modern South Korea from various KDramas. Thus, they tend to know more of the present South Korea. This place actually enable people to have a glimpse of the past and get a grasp on how much had change since then. This is a good walking experience.  Tip: not for those who have difficulty in climbing various roads or places.

The village is a pretty sight. It's accessible from the subway/metro Line 3 station Anguk. You only need around 30 minutes to go around the village. And one has to observe silence and respect the neighbourhood (it is a private village). There's a nice cafe, Dooroo, by the entrance to the village. And, there is a nice little souvenir shop along the road to the station (see photo). July by the way, is monsoon season in Korea so be prepared for rain.
A good place for those who like the korean traditional houses. Just prepare your self for long walking with road hill elevated. This place is a picturesque.

Beautiful architecture and great winding streets. I visited Bukchon on a Saturday afternoon in April and it was very busy, but it was beautiful. There are a lot of hills to walk so wear comfortable shoes. This is a great location to see the traditional korean houses.

The village is at a convenient location in the city which makes transportation quite easy. Since Korea's taxis are cheap, we decided to take it to Bukchon Village.  At the village, there's some souvenir shops and small cafes for you to sit and relax. There are also some sites where you can walk into the traditional homes but with a small fee. The walk around the village for tourists is not that long. In fact, I would estimate about a 15 -20 minute walk in total. We came during the evening which was a bit crowded but it was tolerable.  The views from uphill of the village is great. There were many tourists taking the views as well which shows the image of all the traditional homes.

Love the stroll recommended online (you can easily find plenty of info on bukchon village trail). I took about half a day to visit all 8 photo points on map. Don't worry about being lost - there are roving guides at various spots to assist. Do spend some time to soak in the atmosphere. Bring along water, a brolly and hat as summer can be scorching. Stop at various cafes and shops to rest and relax. This place is a must visit for first-timers to Seoul!

Bukchon is my favorite neighborhood. It's my favorite because of the preservation of historic homes and building styles typical throughout Seoul before the redevelopment. In one particular area, there are many of these homes that are living artist studios where you can visit (often for a $1 cost), and for an additional cost you can make art or a craft with them. We have done a few of these, and have done with just adults and with kids, and everyone not only had a great time, but also made a functional piece of art for use or display. Our party made painted necklaces for $10, painted hair decoration for $10, did a woodblock print ($3), and learned how to tie buttons from cord (free). If you have time, we highly suggest a visit to a studio or art center, there are mostly just drop in, so you can find one that interests you.  Another popular stop is a teahouse. There are many, and most walking tours pass by at least one. Teahouses usually involve a cup of tea and a sweet, but cost more than many travelers think it should, but the experience is worth it for many.  It is easy to enjoy a walking tour through the neighborhood, there are tours outlined in many different guidebooks or websites. We started at one corner down on the street that goes the palaces, and walked up and through the neighborhood, and then back down to the other side, and ended by the big palace and walking past the folk museum. Just make sure your walking tour gets you "up" enough where you can wander through the neighborhoods of hanok, the traditional homes. A picture of the roof lines is worth the visit.

Bukchon is situated on a sloping hill, like much of Seoul. So wear comfortable shoes and be prepared to walk work those calves! Beautiful houses, the only thing is its a little weird because people live there and I felt awkward taking pictures of their houses.
Good to have a quick stroll through but the Namsangol Hanok Village was far more enjoyable to visit in my opinion.

I went with friends in hanbok and it made for a wonderful photo opportunity! It was as if we had stepped back in time for a bit. Not the easiest place to find, because everywhere we turned said 'bukchon-gil' but after asking some locals we found our way to the main street that you always see in photos. Definitely worth a trip to if in seoul.

Can't believe I have missed this on previous trips to Seoul. Definitely very nice to walk around the village where nobles used to stay. Many cafes and small shops selling fashionable items as well! We enjoyed a great afternoon here. If too warm, would suggest to skip as a lot of walking and up hills.
What a sensational place to visit best in Seoul. Old historical area of seoul. Not far from metro station. 6 stops Seoul station line 3. Fine local food in area.
When u have done too much shopping, it would be nice to walk around here. Quiet Street and I am having some traditional Korean tea here.
you can also see Insadong since it is a short 5-10 minute walk from there. Also, it is best to come by subway.

Give yourself a day to enjoy the many art galleries, shops, great eating and beautiful old village of Bukchon. The architecture is a stunning mix of old and new. A beautiful heritage area worth the protection it has been afforded. Heaps of tourists there so don't be surprised by the request from residents to not step in their doorsteps and for silence when you're looking around.

we really enjoyed spending a few hours strolling around the streets of Bukchon, admiring the old houses and visiting the shops and galleries in the area. There are excellent free english maps available from stands near the train station, which highlight the sights in the area. definitely a must do on a trip to seoul.

Bukchon is the area of transitional Korean houses. There is not much going on but certainly worth visiting just because you are in Korea. Some houses charges entrance fees for touring the house and asking questions. Some offer traditional crafts for a fee between 10,000-20,000 won. Is fun to try some of the crafts. They might look easy but you will be surprised it can be so tedious!  My niece dropped her iPhone and the screen cracked. So be careful with your phones when you are there because there so many big and small stones everywhere on the floor. Whichever angle at which you dropped your phone, chances are the screen will crack. 😭

This is an old part of Korea with the buildings preserved so it looks very nice. Yet it seems to be a tiny street and there is very little things which are uniform. hence it seems part of the charm as it is not entirely fake. A lot of tea houses etc and somewhat manicured look. A lot of museums around the area as well.

It was like walking back in history. Get here early in the morning before everyone else and take the recommended trail starting from the main street. Enjoy the peace and tranquillity as you venture into the small alleys. You wonder what lies behind the walls of these houses and what was life like in the good old days. Some of these houses have been turned into galleries but will only open later when the crowds arrive. Quiet signs are everywhere and you can understand why as this is truly a popular spot.

Bukchon is the historically preserved neighborhood of Seoul. Most of the true old style houses are located within a quite residential neighborhood. Nice to grab a map and stroll around. There are some nice photo ops, although most of the actual houses are not open to the public. I found some streets to be quite lovely and peaceful; some others I hit right as tour buses were unloading and that was not so great. They have people stationed on some of the corners asking tourists to be quiet, since it is a residential neighborhood, but the tour groups I was near ignored that and were very loud and rude. So, try to time it to arrive early before those buses. Some of the surrounding streets have some nice cafes and coffee shops. You can also find a bunch of places offering workshops in various crafts like woodworking, kite making, and knot tying. If I had an extra day I would have made time to do one of those. Plan on doing a lot of walking, including up and down a lot of hills.

real traditional houses . get a map from the street tourist info. We went early before the tour group arrived. lots of walking. These are private residences and some tourists are inconsiderate and spoke loudly. There is one particular traditional house that is open to public for a fee. Worth the visit to see inside it. Lovely garden and rooms. Recommend that U visit this house.

We were on a quest to find an example of an old Korean village and found Bukchon Hanok Village. The architecture was a great example of the old style buildings or "hanok" which means traditional buildings. The site is hilly and the alleys are narrow. Worth the trip and walks.

Residential area in the style of old Korea, worth a visit to see the architecture, these are private residences so bare that in mind. Don't go too early or all the shops will be closed. Many tourists come in by bus and can make it crowded, easy to get to by metro, and then visit the nearby markets.
Definitely sign up for the free two hour walking tour and the. Stay after to enjoy lunch and a bit of shopping.
not easy to find, we had a long walk before we found it. its basically a row of unique korean houses (its a residential area) which is only found in korea. along the way, there are shops / eateries.
went to visit since it's near to Gyeongbokgung... it was a nice walk seeing rows of Hanok.. but do be prepared for lots of tourists.

It was a mild rainy day when we visited Bukchon Hanok Village, but it did not dampen the charm of the place. We started off with a late lunch as soon as we arrived, coming from a leisurely walk from Gyeongbokgung Palace. You could pair your sightseeing going to the Palace first, look around, watch the changing of guards, then proceed to Bukchon. Everything in Seoul is accesible by train or bus, anyway. But if you can take the 15-minute leisure walk to Bukchon, do so by all means. Good exercise and it helps increase your feel of the area. Then explore the place with the quaint houses and unique shops, eating really good ice cream and streetfood along the way, and just enjoying the quiet and lovely scenes around the village. We went up and down the streets, looking for interesting shops. I didn't realize that this could be an interesting activity for my young adult children. We even entered an art gallery with amazing paintings! The locals were very hospitable and though we were foreigners, we were made to feel so welcome! It truly warmed our hearts especially on a cold rainy day.
Seoul as it once was. This is a touristic place but still worth the effort of visiting. Book a guide to get an insight into the lives of the people who still live here.
There are a lot of Korean traditional house in that village. It is a mountain view and many tourist visit at place.

Quite a walk from the train station, but there are a lot of stores to see along the way, so you won't find it too tedious. Street is also lined up with coffee shops so you can take a break somewhere.  This is a great place to have a look at traditional Korean architecture, perfect spot for a couple of selfies and photos. Don't go here on a rainy day.

Perfect place to see old Seoul architecture. If you want you can even rent a traditional costume and walk around the village. It is fun, though don't forget to keep quiet since it is a residential area.
Great place to have a look at Korean architecture and boutique shops and cafes. A bit touristy but that's given cause it is a beautiful and well preserved neighbourhood.

In Seoul, a city dotted with high-rise apartments, its nice to see these old Hanok houses in the Bukchon Village. Its pleasant strolling through the narrow lanes between houses. There are many arts and crafts experience workshops (at a fee) in the area plus many cute shops while walking towards the village from direction of Anguk Station exit 6. The up and down hilly feel of the village gives you a nice view of the city and the N-Seoul Tower. There is a house in the area (cant recall exact name/street) still occupied by locals, where you can go up to the terrace for a fee (I think it was KRW 2,000/pp) and order a free item from the beverage/snacks menu while enjoying nice views of the area and giving your feet a rest as well!

For backpackers or any travellers who visit Seoul, I very recommended this place. If you love to take a walk by foot there are many to explore in this area. Take subway and stop in Anguk Station, at first you can cross or shopping for souvenirs in Insadong the just walk by foot about 5-10 minutes to Bukchon if you go directly but I bet you will stop couple of times because on your way to Bukchon you will see some interesting art galleries, museums, or old churces. From top of Bukchon, you can see the city view. You can take a rest and have some coffee or liquor and enjoy the fresh air. You can request free tour (check in internet, many volunteers offer free guide) or like me, I just like to explore by myself.

the strees of Bukchon give you glimspe of real Korean Culture. get a trail map from any of the shops in the street and walk through the trail. You can see the traditional Korean houses and on the way visit multiple Korean arts and painting centers. You can also take Korean painting lessons for 45 minutes. We were lucky that one of the residents was kind enough to welcome us to their house and show us around. The lay out of Korean Houses are very different and interesting.
Little 'fashionable' shops and where the trendy young people of seoul like to flock, but expensive by local standards. It has a nice feel and interesting little boutiques and cafes
Enjoyed walking around and seeing great history! There are a million photo opportunities and a shop and restaurant that caters to anyone.

The sightseeing area is not very big. If you don't have time to visit Jeonju,better to just go at Namsan Hanok Village rather than Bukchon. For you who want to get more traditional feel of hanok village Jeonju is definetly must visit place.
An uphill walk to get to the village. Kinda disappointed since there were no hanok rentals nearby but overall the place is a must see
It's a residential area so please keep quiet whilst visiting! Go grab a map at the tourist information desk and follow the route, went during dawn and got to see sunset among the way. Stunning!

I would suggest for anyone to get a tour (one of those free walking tours), and let them bring you around the village. I had an awesome 2 hours walking around, taking pictures, listening to the history and taking in the beautiful surrounding.  At the end of the tour, you will most definitely have a workout... as they have quite steep hills on certain streets, and the village in general is on a hilly area.
take a walk in bukchon a chill and relax stroll a fantastic walk and relax walk around the traditonal house in seoul after the walk grab a cuppa at cafe surrounding it
Strolled this quaint, chic historic neighborhood. Adored the shops and restaurants nestled in the historic buildings. A cool, hip vibe we enjoyed!

This is a must go place when visiting Seoul. At least you will get a chance to see beautiful old buidlings which are still very well maintained. Some of these buildings were converted to museum which open to tourist. If going there during summer, can be very sunny, do bring along sunglasses and umbrella. Need some uphill walking(proper road),make sure you put on comfortable shoes.

a nice look into the living standards in Seoul 500 years ago, however the renovation is demonstrated and does not contribute to the authentic spirit of this place. good preserved, sometimes overcowded

Alike the Kyoto of Japan, this is a residential area in the part of Seoul. There are many shops allowing tourists to try their traditional outfit.. The streets are also great for photography or just experience the ancient feel of Seoul.

After the Gyeongbokgung Palace you might as well visit Bukchon since it is just around the corner from it's northern gate exit. It's a very quaint place with keep quiet signs everywhere that unfortunately people generally ignore!

I had a good walk climbing minor slope of Bukchon Village. I loved to see old buildings that have kept in a very good conditions. There are many shops and restaurants along the street. It is amazing to know there are real people who still live in the area.

This area, although a tourist attraction is not for everyone. If you don't like climbing steep roads and taking in the atmosphere then this is not for you.  Essentially this is a long walk around reconstructed buildings with homestays, shops and various activities you can participate in.  Personally I think it's a nice walk and I enjoy the atmosphere.  I'm not sure why the bad reviews say it's hard to find. I had no problems finding the place and there are even information helpers in red clothing if you need assistance.  Remember if you go on Monday, all the activity shops are closed as well as some of the regular shops too.
Interesting place to see how Seoul people lived in the past. There are little cafes which have set up around the area which makes for interesting teas and dinner with friends
Nothing special to see, really. It was also very crowded with tour groups when we visited on a Monday.

Had visited this area before. A residential area with local people living here. Galleries, cafes, and local restaurants fill this area . Popular with tourists and high school students. Relatively quiet during weekdays compared to my last visit ( which was on the weekend). Pleasant stroll.

Pretty view but hard to spot. Stamina must be good enough to crawl up the steep slope. Look for information crew member before you moved on, signage was not visible showed on the walls. There is around 8 photo taking point. The famous E photo taking point is point 5 & 6. Try to go during weekdays and avoid public holiday. U won't be able to shoot nice scenery with many heads on. Haha! Sufficient sunblock is necessary. I had burnt even walking around at 11am.

We headed straight to the information centre for a map and asked for a recommended route. Lots of walking, lots of tourist, lots to see and photograph. The quaint shops along the way added to our enjoyment.

This place is amazing! So glad I decided to come here. After coming out from the subway, I go straight to the tourist center to get a map of this area. There was a suggested route which lead us to some buildings/ houses with history. The route was beautiful and is like in the old movie. Sometimes there will be people wearing hanbook passing by and made this feeling of unreal stronger. Along the way we get to visit nice shops, craft shops and nice cafe. I bumped into a cultural shop where after paying 10000 won, I get to wear hanbook for one hour. Such an amazing experience! The end of the route brought us to ChangDeGung. Really enjoy the whole experience and would come back here again.

Interesting stroll through this beautiful neighborhood of traditional Hanok Village. (Remember to be mindful of people living here and not be to loud.) There are information stops if you need directions or helpful tips, map of the area. English speaker available to assist.)

Walk around Bukchon is a fun escape from the modern landscape of downtown Seoul.  Make sure to pick up a map from the tourist center.  Start the walk towards the east so you wrap up the walk on the west side where there are shops and cafe on the big Main street.  Head over to Insadong right afterwards!
I just walked from my hotel to that place. It's lovely to walk around and see how people live ans shop in Bukchon. It wasn't sunny when I was there but it was really great!
I loved this place because it's very artistic and you could take a lot of pictures, you will also fall in love with those old buildings.

This is my second visit to Bukchon. The ancient houses still holds much charm to me. This time round we walked along the slope and found it to be another way to admire this area.  Some areas can get a bit crowded and hard to get a good nice shot. Quite a number of people dressed in traditional hanbok came to have photos taken.  Nice place to spend an hour or two for a slow walk and photo taking.

A lovely, quiet residential area that is nonetheless popular with many many tourists. Try to avoid weekends if you want an unobstructed view of Seoul tower from the top of the hill. It is really worth meandering around the streets between Bukchon and the palace as there are lots of funky little shops.
Some nice old wooden houses, but too touristy for me. All houses where fenced so not much to see for me. I would skip this if you have just one day.

Traditional houses in Bukchon village is very well maintained, maybe you can feel like you're in one of those Kdrama, lol. However, it is also a regular neighborhood area so we should also bear in mind to not disturb the house owner. One additional thing, I came here on Sunday so i don't know whether it is because of weekend its so packed there or in general bukchon is always crowded
Very interesting area, actually people really live there, some nice cafes and shops, but mostly artsy and panoramic views.

We took the recommendation from Lonely Planet to walk around the whole Bukchon area. It's beautiful! We went there about 10am and the streets are still quiet. We have a lot of opportunities to take photos and take a good look of the shops and restaurants. If you are fit enough you should go all the way up to the look out. It isn't that high but it's interesting to look over some traditional homes. I m sure it looks amazing during autumn.

traditional village and absorbed the modern life too. It was interesting walking and seeing locals. Passed plenty of shop place and few good restaurant. Just admire the local staff creativity totally worth visit
the house is beautiful, location really good, the environment is so comfortable, clean . I hope tourist more polite and not make too loud voice

I used to live here until last year and I chose this area because its charm of traditional feeling and small cute stores around the town. Well, the first demolition happened a decade ago in terms of construction, then the second demolition in its personality is on the way. I would say even for that short 3 years of my staying there, I've witnessed more than 50% of my favorite stores including small handmade shops, real cafés, local restaurants had been replaced by worldwide or local super power franchises. This was really frustrating and became a reason to leave the town... I still give 4 stars though because there are yet some survivors struggling against the push of landlords and also there are beautiful narrow hidden alleys all around the corners. Just avoid the main road and super chains if possible if you want the real town coming slowly back to us.

Very nice area, quaint and clean. A must to see, because it's the old area of Seoul. the houses are very well kept. Many shops around it. Lots of walking and uphill, bring comfortable walking shoes. We found a tea house with an amazing view inside Bukchon, but cannot remember the name of it.

Good opportunity to see authentic Korean architecture still in use. Best reason to visit the place is the cheap food from numerous stands. Also the only place where I found the famous rice wine (and paid only 1,500₩ for a large cup!)

A nice place to visit and see the traditional Korean buildings but the narrow streets gives "crowdy" feeling. When I visited there, I found that many tourists rented the traditional Korean dress, a HANBOK, and travelled around the place wearing it and took pictures. You may try to taste but I didn't as I wanted to spent more time enjoying the nature environment.

But of a nightmare to find on foot but worth a visit on a sunny day for great views! About a ten minute walk from Anguk station, lots of restaurants to eat in albeit EVERYTHING is in Korean with little English translation. This is a residential area so visitors need to be respectful of locals who are living in the Hanoks. A good way to spend an afternoon or evening. We found a vantage point and watched the sunset, can't beat that!
This place is really well known for both locals and tourists. It is best to put a Hanbok on (which can be rented at least for an hour) and take a picture here for an added feel.

Interesting place where we get to see well preserved traditional korean houses. Other than these, the nearby streets offered quaint charming shops selling clothes, accessories, arty stuff n food. Nice place to spend half a day.

We walked our way from the blue house exit of the Gyeongbukgong Palace to Bukchon.  I found the place interesting. There were lots of shops, restaurants and people too. We were looking for the traditional houses and did not mind the what looked novel. It took us a while to find the traditional houses. We traversed the road leading up a hill and found concrete stairs leading down only to find out that we're back to where we came from. We climbed up again and took our chance at a corner leading to the observatory until we came to a narrow street that was lined with the traditional houses and there were several streets like this. We just followed the path where our eyes took us and reached another street that led us to Insadong.  Over all you need the energy to do the walking that we did, but exploration was what we were there for. It was hard for us to take the bus because the routes were not written in English.  It was quite exhausting but worth it.
Lots of traditional houses as well as nice contemporary architecture around the area. It definitely deserves a visit.
Lovely area with original old houses and streets- how Seoul would have looked in the past such a contrast to the high rise of today . Lovely area to walk around and nice coffee shops and galleries.
This had more of a historical feel to it than the rest of Seoul. It's nice to walk around but no need to spend more than a couple of hours there.

bylanes of the old crisscross with the touristy and this up and down long walk deserves both aimless strolling and a useful local walking tour to catch what you may have missed in terms of vantage points and historical value.
The houses is almost old but still beautiful and so charming. Easy to go there and if you been there,please be quiet because all that houses still have people to live.

This is how many years back Seoul must have looked. Growth and prosperity asked for its price and whole quarters got levelled.  There is a nice round trip by foot with lots of cafe stops and interesting little handicraft places.  In itself, it looks magically removed from daily pulse of Seoul...

The Hanok houses are all very well preserved, pleasant walk with really steep slopes at some parts. I feel really bad for the people living there, even though there were lots of signs reminding people to keep their volume down, some groups are still very noisy. Please be considerate!

This is a place you could not miss if visiting Seoul. This is my second trip and we still enjoyed the nice walks and the views when you walked around it. After the hilltop views, you can walk down with all the coffeeand a bit of shopping areas around. It's a very nice place to visit and choose the time around noon to avoid those tours as they mostly visit in the morning. Worth going and can do lunch around that area as well.

I love historical building there, been there three times already. When you feel tired due to long walk, you can go to coffee shops as a lots are there. A quiet and good place for visiting in city town.

As part of the incentives as Korean Air transit passengers, we signed up a 5 hours day trip, provided free by the Incheon Airport. This is one of the highlight we went, and all I could say was it was indeed a very nice place to walk about, even we just have 1 hour to enjoy it (2 hours return bus trip from and to airport, plus another 2 hour visit to other destination) . It is a bit steep in some part of the trail, but overall it granted the view of Seoul and the historic houses. The nearby has many cafe and shopping alley, and though the alleyways were small, they limit access of big vehicles and so it was relatively safe at the same time.

Be prepared to walk, up some steep slopes and stairs. Since it's a residential area, unless you visit the tea house for example, you will not get a view of the quarters. The plus is seeing ladies wearing hanbok doing the tour, which is part of Korea tourism promotion.

This area is walkable from Isadong. You may wish to include this into the itinerary if dropping by Isadong. For direction wise, you may seek assistance from the tourist office. It is about 20-30 mins of walking. Once you reached the Neighbourhood, you see a lot of nice old heritage houses and many being still occupied. There are also some nice cafes hidden in the alley as you walk deeper down. A nice place to explore and have a cup of coffee in the nice cafes over there.
I think it is a little bit far away from Metro, I suggest you can take taxi to get here. It is a residential area, so please keep quiet.
those traditional houses are really unique. need to be quiet when you're there, as there are families living in it.nice to just take a walk there.

If you are looking for a no hassle Korean culture experience, Bukchon is a good place to start. Here, you can soak in the views of Korean living frozen in time. Walk the streets and enter permitted quarters that shows the interior of the hanok homes.

We came here after visiting the Changdokgung Palace nearby.  A very good Thai Restaurant is located in a basement on "Bukchon-Ro", about 1/2 way down the street. It is called "In The Mood For Love" Thai Restaurant. We had a wonderful meal there.  We also got to see an original Hanok on that street, it has been turned into a museum of sorts.
Nice old buildings. Many of them now functioning as guesthouses, galleries, cafés etc. Quaint charm.
It's a great place to go for a stroll, but just be weary that there are plenty of hills in the area to get to a nice view point

Very nice to see the different houses and styles and craftsmanship. Seems like a very expensive neighborhood nowadays. Lots of embassies in the neighborhood. Walking distance from the great palace . Nice places to have coffee and/or lunch.
Delightful walking up and down Bukchon. Should have joined a tour that includes going inside one of those homes, if that is even available.

Personally, I went to Bukchon for the hanok style houses. I found them less impressive than the glossy photos in the Bukchon brochure, let alone they are hard to find! Having said that the quarter is very charming and I loved the little restaurants that are tucked away in all those little alleys. Best to go there late afternoon so you can take a few pictures and then have proper Korean dinner.

This area has some beautiful traditional homes. The architecture of the homes, walls and streets is well maintained. We were able to step inside one of the homes to see the inner courtyard and rooms. The hike to the top of the hill is worth it as you get some incredible views of the downtown area. The pictures are beautiful with the well-kept traditional homes and the big city skyline in the background. It is important to be mindful of the fact that people still live here and to be respectful of their privacy and space.

If it is hot, there is not a lot of places for shade. There are a lot of places to eat and souvenir shops which is convenient. However the Chinese tour groups are very noisy and distracting. It's a nice area to walk around but try not to go in the middle of the day when it's hot.
It is a village of hanok. Cause it is on the hill,you can see seoul sightseeing view. Nice place. But there are lots of people

Great, ancient looking building/ houses! However many Chinese tour groups (the people are so embarrassing- talking super loud!!) no wonder there are so many signs written in Chinese to tell them keep the voice down!!

This is a lovely area to visit right after the palace as it is close by and you can walk then on to Insadong. There were little streets with many tourists, but overall quieter than other tourist areas. The houses were nice to explore from outside but would have rather had a guide or more info as background rather than just walk around.

We arrived in the late afternoon with our tour guide and the place is crowded. Even though there are signage to keep our voices low but the tourists around were too excited and noisy. We felt bad for the people whom really stay here. Luckier our toddler were asleep and we had a quick snap of photos. Don't miss the past president house and Yido cafe. Is a quiet place for a good coffee and you may be tempted to buy some korea ceramics at Yido cafe.
the houses were so beautiful and well maintained. nice stroll around the neighborhood but some roads may get to steep.

This is the place where all the old traditional houses are located. We stayed in one for 2 nights and enjoyed the experience very much. Most of the houses are very well maintained and great looking. The place can get quite crowded in the late mornings and afternoons with tourists. Best to come early morning.
I felt that this place is over-rated for couple like me. We like to see cultural things but the price to pay for visiting their home is like a little bit over.
Nice peaceful village.A must if visiting seoul to see the experience the traditional culture of Korea.

I went here for the old traditional house but the place did not really match my expectation.  Yes, there are houses, but it does look that old. It is a hilly walk up so may be i havent walk far enough to see the good thing.

Great for photo-taking as this is one of the last few original villages in Korea! There's a free museum to show you how it looks like inside and a few locally-run stores along the path. Other than that, nothing much else to do! Do keep your voices down as people still do live in the houses. Crowed with lots of people squeezed onto a small upslope path.

We rented hanboks and went there to take pictures. Was expecting a big village but I think it was just a small area. May be we didn't get to explore the entire place. It's still worth checking out, and it's right next to the Gyeongbokgung Palace.

Bukchon is extremely picturesque and makes for a great backdrop in your holiday photos. This is especially true if you've rented a hanbok for a day!  That said, you'll probably be done within an hour since most houses in the area look fairly similar. A possible itinerary goes as such: Gyeongbokgung Palace - Bukchon - Changdeokgung Palace. Get ready for lots of walking though!

This neighborhood has the last of the original houses of Korea. I found it fascinating as much of Seoul has high-rises and modern buildings. It's residential mixed with retail. Lovely homes provide insight into the history of Korea. Don't miss the smaller family-run shops and restaurants intertwined with the homes.
probably due to too many tourist at the scenic area, can't really get nice photo, and is a bit tiring to walk uphill also

Bukchon literally means North Village, traditional architecture of Hanok village where some Seoulites still live or conduct their business/cafe/restaurant. A very pleasant quaint eye opener into the past, there is that magic that is missing in the modern concrete jungles in most big metropolitan cities. Very easy to get to with the metro system, be prepared to spend a few hours even if you do not like "shopping". Stop for a meal in the old Hanok shop or coffee in a modern setting, admire some of the local creative and artistic wares. The prime minister's residence is just nearby, you can't miss it where so many friendly and polite police in uniforms standing around, I feel safer there, I did not see any machine guns!
Interesting place with mixture of Modern and traditional chic ! You are allow to take photos everywhere but please do not disturb the locals as the old houses are still occupied by the locals.

Cute little preserved 'village'. Most houses have been converted into little boutiques and cafes. Has a very hipster vibe though. Its right next to Gyeongbukgung Palace. So club it with the trip there. Schedule it in the afternoon or evening so you can either grab lunch at the little dimsum bar with the longest queue or for a little cafe time.

Definitely a must-visit! Been to Seoul twice in 2016, and went to Bukchon area four times - just beautiful. We had a walking tour the first time, and went back to dine and walk around more. A place suitable for families, the romantic and just friends hanging out.

We really enjoyed walking in the cool springtime air in Bukchon. The little shops were interesting and offered a lot of handmade jewelry and accessories, clothes, nice cafes and we stumbled upon a small flea market with a few unique stalls. Bought a perfume stick 15g for 7000won. We took nice photos with the interesting backdrops of the houses and cafes and even saw many lovely cherry blossoms trees. Enjoy and chill.

This neighborhood is very pleasant. Nice views, old houses, nice coffees and small museums or shops everywhere. Very different from the rest of the city. No longer very authentic though but still a good idea for spending a couple of hours
we enjoyed our casual walk. The surrounding area is fun for eating and shopping as well. Fun afternoon destination.

This quaint street gives you the hipster yet traditional vibes. We went by after Gyeongbokgung, there's this small corner stall that sells chicken skewers. MUST! (Short queue for it as they cook it on the spot) You can get some unique pieces here, totally different feel from myeongdong!

the area is a bit walking around 10 minutes from Anguk Station. uphill on some parts. it lets you see the way of life / houses of the past. there is also commercial area. you know that you are near the place cause of the many tourist and there are people that are around to ask question about the area. it is a private street so we have to be quiet at all times.

A street of old neighbourhood. You would need to walk about 15 minutes plus to reach there. Basically just an old alleyway that still retain old architecture. If you into architecture of common folk in olden days then this is place you want to go
A very interesting area to visit the houses has an amazing architecture some gift shops are available with good prices.
crowded at some spots but i joined a walking tour and received a thorough explanations on how they lived in the past. walk around the district, it's HUGE.

Pleasurable walk around small alleys and traditional Korean style homes. There is a lot of small shops, restaurants, cafes and places of interest throughout as well as really nice panoramic views of Seoul.  Excellent place for a little walk around with some gems scattered about in between.
