go early in the morning to miss the tourists. Beautiful buildings, gardens and architecture, wonder enough and you'll get a good view of seoul and find a street full of street food for a snack before moving onto the next location.

I'm not one for shopping so I can't comment on the many boutiques dotted around. However the setting is perfect for strolling around. If you pop into a tourist information office (easy to find) they can provide you with a map with an easy to follow walking route through some of the more beautiful areas. Besides the buildings there are also some good views of the nearby vistas. This is a good place for photos.

A lot of walking in Bukon village to enjoy the heritage site. You will enjoy the site if the weather is cool and not hot. However, do prepare a good walking shoe as there are many up hill and down hill route.

When you visit Seoul you must visit Bukchon to experience that part of the history, to see the architecture of the past. Best is to take the subway or bus to Anguk station as start/end of your walk through that neigbourhood. There is suggested route through the area that you can follow through the signs. On your way there are various local restaurants to try their typical local food. You won't regret the visit and there'll be many views to take memorable pictures of Hanok style houses.

This is a great place to stroll around and see some traditional Korean architecture. But get here early to avoid the crowds, especially if, like me, you want to take photos of the buildings without hordes of people in them.
Nice to view historic homes but more a tourist attraction. Not a whole lot to do in the area. Gift shops geared toward tourists. Lots of small shops and cafes too.

Thoroughly enjoyed our tour of bukchon. We spent the morning exploring samcheongdong, which was a good blend of modern buildings housed in refurbished old buildings. The streets were really pretty. In the afternoon, we moved on to do a guided tour of buchok hanok. We saw many quaint and well preserved hanok. Our guide was wonderful and shared many stories with us on how a hanok was built and life in the buchon.

A selection of shops, crafts tea rooms and interesting houses, definitely worth a couple of hours. There are some nice traditional tea and coffee houses - they charge more than most but have much more character and serenity than the 100s of Starbucks that have sprung up in the city
To find this island of tradition in the middle of an exploding Seoul was a nice experieince. The wooden houses that once were all over Korea can still be seen here in this living museum.

One of my favorite place in Seoul, been there many times, this is a lovely place to have a walk (really liked the traditionnal korean houses - hanok), near Insadong and the royal palaces that you can visit in the same day.  It can be a bit crowded that is why I recommend you to go there on weekdays and especially in the morning cause it even more enjoyable where there is few people in the area

This beautiful Hanook village (traditional Korean housing village) is really beautiful. The buildings are well maintained and the activities on offer for tourists are fun to do and see. This area however, is a residential area and so when walking through it you need to be aware of that and remain quiet. It is worth a visit though!

The Bukon Hanok Village is located beside SamChongDong and is alittle complicated to find if you are heading there via SamChongDong. My partner and i spent quite a while trying to find that famous down slope photospot of the hanok houses.  There are also tea houses located within the village and it is an interesting place to visit after visiting GyeongBokGung and SamChongDong shopping belt.

This was a really cool experience. All they pushes looked beautiful. It was as if you went back in history just strolling through the neighborhood. It's still houses real residences so we tried to be quiet as we walked through the 8 viewing points. But here is a cultural center that where you can experience making Korean crafts for a fee. I would highly encourage looking into this and making reservations. We saw some people wearing hanboks walking around and it turned out to be tourists that rented them for four hours so they could stroll around in those beautiful dresses as they went through the neighborhoods!!! Way beautiful... They indicated that the rental place was near the subway station! It's best to go to the tourist kiosks to inquire :)

It is a hanok village with its' peaceloving residents. If you do visit: mind your manners (must say that even the locals were quite noisy while visiting the area). What draws locals to this area is not the hanok village but the trendy surrounding area with its boutique shops, cafes and trendy restaurant.

I found it amazing that in the middle of an ultra modern city, this gem exists. It truly feels like I have stepped on the set of those Korean dramas my father in law watches! Alongside quaint shops and cafes, this is truly a relaxing side of Seoul that I would highly recommend to all.

Visit the place very early to avoid crowd of tourist. Its best also to mind your noise since this is a residential place. Too bad a lot of posters are in their doors already because of noisy visitors but there are houses with camera badge for picture taking.

This was a fascinating area to visit; very busy on a sunny Saturday afternoon. There are little streets with pretty little houses. In the surrounding area are a myriad of cafes, sweet shops, street food and the like. On week-ends (and maybe week days), the locals (especially the girls) like to dress up in traditional Korean costumes and have their photos taken. There are hire shops that cater for this (but I gather they don't hire shoes - they were all wearing Nikes and the like!). Apparently, they can get into the various Palaces for free if they are in costume. Most are delighted to have their photos taken by or with foreign tourists - I don't mean cynically, but they want to be noticed - that's the whole point of dressing up. Even children get into the act. And there are plenty in the Bukchon Hanok Village area, making for great photos. I had a great time here.

Took us a while to find this place, and there's lots of steep roads to negotiate when you are there. But strangely, it's a pretty enjoyable place to visit. Maybe because of the unique houses or the nice cafes along the narrow streets. Worth a visit.

It is best to go to the Tourist Info Center 1st to get maps & ask which site to go. It is a huge area to go around. There are 2 main sites to see with traditional houses & museums around the area. It's quite a long walk so wear a comfortable walking shoes n hats as well. Most of the hanoks are private houses still being use by the locals so a lot of them are close and only the exterior of the houses and the roof tiles are available as photo ops. Some houses choose to open to visitors for workshops showing off kite making, lacquering, knotting, embroidery, and the hanbok. Thumbs up!!!

Definitely a busy spot for Japanese and Chinese tourists. There's some interesting Hanok architecture and even great cafes there too. A lot of hills and winding paths. Bring your most comfy shoes and try to be polite to the house owners.

Well, only if you are into that sort of thing. It's quite a track and it's rather hilly. As the village is actually residences, you won't be able to see much except the streets and the outside of the houses. You will also see numerous (read: in your face) signs to keep your noise level down so as not to bother the residents there.

This would not be my top ten list in terms of the must-sees in Seoul. If you have many days in Seoul and you have already done what most tourists do...perhaps then. It gets quite crowded since all the Chinese tourist groups stop here. Besides the traditional homes, there are a few good restaurants including a thin pizza place which is well-known to locals. There is also a specialty department store which specializes in ceramic pieces, although quite expensive though but they do have memorable pieces.
be prepared to walk a lot of uphill & ve a good pair of walking shoes , best wear Loafer coming here just to see Korea old buildings
This is a great place to stroll through to see Korea as it used to be. The traditional architecture is so beautiful and the location near the palaces is very convenient.

There's a lot of retail and restaurants in this old quarter of the city but one can still find some traditional design structures. The Baek In-Je house provides a very good glimpse of the old designs. Not far from here is a samgyetang ginseng chicken soup restaurant which I found to be quite nice.

This place is huge. We couldn't finish walking (with children). We also lost our way and a nice local guy showed us the way. There are restaurants and some serve really great food. However, they are really serious about having their own lunch that they do not serve guests at certain times.  The traditional houses are very beautiful and they look really luxury. We went to a traditional hanbok clothing shop and rented them for photo-taking. These are real hanboks made of silk and really very beautiful. It was a real original Korean experience in Bukchon.
this place had Korean traditional houses and beautiful view. a great place to experience some history+tradition! But I gotta say, I surely did walk a lot!
First thing we wanted to see is the old, authentic area of Bukchon. And it's well worth visiting. Lots of small coffee shops that makes you feel warm and welcome.
The whole place has an authentic traditional feel to it and brings you back to ancient Korea times. There are a lot of traditional crafts to try. Excellent place to go!

Nice place to visit. Very calm. Not much of big shopping center. A lot of small shop selling traditional stuff. Can see teens wearing their hanbok walking around. The street food there can be abit pricey as it's a tourist spot. Get a map so you won't get lost. The visitor center very efficient . Speak English very good.

We decided to walk the area before the Palaces opened in the morning. It is residential so it is important to be quiet and not disturb the families living there. We wanted to do the Bukchon 8 photo spots and had read some blogs about the best way to do this. I assumed the area was larger than it was and we decided to skip spots 1-3. It only took us 10 minutes to walk the remainder so I wish we had done the whole walking tour. We were there around 8, so the streets were empty and it felt so peaceful.

Step back in time to see these beautiful hanok houses, still well maintained and lived in. The area is amazing and well worth it. However it might be difficult for people with mobility issues to get around as there are a lot of steep hills to get up and down.
The old buildings are well maintained and offer a fascinating contrast to the very modern city centre.

It's a residential area made of preserved hanok homes. There is a tourist strip along the main street, and a few renovated homes as cheap museums/arts centers, but other than that it really is a neighborhood. Nice, quiet, and quaint. But not somewhere I'd seek out again.
We enjoyed our time here. Lots of places to take great photos. There's also plenty of shops and restaurants in the area.

It was a pleasure walking round this traditional village and I enjoyed the architecture. The trendy and traditional shops around added to the atmosphere of this place. Visited an old house which was free and enjoyed looking into the rooms. Stopped to have a lovely Ginseng Chicken soup meal. The view from the top was great and the wall murals were an attraction in itself. I enjoyed the exercise of walking up and down this Hanok village.

Very interesting to check out the old town from Joseon Dynasty. Buk chon (North Town) is village with old Koreab traditional houses built around in 1930s. In Bukchon village, there are 8 different spots to check out different views to enjoy the old town.
Nice traditional village located in the middle of the Seoul. Unforgettable experiance, feel the Korea as it used to be
Part if the world heritage .. The houses are scattered, will have to talk little and get lose often but it's enjoyable experience after all

Went there wanted to take nice photos but couldn't find the right spot as what i saw from YouTube and website. Quite disappointed. Might be good if there's sign board there directing us to the right photo-taking spot.

I've always been amazed with these hanoks whenever I see them in Korean dramas, so I made it a point to visit Bukchon last December. Wear the most comfortable shoes when you visit, as you will do nothing but walk. Be prepared for the uphill trek, too. The pathways are lovely, and the houses are a sight to behold.
It is a good place to take photos. Please remember to keep your volume down because there are people living there. We totally enjoyed the view and walking around those houses.

Bukchon is the old style ville. you can go there by sub-way. The ville is on the hill, you can go up there and see the high view perspective. Not too much attractive view point, or interesting point. The ville is not too much attractive. The good thing is the food street near the ville, don't spend too much time in this.
Very little interest. A few so called typical old corean houses. Nothing to be amazed of. Strongly recommend to skip and visit Namsangol Hanok traditional village instead, absolutely lovely.
Everywhere you turn there is a new detail to admire. Really enjoyed Traditional old Seoul. walking around here,

This place there are a couple of traditional houses kept. Have to walk inside the smaller lanes. However this is still occupied by the local residents so can't go in and visit it. However if wanted to experience the traditional houses there are a couple of guesthouse. Can visit one of the high school located uphill. What a nice atmosphere to study in the school.
Nice for walking around, tea houses, small restaurants, feel of old Seoul. Make it a half a day trip if in the city. So far it was my favourite part.

A straight walk after came out of the cdk palace, we arrived at bukchon museum which is the place one should see first before wondering around the area. All houses that were remained appear to be built of the same type of architeture structure, probably the same peroid.....never evolved? All countries have these remants but some are better than these primitive ones. Not too attractive in any perspective and it has been made too commerical. It was nice to walk for half an hour and hit to some other place.

A great relaxing place for tourists. You can meet up with artists here or view specialty shops. The roads are beautiful, the building historic. The people who live here are so lucky! Get a map because the roads are winding, take lots of photos and wear comfortable shoes
Seoul is busy, lack of quiet places for your own time. This is the right place. Lots of great architectures and streets with foreigners allow you to be your own.
The village is very interesting and lovely designs. It has traditional and modern. Then go to Samchungdong for lunch as it is very near Bukchon Hanok Village. This area has many nice cafes to choose.

This hanok village reminds me of the hutons in Beijing I love the way there is such a relatively big area so well preserve and alive (people live in the centuries old houses) in a quite impersonal city as Seoul. Definitely worth visiting and having a traditional tea in our of the amazing tea houses

You have to pace your walk as this is not a single straight street. You'd have to climb up the hill/street to get a glimpse of the old houses. Note that they have old and new houses there, this is not some historical place protected by UNESCO. It was a nice walk.

Frankly speaking, this hasn't been a great place for tourists in Seoul. However, now it is transformed to the very perfect spot for any travelers. As it is located just next to two main palaces in Seoul, you can also walk through this place.
Absolutely beautiful traditional Korean houses, Slope of the street makes this place even special and beautiful, highly recommend visiting this place.

Lovely traditional Korean homes. Wonderful to wander (and get lost) around the tiny lanes. Lots of photo taking opportunities. Bukchon is growing in popularity, which means that more and more tourists are heading here. Wish they would respect the residents’ privacy and keep noise levels down. It would also make for a more tranquil experience as they explore this lovely traditional neighborhood.
Basically this area is good for a 2 - 3 hrs of slow walk. You will see a lot of traditional houses and building.Good for those that like to take a lot of photos during travel.

One of the best place i considered in Korea.. aside from the preserve traditional look of the place.. i loved the serenity and peace of the place.. it is definitely one of the highlight of our stay in korea

Went with high expectations and well after a walk from the nearest station of about 10 mins reached the place . . kept on wondering what was there to see apart from small lanes and old houses . . only go if you have nothing else to see :)

We went here using the "hop-on, hop-off" bus and a walking map. The houses are built in a traditional style with tile roof, masonry and timber exterior walls, masonry boundary wall and heavy wooden gate. The walk is quite long and parts are up hill so wear comfortable shoes, and don't forget to wear appropriate clothing as the full walk is several hours. There are marvellous street vistas and interesting views across the roof tops from the top of the hill.  There are many cafes and restaurants for refreshments.
We went to Bukchon on a freezing day, but it was fun experience walking along the street which looks just like in a K-drama. We took place in a workshop to make a traditional book mark.
The buildings are very unique & beautiful. This is a must visit place which reflect the beauty of Korea in a traditional way.
This place is where one can see the traditional architecture of Korea. A sloppy place to explore, best done in the evening where it is not crowded.

accessibility - good view - fair. for those who want to have a walk around the city, this is a good place to visit. Note only that this is a residential place so please observe silence as a respect to the residence of Bukchon Village.

We love visiting the Bukchon Hanock Village in Seoul. Get a map & it is easy to navigate. There are amazing traditional hanocks that are open to view. The neighborhood is fun to explore. A beautiful way to see the views of traditional & modern Seoul.

Listed in a must visit for Seoul. You must love it. All the area are the korean style house. good for photo and walking but please be silent as it is a residential area. I found that it is quite crowded when I visited and people were speaking too loudly.

Actually, there are only some houses which still have Korean ancient architecture. However, it seems to me that there are so many tourists, which makes Bukchon quite crowded and I cannot feel the ancient atmosphere here. Some places require to pay money for entrance.
This old korean village are beautiful. there are old houses along the uphill road. Be sure to be polite and don't be noisy, cause there are still people live there.

We went there in the morning, not so crowded with tourists. Have a nice walk around and visited the traditional korean house.  Love those small little lanes, quite environment and fresh air compared with places like Myeongdong & Dongdaemen.  They are also some shops along the way selling food and souvenirs.  Recommended to tourists.

It would take 15 min or so to walk from the metro station to the area, slightly uphill. Watch out if you go with young kids or elders, also during winter time too. Kinda cold for the walk But totally worth it. Historic places but with nice contemporary cafes around. Next to the area, there is a cool and trendy area for young local people (not big brands but nice small shops for all kinda, lifestyle, fashion and cafes). You can spend about 1/2 day there and surrounding area.

Though this may seem like a touristy area, it is filled with great little independent boutiques selling one off clothing pieces, it reminds me a little of Covent Garden in London or Greenwich Village in New York. I love the cutesy cafes and coffee bars - one of my favourite neighbourhoods in Seoul!

Stayed here for 4 days. I will definitely stay in this area next time I visit in 2016. In walking distance of some of the main attractions. It's busy through the day with lots of tourists given its a heritage site.
If you need a moment to wander in the calm far from the city crowds, it is the perfect place. Really charming.
Is this a great place to visit? To me, so...so. Is there any interesting thing to see? To me, old Korean houses. Is it worth your time to visit? Do visit if you have the spare time.

I remember watching an episode on running man where the members exclaimed about the beauty of samcheongdong / bukchon hanok village. As I reached the place after walking over from Gyeongbokgung, I understood why even locals love the place. It's simply a charming district filled with rows and rows of hanok style buildings, and a mix of modern looking shops and restaurants. Every turn and angle leads to another path of beautiful shophouses. A very interesting place and I can say it's one of my favourite districts to just wander around, take photos and get lost in the many similar looking alleys. Even the bare trees in winter that lined the streets looked pretty! A pity we were rushing if not we could have explored the place more. There are 9 photo zones, but I didn't have time to visit them. I would gladly visit samcheongdong/ bukchon hanok village again during my next trip and take lots of photos of the beautiful hanoks! It is walkable from gyeongbokgung, changdeokgung and insadong! Topokki sold here is different from the usual, the rice cakes are on skewers. Found the traditional candy, ppopgi here as well and i was so happy! Touristy it may be, but we found some really good buys there :)

My daughter, 9, and I picked up a walking map from the tourist info center. She had fun navigating the place.  As it was still a place of residence for the locals, there were many notices put up to remind tourists to lower their volume.  Definitely worth a visit to see the old architecture. Highly convenient as it was right smack in the city. Just a little cold in winter. So, if your schedule is flexible, pick a nice sunny day.

Great to stroll around the village early morning or near sunset, when all the tour buses have left. You don't need a map, just walk around. All roads lead back to the main road. Respect the quiet, people do live and work there.

Even though I don't have book knowledge of architecture of any countries, I do love visiting and looking at old architectures in different countries. It just amazes me how different eastern and western architectures are, yet both are really captivating to look at.  Bukchon is a must visit to people who visit Seoul, especially if you are interested in history or architecture or both. You would have to be quiet while visiting though since the houses have people living in them. They are not just for display. Best time to visit would be Autumn or Spring.

My Korean tutor's husband was our tour guide for a day and this was one of the places we went to because I really wanted to see a Hanok Village. There are a lot of steep hills, and it is tiring (especially since it was HOT) but it was very much worth it. If you get to the top of the hill in the neighborhood, there is a beautiful tea house. I recommend sitting outside on the terrace and enjoy the view while sipping mango tea. We got up there just before sunset. It was so peaceful and relaxing but at the same time very exciting and vibrant. I have never seen another neighborhood like this in any of my travels.

In the whole city during my time ther i found myself at everytime walking to here, it is because it's a calm neighberhood, old houses and the smell of wood, don't forget to get this Guide from the Tourist Information and Go to all the mention Spots, you will get the best Shots ever Do it in the morning you will be alone there and perfect for shooting, the afternoon gets busy again Enjoy it

Bukchon and Samcheon are in the same neighborhood and are worth a trolley about (but not in the snow since some roads are steep). You needn't follow any particular route. I have been many a time and I am still pleasantly surprised by some of the little alleyway treasures. Also very near Changdeokgung Palace, so a good combo. Get off at Anguk Station exit 2

Visited Bukchon village after Gyeongbokgung Palace. Lots of alleys to venture into and get immensed in the traditional housing of the Joseon era. While some of these hanok houses have remained as residential quarters, many have been converted to shops, galleries and eating places.

this attraction require some stamina to walk. it is situated along a slope and not recommended for elderly (unless the old folks are strong enough to walk up a slope).  Views are great with many photo opportunities

Yes, there are still hanok houses here, but most of them have become souvenir shops. I was a bit disappointed. I felt that it had lost some of its authentic charm. But it's hard to find places that are truly authentic nowadays. So, it's still a nice place to visit, but don't expect to see anything other than restaurants and kitschy shops.

Visit was interesting looking at the traditional houses, especially in the cold weather where it is less taxing compared to summer. Lots of things to window shop and street side food as well as cafes too.

This place is a nice quiet town with so many back alleys to take instagram photos. There is a cafe right at the corner that sells sweet potato latte! Please take a map at the start of the walking trail to see which scenic spots to take photos
Was not too impressed, as neighborhood seems overly refurbished. Was hoping to feel the air of the Josen dynasty architecture.

It was nice to see old houses and this village was able to preserved their houses. This is a residential area but they allow the public to roam around and have their pictures taken with the traditional houses as their background. But be mindful with noises as the residents do not like to be disturbed.  There's no fee when you visit the village and it is just 40 minutes walk from Gyeongbokgung Palace and few kilometers away to Insadong Market. Don't mind the long walk as the place is very nice for walking. Just enjoy the scenery and the culture that the Koreans has to offer.  There is also a shop allowing the visitors to try the traditional Korean costume with a fee at the Bukchon village.

This places is where you can see the traditional korean houses. Many tourists as well as the locals came to this tourist attraction and took some photos. There isn't anything special except for the houses. As it is a residential place (where some people are living in), you have to be considerate and keep your volume down.  There are also some souvenir shops and cafes around. Nice to visit if you are curious or interested about the look or feel of traditional korean houses.

Bukchon Hanok Village is an area of Seoul that every tourist should visit and experience. I was there on a Friday and some of the buildings were not open for viewing on that day. Fortunately, I got to experience the Korean Hanbok dress and take pictures. That was quite inexpensive. Otherwise, the locals do not recommend eating in this area as prices are higher than average. There are also some nice souvenir and pottery shops along the main street.
Amazing to see the contrast in these traditional houses versus modern houses. Some houses offer photoshoots in traditional hanboks. I liked that food was readily available

If you need to get away from the shopping and modern city Seoul can be, then definitely head to this place. Small roads to fit yourself and a smart car side by side. Hills back and forth so you get a workout. The bugging of this place has little boutique stores and very few craft stores. There is definitely food all around

Good place to stroll around, see some old Korean style houses, and shop for some vintage souvenirs. With friends, not really worth visiting on its own, but since it's close to the palaces and Insadong, you can just pass by.
Tradional village with narrow street up the slope from the main road. We saw movie filming when you are walking. Lovely slow walk.

This place is great and amazing. But, I'd like you to know that if you don't feel hiking and walking a lot, then u should not visit the place because you need to walk a lot and it's very steep. But, because of Super Junior, i visited this place!
Nice place where they preserved the old residential houses. And these are 'living' area where people are currently still living there. You won't need a lot of time there but good to see.

You cannot missed to visit Bukchon Hanol Village when you are in Seoul. Basically, Bukchon is a private residential area but the unique thing is their houses are Hanoks (traditional Korean house since Joseon era). These houses has been passed down to generations has underwent minor renovation to suits current lifestyle. most of the houses here are the same structure since Joseon era. A must go.

Came here early in the morning when its not too busy. The streets are narrow and hilly at certain parts. Wear a good walking shoe and be prepared to walk. Many small shops selling interesting touristy things. Enjoy the traditional houses and don't forget to shoot photos. Stop by at Gahoe 2nd Floor observatory for coffee and enjoy the view.

It was interesting to see the area, with lots of little shops to pop in and out of. I would recommend exploring the rest of Anguk, perhaps for lunch, on the same day, and the nearby Gyeongbokgung Palace

Its a beautiful well kept village, for a reason too. Since its a living village, visitors should respect the villagers, but i dont see much villagers there :). Mostly are tourist taking pictures with cafes, restaurant and convenience shops. Place are kept clean and you always have tourist police in red uniform to guise you.
The houses are beautiful , good for photos but that's about it. Not a very big deal. It's a good 15 mind walk from the station...just keep going . There are some coffee houses you can try

A very interesting place as it shows a traditional houses with alleys leading to more interesting houses. But many tourists do make a lot of noises which they are not supposed to do since there are people living in the houses.

Get out at anguk station exit 2 and just walk straight up the street until you see the information booth. There you can get a map, which I would recommend because you can get very turned around here. They have 8 spots for good photos which are marked on the map. There are also information people in red that walk around and can point you in the right direction. There are LOTS of hills which can be exhausting, but the views really are stunning. I recommend going in the Fall because all the colors on the trees are gorgeous. Must be quiet because people still live in those houses. When you go down the (rather terrifying) stairs of the 8th view, Samcheongdong is right there at the bottom. You can walk down that street to get to Gyeongbokgung. Insadong is also close by. We visited all these places in one day. Bring your walking shoes! Hills!
Great for shopping and cafes short walk from folk museum. We had our toddler in a pram which restricted where we could go as very hilly, but still a nice place to wander and get lost.
Visit this place early in the morning so you won't encounter noisy, annoying tourists. You'll be able to appreciate the houses more and find some relaxing time while walking around.

right after our tour at gyeongbukgong palace, we went straight to bukchon hanok village to see for ourselves how koreans live centuries ago. it was a great learning experience and they were able to preserve something of their past and converted it to modern times. we had a lot of photo opportunities and were able to pose wearing traditional korean costumes(hanbok). use your smartphones to take unlimited photos. they only give you one small colored photo.

We visited Bukchon Hanok Village while in Seoul. It was a highlight of our time there. We found that it was absolutely fascinating to walk through the narrow lanes and alleys of this neighborhood full of traditional Korean homes. Part of the appeal of this area is that this area is lived-in. It is NOT a museum, but a living, vibrant community. People take care of their homes and the streets and alleys are well-kept. Be ready to climb some steep stairs to get there, though. The 'village' is perched on hillsides and as you walk around, you get wonderful views of the village and the modern city off in the distance. If you're up for a strenuous walk and ready to climb flights of stairs to get into this village, you will not be disappointed with your effort. Come and see this memorable village for yourself.
This area can show you how Korean people lived in 200 years ago. The house is called Hanok, which has interesting structure.

One of my favourite memories of Seoul! Authentic traditional Korean architecture still used as a residential area, so you won't get touristy stuff shoved in your face on every step. It's quite quiet but surrounded by cool little shopping areas too.

The whole neighborhood consist of traditional korean houses or hanok. There are volunteer that gave us map showing several location that is the best spot to took pictures. The area is very quiet and calm. Very relaxing
This place is awesome. If you want to see how old korean house style, you can come here. The architecture is awesome. This place is famous place for korean drama shooting.
was with a few korean friends so we went to a lot of places... this was one of them,., my first trip to seoul..but i will be back

just a few minute walking from anguk subway station and then you'll get there. very nice Korean's traditional house and still clean,but you should be quiet in this place because it's also a residential area. nice place to walk around and get some beautiful picture, and its all free :D

Just a few minutes walk from the Changdeokgung Palace is the Bukchon Hanok Village. it was good to see up close what korean traditional houses look like. we also discovered that there are guesthouses or hanoks for rent in this area which we want to try next time!  there are lots of coffee shops and food stalls in the area. we went here in the morning before taking the 10:30 am English tour at Changdeokgung Palace  to get to Bukchon Hanok: take the subway, alight at Anguk Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), then take Exit 2

If you want to have a look of the old Korean houses, this is a good place. I think they are beautiful. These houses are still being occupied by local residents. You can enter some of these houses by paying a fee but we were able to visit one with free admission. If you are lucky, sometimes you could finnd locals wearing traditional Korean clothes wandering around the streets.

Korean 's traditional houses on hill,near Changdeok Palace, Gyeongbok Palace and Samcheongdong-gil Nice place to walking around and take nice photography. Visit Bukchon Traditional Culture Center to get a free map and find out more attractions around Bukchon. You can see Namsan Tower clearly, suggest you to visit here on weekday to avoid large tourist groups And because this is and active residential area so please do not disturb the residents and keep quite ^^

I spent a week in Bukchon and while I did not get to visit all the main sites and attractions of Seoul I think living in Bukchon gave me a real sense of what it's like to live and work in modern Korea. Bukchon remains very traditional in the sense that several hundred traditional houses ( Hanok) and workshops remain so you can spend time wandering through the narrow lanes and a number of buildings offer workshop experiences such as kite making, ceramics, traditional dress ( hanbok) experiences to enhance the cultural experience. In addition I noticed a lot of Korean tourists were staying in houses converted into homestay or guest houses. The area also has strong connections with modern Korea as the streets are filled everyday when workers pour out of the Hyundai office blocks to buy coffee in the many coffee shops ( yes - these do include Starbucks!). Lots of food outlets too offering lots of variety. Sadly a few streets are overrun by tourists ( mainly Chinese) and this can limit the pleasure but there are plenty of times and streets when the coach tours are not there to spoil the sense of being in a living and lively local community. If you get the chance - don't just visit - try and stay in Bukchon.
It's quite a walk uphill but it's interesting to see the houses on our way up. Nice place to take memorable photos of your visit to Seoul

Well, the experience was refreshing as this is something that cannot be seen in my home country. I would say the old-style houses are beautiful, but it can be slightly disappointing as that is about it. If you are have want to go there, You actually can as you can do some shopping around the area. It is also near Insadong, where you can do quite alot of stuff as well.

Worth a visit. This place are so beautiful, quiet and peaceful. We were in spring season, the weather was great and the flowers blooming all over the place. It was green environment. This village mainly filled with old style korean houses and there were cute shops along the street. Stairs were kinda narrow and steep. No need to rush and enjoy the amazing view.

An interesting area of Seoul to visit is the Bukchon Village near Changdeokgung Palace. This is an historic neighbourhood where you can find hundreds of Hanoks, traditional Korean style houses, recognised for its unique architecture and structural positioning in relation to the contours of the surrounding land.  Here you can walk paved streets, lined with Hanoks, many of which remain residential while others serve as cafes, coffee shops, shops, galleries and a handful of small museums. Seems there are some homestay opportunities in the area as well if visitors fancy staying in a Hanok during their time in Seoul.  We found Bukchon to be a good place to stroll and enjoyed seeing the many traditional Korean style buildings. It felt over-marketed and promoted but still a nice place to spend time, especially if you intend to be in the area, visiting the UNESCO World Heritage Chengdeokgung Palace. You can easily explore a good portion of Bukchon for 30-45 minutes before or afterwards.  Note: The area where you find Bukchon Village is quite hilly so be prepared for some steep street climbs from time to time.

The streets are narrow and steep and can be confusing to navigate without a map. The traditional buildings are interesting to look at but vestiges of modernity are everywhere, with fingerprint scanner locks installed over ancient looking doors. Over promoted as a tourist attraction, resulting in large number of tourists around, making moving around the place challenging at times.
Walking through the street with old style korean houses.  it is an eye opener I would say. worth a visit.  after that, can visit samcheongdong for shopping and plenty of cafes lined along the street.

Walking around in alleys and finding different Hanok houses was interesting. A lot of Hanok have been converted into galleries, cafes or guesthouses. This area is still largely residential. Be considerate when walking around.
The area is filled with traditional houses (hanok) and is a pleasant walk from Insadong. There are various dining options in the area.

This village preserves the old shapes of Korea in the era of Joseon Dynasty. Also, there are lots of restaurants specilazed in dishes, cafes, galallies, etc.. Go to there if you want to see Kirean cultures. There are lots of foreigners getting around.

Bukchon area, especially the Hanok Village is a must-visit place IMO. You can walk around, sightseeing, and if you have the map, you can seek for the recommended photo spots and take some insta-worthy shots!  Do mind that LOTS of walking is involved and the area does get crowded at times. And because the hanok(s) are private properties and people actually live there, we are not suppose to visit after 6pm, if I remember correctly :)

A great place to walk through and get a glimpse of old Seoul. I toured the Western Gyeongbokgung Palace in the morning and en route to Changdeokgung Palace and Secret Garden I toured through the narrow streets of Bukchon. A great place for photos and many little places to grab a refreshing beverage to quench your thirst or take in a traditional Korean BBQ. Highly recommend Bukchon Village as a destination while in Seoul.
Walking around the place, please maintain silence to give privacy to homeowners. Both sides should be visited

I spent a pleasant few hours wandering around here. While the traditional houses are interesting, I was happy just soaking in the local flavour and enjoying the delicious street food. Gets quite crowded late afternoons on the weekends.

Very beautiful traditional houses, steep lanes, plants and flowers - wonderful ambiance. The fact that people still live there normally adds a very "live" aspect to this area. In the part closer to Gyeongbokgung Palace there are lots of cafes, restaurants, art galleries.

We took a morning walk from Insadong to the area. Mainly old traditional style houses where people live in -- not a museum but an actual neighborhood. There is a temple towards the top, plus some shops along the day. A place to look for persimmon trees if you have never seen one.  Good place for picture taking if you love traditional architecture.  Along the way to the area are some museums, souvenir shops, and street food vendors.

I feel like I would have enjoyed spending more time inside a palace or museum as we didnt get to see the inside of any house since my husband and I did the tour on our own. Seeing a few houses would have sufficed for me! Looks the same anyway hehe. Pretty steep inclines to the best locations so its not recommended for seniors or anybody who is too tired..

Beautiful houses. You can see how is korean traditional house is look like. No free tour available. All houses and close and there is sign not make noise. You can enjoy and feel the sourounding and take picture of the house.  I
its such beautiful village, surround with old traditional home korea. you can find many traditional home here, clean place, you can visit for free. if you like history is good place to visit

Personally I prefer this to Myeongdong. I could spend the whole day strolling along the narrow roads of this traditional old town, admiring the buildings, houses, rooftops, trying out every quaint little cafes. A must go if u r like me, prefer to have a taste of life at a slower pace. It's like Kyoto in Japan.
Love the place with perfect location of traditional view in the city. Lovely atmosphere to walk around.

I can say that this traditional village may be home of pioneer residents in the city. It is only in this village that I saw traditional houses with luxurious cars parked outside their porch.  If you are a K-drama fan, you'll find here the gate featured in Lee Min Ho's drama 'Personal Taste'.

This was a very old, traditional part of old Seoul - which stands in stark contrast to all of the large buildings and skyscrapers you see elsewhere in the city. Here you find tiny, traditional houses as they once stood 50 or more years ago. This is not an exciting place to visit - more historical.
I think everybody would enjoy visiting this romantic, cozy and beautiful neighborhood. Stroll there to enjoy old times idyllic set up. Take a lot of pics.
You will pass by traditional Korean houses. No other interesting activities. You can try to wear their traditional Korean dress but quite expensive 7000 Korean won!

If you would like to see authentic, traditional Korean houses, you should definitely come here! Be prepared, that in will be too crowded, and you have to be super patient if you would take a good photo on the neighbourhood without tourist hordes.
This is an old house places and very interested to visit. Prepare to walk with comfortable shoes and many eating shops are other fashion shops.
We reached when its almost dark. We managed to take a few photos. Lovely view. Regret not to come early. I will come back again.
This is indeed a nice area for walking, a little uphill, but through quiet streets. The houses are old and quaint. Plenty of shops and eating facilities in the direction of Insadong.

Samcheong-dong + Bukchon is a must-visit area in Seoul . The Hanok (traditional Korean Houses) and modern buildings blended perfectly and gives this place its unique flavor. There are also many nice cafes in this area.  The place is within walking distance from Gyeongbukgung Palace and is easily accessible.

I actually stayed in Bukchon for my first leg of my trip. It's quiet and charming. It's very close to two palaces. The subway is close by. I loved staying in this neighbourhood and walking round. If you don't love the hustle and bustle I highly recommend it for an area of stay.

Walked around the whole area. It might have been an historic site but currently it is all renovated. There are some coffee shops and small restaurants west of the Gyeongbokgung Palace. If you are willing to walk, stroll south trough Buckchon Road until the Insa-dong area and further south. Nice follow up after the Palace visit, which is a mandatory destination.

My husband and I walked around this area on a Wednesday morning and it was fairly crowded. There is a nice small museum set up in one of the houses that you can walk through. The buildings were interesting, but if you only have a short time in Seoul you could skip this. On a side street there were some good views of one of the mountains. There was also a little wine bar and a cafe with a good view of the mountain, but neither were open. I imagine they would have pretty views at night.
This is my first visit to Bukchon in my 4th trip in Seoul and it was amazing to see the traditional houses well kept in this quiet neighbourhood in Seoul.
You can visit Buchon's street for shopping then go to 31 Gahoe-dong or 11 Gahoe-dong route to view the hanok. Gahoe-dong is up hill and downhill need a lot of walking but the hanok is worth to visit.

This place has real traditional houses where people still live in. Of course they don't still live the olden way. But rather, they just restore the traditional houses and have electricity and water and all the comforts of modern day living.  Nice place to check out.

Some people complain about lots of shop there. True, lot of those houses have been converted into shops and homestay. However, if you go further into the alley, there are MORE that are NOT been converted, and still keep it original, or even much older. You need to go out of what the "Map" tells you. Otherwise, you can only see what a tourist can see.

If you love those scene in Korean TV series, you should not miss this place. You can easily spent your entire day exploring this place, shop to shop, cafe to cafe, etc. Be prepared to wear your comfortable shoe as the terrain there can be quite challenging for some. But the amount of food intake and easily burn-off at teh end of the day. Beautiful place. Must allocate time for this.

Took some time to stroll around here in-between visiting Changdeokgung and Gyeongbokgung Palaces. This neighbourhood is extremely charming and picturesque. It’s full of adorable restaurants, cafes, and shops that are a joy to visit. I recommend doing lunch in Bukchon and getting lost in the winding alleys and streets on a leisurely afternoon.

Wonderful neighborhood of traditional houses very well preserved. This is mostly a residential area, but surrounded by great shopping and cafes. The building style is "old Seoul" and houses have been lovingly restored. Don't even think of driving on the narrow and winding streets - this is a walker's paradise. There is a neighborhood walking tour marked on locally posted maps and an information center that can provide more walk info. This is well worth the time!
I love the street & old korean houses here..so nice and pretty.. It's so quiet because it's actually ordinary residence.the sign of "silence please" is everywhere..

Paid this a visit and it was worth it to see the hanoks which are a rarity in modern Seoul. There are specific photo zones (on the ground) that you can look out for to get the best angle for your photos. Is a popular spot for couples in every season, and there are traditional activities you can take part in, just do some research online. Since this is a residential area, visitors are reminded via signs to keep the noise level down in the neighbourhood.

We were disappointed. It took us a good 20 minutes walk from the Gyeongbokgung Palace to get to the village. There were hardly any proper directional signs to lead us there and we had to ask along the way for pointers. When we arrived, instead of seeing hanok, we were greeted by a changing landscape of modern houses mixed with whatever is left of hanoks. What remained were converted to guests house.

If you have a map of Bukchon (easily google it or you can ask a map from their tourist guide dressing in red clothes), there are 8 spots you can visit. Because of our strict schedule, I only manage few spots here but I am satisfied! The view was amazing. This road is in uphill so prepare your foot! You can rent a hanbok in Bukchon Museum, right before you turn left to downhill (check your map!). The rent is cost 10000krw. It's expensive but worth it! The color is so pretty and you can wear it outside and enjoy Bukchon for 30minutes! If you want to go to Insadong, you can visit Insadong after Bukchon just by walking and chill the road. There are a lot of cafes, restaurants, and stores! Watch your wallet, ladies! Hihi Just easily check your map to see the direction from Bukchon to Insadong. It's easy to read, don't worry!

The traditional architecture of the old day Korean house were well kept since it was under the World Heritage property. A slow walk up hill will get you amaze with the different design of the house, roof and the wall design. A must visit for 1st time visit to Seoul.

If you want to see the old traditional houses and streets you must visit this. Be aware of some steep streets but worth it. If you follow the route then you will see most of the old houses. Also in some houses there are exhibitions or workshops or you can wear hanbok and take pictures.
This is great to see as part of a day exploring Seoul. However, I would not do this all day or plan a trip around this.
So much on offer, great café scene, hidden Korean eateries and lot's of culture. If you have little (or lot's of) time and like to absorb some the old and new Korean feel, it is the place to go

I've always wanted to see the various styles and it was quite quiet when I visited. The views are also good from the vantage points. Unfortunately I wasn't able to look inside a house but they looked really quaint from the outside.

We love this place , cute buildings old history and design but still nice modern shopping and food outlets , old houses have beautiful timber work , and the old tile roofs are amazing , do yourself a favor and check them out !!

Great to see the traditional houses still in korea  Heard this place is famous as well because alot of the houses are in korean dramas  I must say theres too many people here to even take nice photos tho
Bukchon 8 views are so interesting and worth to take a look. Avoid going there during weekend or holidays as the place will be very crowded.

One of my favorite destinations in Seoul. It was crowded when we were there, but worth our efforts, time. You get to see the old streets and you seem to move back in time. A must see! I would definitely go back there - probably early in the morning.

located between gyeongbokgung palace and changdeokgung palace. it's a unique area where traditional and modern meets. you can either go shopping, eating or just walking and seesighting. most of the store have a chic design make the street looks even more unique and beautiful. very lovely. bukchon have a lot of korean traditional restaurant and also you can't miss the food street. The most popular spot on bukchon is Bukchon Hanok Village, is where you can find korea traditional houses in the middle of Seoul. awesome!

Pretty beautiful area to hang out, and see the different architectures. Don't expect something that'll blow your mind though :) some nice cafés and restaurants. Dedicate easily 1 hour to walk around there.
This is still a residential area, with some cafes and shops. So, not that commercialized like Namsangol Hanok Village. A lot of great photo opportunities.
Beautiful! This is definitely less crowded than Myeongdong. Many interesting and creative shops, workshops and cafes around. Best photo taking spot! Love this place!

Picturesque! A nice tranquil walk in the residential area, i feel like I'm back to the old times. But this tranquil walk can become very annoying if there are few groups of tour surrounding you. Since I'm going there free & easy, I just let them walk in front of me, so that i can have some peaceful walk and some nice pictures.

Bukchon Village was truly incredible and I was able to experience what life used to be years ago. As you visit you're required to speak on a minimal tone of voice to not disturb the people living in the area. Within the village you will be able to find souvenirs made by the locals.

On a sunny day this place is a must. It has been the highlight of our stay in Seoul. Awesome atmosphere very well preserved area gives you a very nice feeling of relaxation and how traditional areas looked like

A quaint little village with a community feel. (now gentrified) The houses are done with tiled roofs and stone in narrow alleys. You could easily spend the whole day walking around here. There are some cute shops, good food, pancakes were yummy, coffee, etc THere are a lot of tourists and locals on weekends. But hey, everybody wants a piece of history to soak in, right? It is also very close to the palaces. We stayed in one of the houses - Hanok style houses and it was easy to explore the area. The family we stayed with were very kind and cheerful people. The room itself was a bit disappointing. We expected a little original (after having stayed in a similar type of house in kaesong, in North Korea) but they seem to have plasticised stuff. So it felt a bit synthetic. There could be other homestays that are possibly in its original state. THere are museums and various tours that you could do. There are also cyclos that take you around the area, highlighting the important landmarks.

Bukchon is a a neighborhood close to the palace. From a very busy street, you take a turn towards Bukchon village and suddenly you are between low rise, old houses in small streets. Many small shops and not the ones that sell the same souvenirs. No, each shop has its own fingerprint. A very nice mix of modern and traditional.
One place that I would hope to visit again someday. It gives a cultural glimpse of the old life in Korea. The houses and streets are clean and quaint.

You can find a map of this area in most places. If you walk up the road next to Changdeokgung Palace you will reach the traditional houses. You can then make your way back down through the area, which has lots of cafes and traditional restaurants. It is between the 2 palaces.

I recommend taking a coffee break there. It is a nice neighborhood with old houses next to the palace. A nice view of the city and lovely houses done like in the old times. Tourists information guys are at the entrances and will offer you an explanation and a map to a self tour with the mail attractions ofbthe neighborhood

walking around this area is so delightful, taking you back in time through the winding streets past the traditional houses. there will be lots of other tourists walking as well, but somehow it is still peaceful as mostly car free. This area is easily accessible and you can combine it with Insadong or the Folk Museum. Take your camera and follow the online TripAdvisor walking tour, or pick up a brochure from the tourist hotel.

although it is a distance (around 1km) from subway and need to walk uphill. It is worth to go there and walk around so you can see the old style houses and feel the culture. scenery up there is nice which you can see folk museum from top view.

If you like traditional architecture, here you would be looking at the traditional houses of Korea, there are even places where they offer lodging korean style. Nice place to visit. There is also the school where they filmed Winter Sonata.
If you wanna know some traditional korean culture, then you can visit here :) You can also try wearing traditional korean costume and have picture taking :)

It's a nice to walk around this neighborhood surrounded by old houses. There are a few small museums you can enter for a small fee. The area is very local with very few tourists roaming around while I was there.

Bukchon offers a blend of old and new. As you wander the streets you will find very traditional Hanok houses and more modern dwellings interspersed with galleries, shops and boutiques. Samcheong-dong Street also offers lots of trendy boutiques and stores and is great for people watching.
Its really nice to walk in this village but it can be crowded becuse it is a tourist place so it well be better if you go early .

A very cultural and interesting to go to.. All the unique designs of the houses and street.. Do visit the place to experience the cultural feel. Will visit again and maybe stay in one of the houses if possible. Wear comfortable shoes as there is a lot of walking to do.
Very nice little alley of traditional houses. Located up the mountains therefore might be tiring to go there with older people.
Visited without staying. If i have a chance again. I will definitely try to the homestay here. It just feels very different and would be nice to experience the korean culture.
A nice and lovely traditional Korean Village! A great surrounding, a lovely area! Nice place for picture taking, go early so you will not have hundreds of tourists in the pictures!

This was a very interesting tour . Some of the old houses are fantastic the streets are narrow and the front doors are a art in themselves . Some of the houses are not so old . People must get annoyed with tourists being there everyday so you can understand way the halls are high and private . Great craftsmanship in some of the buildings . The history of some of them is very interesting . There are a few shops in between like a soap shop jewellery shop and a gift and puppet shop
Its nice to go here on a sunny day when you can walk around and enjoy the beauty of the old buildings. They also have some small unique shops in the area.

Loving this place! Not just the traditional houses, the surrounding area is such a lovely place to visit. I wished that I had stayed in one of the traditional hanok guest houses here, it would have been a good experience.
Walking the streets and looking at all of the old historic houses was really neat. I'm glad I just so happen to stumble across this as I was exploring the city of Seoul.

I was really excited before going but in reality it's just modern versions of old houses in a residential area. Some good cafes and shops in the area but wouldn't go out of my way to go there (I was staying near by).

After a day at the palace take some time to stroll through through Bukchon and get a feel for the seoul of old. Slate roofed houses seemingly built on top of one another on the side of a mountain nestled with restaurants galleries street food....a must see. Through the neighborhood takes you back down towards Insagong were even more treats and sights await. Take it all in!!

Have you ever been to the oldest part in your hometown ? How do you like it ? In Bukchon there are several old-stle houses. And almost all refurbished and in good condition.  So if you are near to Bukchon, just jump in. If not, don't worry.

A long established neighborhood of traditional Korean architecture nestled within site of the modern high rises of Seoul. Visiting Bukchon allows one to experience and appreciated the materials and style of yesterday's Korea. Very nice and upscale shops and galleries are sprinkled throughout the area.
Go in the morning to avoid crowds. Bukchon has beautiful little streets, interesting rooftops, and is worth an hour's visit.

Talk about tradition. If you want to enjoy Korean traditional homes from 500 years ago check this place out its Beautiful you can even go into some of the homes if its possible do it It's a unique opportunity in the heart of a giant city
This old city is amazing nice.....many old buildings with many very nice shops and galleries everywhere
Love this town, its so ancient feel, all the house and doors are so small, short. It feels really peaceful here.

We went here with friends who were living in Seoul at the time. They wanted to show us a contrasting version of downtown Seoul, which is very modern and fast paced. This street was great to see how old Seoul used to be. It was charming and a nice change of pace.  I would recommend visiting if you're in the area. This wasn't close to where we were staying so getting here took some time and you only need about an hour here. This is a very popular spot for pictures amongst tourists and Korean families. Also know that this area is hilly.

This is residential area where most of the houses are still the traditional Hanok houses but since most doors are close you can only get a glimpse of the rooftops and doorways. There are some souvenir or artist shops that are open for tourist but it doesn't really give you the real feel- I guess for that you really need to stay on one those Hanok guest houses .
The place is bit overrated, it's a residential area with bunch of old fashion design houses, not much to see really

the old houses in Bukcon are lovely and unique .  i love those houses, but be prepared to walk up and down hill with good comfort shoes and umbrella during summer.  sometimes, you will notice young girls wearing traditional korea costumes and really impressive and lovely.

place must visit when you travel to Seoul, old style houses and street and friendly local. buddy and i visit this place right after Gyeongbokgung Palace. Collect "maze map" in Bukchon tourist information center before start your long walk (^^,) we spend approximately 2-3hours in this huge place and visit almost all of the attraction in the map. really tiring walk after completion but worth it with the nice windy whether and interesting cultural houses.

Located near Gyeongbokgung Palace.  Wear good walking shoes! The hills can be quite steep.  This is a MUST visit. The area is beautiful and the traditional hanok houses are so interesting to look at and photograph. There were also museums (closed on Mon) and quaint cafes located within the bukchon area.  Go to the Bukchon Traditional Culture Center (9am to 6pm daily) located near Anguk Station Exit 3 to get a walking map 1st.  Bukchon is located in Samcheong-dong which is a very nice area filled with cafes, restaurants, unique shops. You can spend hours walking around this area. One of the nicer shopping areas with cheap pricing in Seoul.
A steep and winding road up a hill. The buildings are old, but only 100 or so years. Gives a bit of an insight about traditional homes, but crowded with tourists and a little over rated.

The amount of legwork required to tour this place took away the enthusiasm that I initially had. It felt like we were traversing a cultural maze that had a small intersection in every turn. It was a constant mind boggling decision as to which direction to take to fully appreciate our visit.  We had no one to tell us where to go and what to do. We just made a quick stop at the tourist information office where we got a map of the village and off we went. Looking back, that was certainly not a great idea. But we were clueless as to the availability of a guide anyway, so we didn't have much of a choice.  The traditional looking houses in the village appeared to have local residents living inside. So practically, this was a peek of the actual traditional Korean village. It was quite an interesting experience, but we got too exhausted to a point that regret surfaced at the end of our walking tour. If you don't mind going for an exercise while on vacation, then this should worth your consideration.

The area is easy to reach although it requires waling up some steep paths to view. The buildings have residents and you can only view them from the outside, most appear to have some sort of restoration, which you would expect if people are expected to inhabit them. It gives you a feel though of what the area was originally like, with tight lanes and small building with strong doors. If you climb up the hills follow the signs to the observatory where you can climb the stairs in a building to the top where you get a view looking down on the area. You are charged 3000won each and get a free tea or fruit juice for every person, well worth the price.
It goes by really fast and you just might miss it. It is almost like walking into a time machine, I had no idea it was one of the top-rated sites to see until I looked it up.

We stayed in a beautiful here knock in the village, and wondered around well in the area. Really enjoyed just exploring the streets, which were surprisingly quiet for a summer day! It's pretty fascinating to see all of the little details you can find on the buildings and doors etc. Several great look out points also to see larger areas of the city or of the village.
We went in the morning and walked around- got some great pictures of our kids in the empty streets surrounded by the cool architecture. We went in April 2014.

I can only advise something ; woke up early to take the best picture of all when practically nobody will disturb you while taking the best shot! Bukchon is one of the best hanok in Seoul and notice the arch and sculpture that each house reflect certainly is an one in a lifetime experience!

This is a nice area to walk through if you have time. Except for one house open to tourists, the rest seem to be private homes which seem to be nice but of which tourists can only have a peek through fences.
This is worth the walk to see the traditional houses and to get a view of the city through the smog. It is a bit confusing but just follow the others and head uphill.

For someone who has never been in Asia, it is impressive. It was the first thing I saw in Korea and it was really nice. Also we were very lucky cause there was a show and they were selling food and things in all the area.

Walked around this whole area from the slightly more modern shopping area and streets and food stalls, to the hanok village which was very quaint and charming (though some uphill bits!) Some great street art too.
Nice area but not a place where i would start off to get to know. Seoul. In that case i would go first to myeong dong area and surroundings

Good for an hour of walkabout as this is not exactly a designated tourism spot, and people are still actually living here although some houses already coverted into Hanoks, so be discreet when wondering around. I am not saying that people are unfriendly but you can be treated as intruders.

Should spend 1-2 hour(s) walking around the village (early in the morning or late in the afternoon will help you stay away from tourists group if you prefer some quiet own time). Then find your way down to Samcheongdong for a tea house experience.

Had a layover in Seoul and since it was already after 6pm we thought this was the best thing to do so we could get a feel of Seoul before heading back to the airport. Saw both temples from the outside and got good photos as the sun set. It was disappointing that none of the art studios were open. I would recommend if you feel like having a wonder around an artsy part of Seoul.
We walked to Bukchon just before sunset and caught great views of Seoul- a mixture of the old traditional buildings and the new ones. Lots of lovely shops, restaurants and photo opportunities

We had limited time to visit a Hanok village away from Seoul and thought of settling for one just right inside Seoul. Took a train to Anguk station, visit the museum, walk pass the palace and reach there in approx 20 mins. It's away from the main street and you need to make a short climb up the steep slopes to visit various photograph spots. Best to visit before sky turns dark. It is a living community with various signs asking to keep noises down.
Cozy houses show the old times of Seoul. Impressive views of the city and you can appreciate the contrast between old Seoul and Modern Seoul. Be prepared to walk, since there are many steep streets.
Lots of shops, restaurants, ice cream and beautiful architecture. A must visit location in Seoul.......

There are good spots for a picture taking, they are numbered and there's a direction to go there, you just have to follow it since it is quite clear. It has a beautiful view on every spot. The traditional houses are unique and so beautiful. Don't forget to wear shoes instead of heels to get through the steep streets. Too bad I came on 7pm so I could not get a good picture, but the view was superb since you can see the Namsan tower and the city lights clearly.
Here i had my usual problem : how can i find it ? At the end i could. As all of tourists . The most photographed street is on the top of the hill .

Its fun to see the Korean traditional houses from outside. But there werent many opportunities to see them from within really. You'd either have to pay for a workshop to get in or something. It wasnt very big either, a little disappointing overall.
Authentic old Seoul, on the hills. Some hipster shops, tasty street food, but not an amusement park at all, meaning it is authentic.

I enjoyed myself a lot just strolling through this village. Its a good contrast to the urban and modern developed part of Seoul. Id recommend this for those who are interested in culture, history and tradition.

Got a map and it shows a lot to explore the entire buchok hanok village! There are hundreds of houses with different designs of roofs, walls, doors, stairs, and if you love the mix of modern ancient architectures, you will love it. Try to enter some houses, there might have display of arts. Feel really like a local! It could take hours to explore, but you need not to visit the entire place! Some houses need a fee to enter.

Bukchon is very atmospheric, featuring many buildings in the traditional hanoak style. But that's the problem -- they're largely just in hanoak style, not actually vintage or historic buildings. In fact, knocking down an old hanoak to replace it with a new building in hanoak style is a common practice. That said, Bukchon is one of the last places in Seoul, maybe the last place, to see a traditional roofscape uninterrupted by multistory modern buildings. Definitely worth visiting for that, as well as some for the specialty shopping, small private museums and independent cafes and restaurants.

Had to come here since a lot of K-dramas are filmed here. Coming from the States and getting a chance to walk where these beautiful homes are was surreal. The day we went they were doing a cosplay photoshoot very nice so we saw Hollywood types following the actress/model.

The Bukchon area is relatively challenging as a climb, and not the most conducive for family travel, if you have children and old folks with you who tend to be very slow or shy away from exercise. Technically, the Bukchon area is accessible from Samcheongdong right at the end of Samcheong-ro, and via a pair of long staircases, you climb up to the top of the hill where you can see these traditional hanok (Korean houses). The area is still inhabited by locals, so you are advised to keep your speaking voice relatively low and quiet when walking around the area, and especially as the day draws to a close, even if you do desire to see the sunset and distant parts of Seoul from an elevation around this Bukchon hanok area, do take care not to scream, shout or talk loudly. This area is arguably one of the few areas in Seoul which still manages to preserve the traditional Korean hanok architecture very well, despite regular tourism.

Bukchon is the location where we had their famous ginseng chicken (a whole spring chicken stuffed with glutinous rice and ginseng). The shop we went to was famous - we got there at nearly 11am and had a seat immediately (after only 15mins wait) , but by the time we finished lunch about 12ish the queue outside the shop stretched more than 500km - the shopkeeper told us it would be a 45 mins wait on average. The local guide with us told us that koreans dont go to this shop - it catered to tourists and an "authentic shop" for koreans were situated just 3 streets away. however, to this tourist's taste, this experience was good enough. Being accustomed to the chinese style of ginseng soup which is of a stronger taste, the korean ginseng chicken experience was quite mild. they give you a small glass of ginseng wine to drink or mix into your soup, which was quite interesting.
Great walking neighborhood with lots of traditional Hanok huts. Near Insadong shopping and dining, palaces.

We loved Bukchon. The whole area is just perfect for spending a day. It is a traditional Korean village. When you're there make sure to visit one of the little stores that has the traditional Korean Hanbok's of the King and Queen. Great souvenir photos. Enjoy!

We did a walking tour of this village. Sort of reminds me of parts of San Francisco, USA. Quaint little streets and shops nestled on the hillsides. A ton of walking so have you most comfortable shoes.

The beautiful houses... the neighbourhood filled with shops... we saw many fruit vendors cruising the street selling things off the back of their trucks... nice first day for us.  The streets are narrow, so be mindful... we also found the Korean drivers to be a little... hmm... aggressive? Stay on your toes as a pedestrian (and buckle up if you're a passenger).  Definitely take a walk through here... and bring your camera.
I got lost moving around this hanok village but it was worth the time. Lovely lines of Korean traditional houses. Next time I come to Korea, I'll definitely stay in a hanok.

to much alley at Bukchon and really confused to found the best alley. so, we try to ask and found the maps to seen the Bukchon alley. there's a couple houses with traditional Korean things, not to much. but I loves it.enjoy the alley with little rainy, so romantic :D
It was a peek into the real Seoul, we were quiet and the neighborhood was most enjoyable. Lovely houses and a nice view from the top of the village.

This was a really nice place to stroll. There is a tourism office that provides maps and the buildings are lovely to take it. There are shops, boutiques and cafes all along the way to make the walk more interesting.  Be sure to stop at the craft center - it is a fun diversion!
Get a feel for a traditional Korean village and home. Narrow streets and alleys so it's easier to walk than drive. Stay in a hanok to get a real flavor of Korean tradition. Great breakfasts!

A village full of 600 year old houses (hanok) within walking distance of Changdeokgung Palace in the midst of urban development is simply amazing.  The house owners are nice to accommodate having thousands of people plying their streets taking gazillions of photos. Especially considering as most of them are quite wealthy being able to afford these prime real estate & heritage houses.  It was nice to walk the various alleyways & just see where the sageuks are filmed.  We took a photo in one of the alleyways overlooking the city & one wearing korean traditional costume & have that as background. It's actually cool.
Such an amazing place with great history. We see Bukchon in Korean dramas and we thought of it as so beautiful. Seeing it in person made our trip worthwhile.

It's obviously not the most authentic traditional village but what do you expect when it's so conveniently located between two of Seoul's most popular palaces? There maybe a few tourists milling about but the streets are still very beautiful and there are numerous cute cafes well worth a stop at. I'd definitely recommend taking the time to explore these tiny side streets to break up your palace sightseeing in Seoul

The Bukchon Hanok Village was a nice place to stroll through. I enjoyed looking at the architecture, but it just seemed like a residential area, so it was a little weird just looking at people's homes. There were a few open doors for museums, craft shops, and restaurant, but not too many. I didn't really know where to go, so we just wandered around, and it was interesting. This by itself is not enough of a draw, but it is at the base of the Bugaksan Mountain, which is definitely worth visiting. So you can go here for an hour in the morning, then take the bus up the mountain, and spend the rest of the day hiking.
Quite and traditional walk in South Korea, we can have a nice half day walk. Don't miss the cafe with waffle and icecream or coffee in afternoon

I highly recommend this Hanuk village. The architecture is tremendous and at residence tells a story of a bygone era. We actually stayed 3 nights in Hanuk accommodation and would visit there in a heartbeat.
Great architecture, beautiful view of Seuol, has some boutique shops that makes it more interesting to rest and catch your breath. Steep climb at times.
However there were a lot of tourists, so you might not be able to take good photos. But anyway, the traditional homes that were there are vibrant and peaceful.
The Bukchon Hanok village was an interesting journey through a collection of traditional wooden houses. The hills make the view of the centre of Seoul. This is a "must do" walk for visitors.

This wasn't my favorite place in Korea. If you're in the area, it's worth the stop to walk through, but don't spend more than 30 minutes here. Most of what there is to see costs (like small art museums only one room big) and isn't worth it (in this artist's opinion). If you're in seoul for a short time, go do something bigger like Myeongdong or Bukhansan instead.

Bukchon is a small traditional area located an easy subway trip from central Seoul. It is famous for the traditional wooden houses that are dotted around the area. It is also the home to the Prime Minister of Korea - although his house is rather more grand.  The area is great for a pleasant stroll so that you can take in the sights and also create some great photos of the old houses with Seoul's rising skyline in the background. There is a small tourist office which provides a free walking map - not the best map in the world admittedly - however it's enough to show you where the main photo opportunities are and enough to get you back on track when you inevitably get lost around the myriad tiny alleyways.
