The area is however quite hilly in parts so perhaps not suitable for all travellers. There are also a couple of palaces nearby although I didn't get the chance to visit - from a distance however they looked impressive.
This is a nice place to take pictures of the old buildings. Go all the way up for the best photo spots! Nice cafes around.

I was taken here by a local work colleague so that I could see the traditional old Korean buildings..I thought they were beautiful and a lovely walk up and down hilly streets. We found some respite from the heat in a tea house which was cool and served the most amazing fruit teas. I could have spent alot more time here..!

Most of the old homes (hanoks) have been restored, and it's fun to walk up and down the neighborhood streets in among the old houses. As you go higher you can sometimes get a peek into the interior courtyards of the buildings. As the day goes by, more and more tourists arrive. This can make for some fun people watching as the tourists pose for pictures among the old buildings. When you reach the top and are done exploring the hanoks, head up the road near the top that borders the neighborhood to the left. Eventually you will come to a staircase on the left that will take you down a winding path to the main street far below. Along the way keep an eye out for the bar/cafe on the left side of the path called "Ontheground". This is a fun place to stop for refreshment and a chat with the friendly owners.

This large area is suitable for slow strolls and lots of picture taking. Make sure to get a pamphlet with the 10? views of Bukchon and get the cameras ready. You can see many traditional styled buildings and alleys. Many of the hanoks can be rented as a house stay for a reasonable price. There are many hanoks converted to restaurants, tea houses, museums, etc... The wall through the views are very hilly. Don't do it in a hot day. At places up high, you can see good views of the surrounding areas and mountains.

This neighborhood is best to visit early in am or late at night, when it is not overrun with tourists and "selfies" . There a few streets, which are highly picturesque with older homes, located between the two palaces. We stayed in a real, legitimate :Hanok here (a Korean style high end B&B)

It is located in a hilly area. Wear a pair of comfortable shoes to walk around. It is like a time travel to see traditional houses first thing in the morning to beat the crowd. Peaceful and beautiful. Worth to visit while in Seoul.

Must visit if interested in traditional Korean architecture. Many excellent, well-preserved private houses (and some B&Bs) in a quiet district for the well-heeled. Nice area to walk around (only marred by noisy tour groups from China sad to say, despite signs saying to please keep noise level down). Stop at Books Cooks for tea (see my review for this cosy joint).
Definitely go see. It's even better during the lotus lantern festival time. The streets and shops are decorated with brightly colored lanterns and there's a celebratory air about the city.
This was one of my favourite places to visit in Seoul. It's very beautiful and special. Gives that older day feel. Definitely a place to see while you are visiting Seoul.
it is a quiet and beautiful street during Winter. There are shops and restaurant in this place. One of the best place during our trip here.
This is a fantastic place for people to visit who want to see a traditional Korean environment without travelling outside of Seoul. Also good for K-Pop fans
It is a street with soul you have to feel it. There is a lot of small restaurants with virtually everything. Nice view from the top of the district.

We went here on our last day and so glad we did. We spent approximately 4 hour strolling through the lane ways and walking into the traditional shops. We found lovely secluded coffee shops along the way which we had some wonderful iced coffee to cool ourselves down. Take some good walking shoes as climbing the hills is a must. You get to look down on the traditional roofs. If you follow the signs they will lead you to where you can obtain a map which marks out the walking routes to follow. Of course we got totally lost and went our own way but that is half the fun! Again there are more shops and some that specialised in arts and crafts. One of the highlights of our trip.
Bukchon Village with winding streets, traditional building, shops and restaurants is a nice place to spend couple of hours wondering around. If you have an extra time it is worth seeing.

This place of interest has many narrow walkway uphill and downhill where you can see the house from previous Seoul era. Many of them has classical outlook, bamboo, wood, traditional roof tiles. They are not just for viewing, these are actual houses where local are still living in it. At here, time has rewind, back to the olden days. You will forget that you are in a busy metropolitan, as if you are still in the classical era.  https://vinshengloh.exposure.co/butcheon-traditional-village

the place shows how life in korea was before all the modernization came about, beautiful houses some converted to become inns and restaurants/cafes. a definite must go to place for the arts and culture buff
It is, really, a piece of history lost in time. But ancient houses are scarse, not so well maintained. Other regions, around the palaces, exhibit same architecture.
Very scenic area with the traditional hanoks and great photography time. Nice strolls up and down the allies finding little hidden surprises.
Bukchon is a nice cultural place. Beautiful and quiet place for a stroll. The scenery there are priceless and to understand more of their traditional cultures there too.

It’s nice if you visit early mornings otherwise this place swell by noon time with large crowd of Camera touting tourist from all over the world !! Wonderful Traditional Houses You must look out for the Old Quiant corner where you find traditional simple food is being served !! Delicious
Good eats...if you sneak up into small alleys...sweet people...cool stuff to see. Shop for jewelry or clothes...or enjoy a romantic cup of coffee

If you happen to be in the area, especially the Gyeongbokgung Palace and/or Changdeokgung Palace, this place should be on your to visit list. This would be my second visit, the first time was during the day and the second time was at night.  Samcheong-dong is near to Gyeongbokgung Palace and is relatively near to Cheong Wa Dae (the Blue House a.k.a the President’s Office) and Insadong; both of which are tourist spots worth to visit. To get there just alight at the some subway station stop (Anguk Station, Subway Line No. 3) for Gyeongbokgung Palace.  Just follow the signs and you will find yourself at Samcheong-dong, one of the most unique places in Seoul where there is the hanok (traditional house made out of wood and put together without any nails) Bukchon Village. Samcheong-dong is a beautiful neighborhood and will definitely take more than half a day to take in the sights.  As it was evening time, there were many students on their way home after school and the crowd was lessened as compared to the last time I was there. It was literally an uphill task… it’s a hilly area with pretty steep slopes. We passed by a couple of familiar shops, but the night setting gave the area a slightly different feel and made it even more of an adventure.  Walking through the neighborhood peppered with both the traditional and modern is an enjoyable activity: some hanoks are occupied by residents while some are into chic galleries, restaurants, cafés and accessory shops.  And while you are here, don't forget to eat the yummy street food!  For more on my experience and photos, please check out my blog: http://www.travelbytez.com/2013/09/samcheong-dong-bukchon-village-food.html  and  http://www.travelbytez.com/2015/05/bukchon-village-at-night.html
This place is good for sightseeing and cafe hopping. It's quiet along the routes within the residential areas but nothing spectacular. Nice to have a walk around but not a must to go.
We only explore this old part of the city in our recent trip. Close to the palaces, museums, presidential house, and, importantly, gorgeous mountains, small shops and eateries are fun and enjoyable.

Explored around the traditional Bukchon Hanok homes area today. The area is surrounded by Gyeongbokgung Palace, Changdeokgung Palace and Jongmyo Shrine,and is home to hundreds of traditional houses that date back to the Joseon Dynasty. Very colorful neighborhoods and many of these hanoks operate as coffee shops, cultural centers, guesthouses, restaurants and tea houses. After exiting the subway at anjuk, just look for the Hyundai HQ and head up the hill. So much to see.

It was a very nice tour to experience the old style Korean houses. They have it's own style and are beautiful. The place is unique, quiet & clean. Please be considered to keep quiet when we visit there as there are people living in the houses.

It's pretty nice to see the traditional Korean homes, but asides from that this place was kind of boring. A lot of the houses are occupied with real tenants so you can't really explore any of them unless you book a room at one through airbnb.

This village is close to the two biggest palaces, so it's convinient to combine visits together. As many other areas in Seoul, this one is hilly, so prepare for climbing. Not many activities except looking at the traditional houses. Anyway, worth checking it out to grasp the atmosphere of many-faced Seoul.
Its a place where you can see a korean traditional village. Check out the local house. Dont forget to visit the gift store where you can get the kpop merchandise.
this village is located in the city and can see lots of students do their activities here ..nice view ...

"Seoul City Walking Tours" is a free program offered by the city of Seoul designed for tourists who want to see Seoul’s top tourist attractions on foot under the expert guidance of multilingual tour guides. Reservations for this program can be made via the internet and mobile web at www.visitseoul.net. No tipping is necessary.  We took a free City tour of these villages and it was great!! Our guide new all the alleyways and which paths to take to see the best sights and views. She also gave us much more info on the area and history that we would not have gotten if we had walked this area on our own.  I highly recommend booking a guide with visit Seoul! The Bukchon village is not to be missed!! It gives you a glimpse into traditional Korean living.

Taking a walk through the traditional village of Bukchon was a great experience. This isolated area of Seoul was a pleasant surprise in contrast to the rest of of the city that is fast-paced and busy. It was good to see that some of the tradition of Korea had been preserved, although it is just a small area. I would recommend a visit to this area.

Going here, Chungmuro station then exit 3. It's the 2nd block from the exit, after Korea House.  There's no admission ticket. I guess its because of the cultural week. The traditional houses/rooms and cook ware was well maintained. Upon the entrance, there were men who's on cultural outfit, who were weaving traditional baskets, shoes and etc.  There was even a traditional wedding held yesterday. The bride and groom's attire was really beautiful.  Even the traditional bed and pillows were well maintained.  It was a very good experience of traditional korean life. N Seoul Tower is near the area through NAMSAN TOUR bus.

Bukchon Hanok Village has old traditional houses that people actually live in. It is a good daytime walk; actually can be a little crowded with Korean couples on a nice weekend afternoon. Hilly and some decent views of the downtown. You can also arrange an overnight stay there, and Bukchon becomes considerably quieter and more peaceful once the couples depart during the evening hours.  The houses here are unique and definitely Korean. Most of them are remodels and a bit dressed up, but as a tourist you probably wouldn't realize that. Try to find a map which shows the recommended walking path to ensure that you don't miss anything worth seeing.
Had to walk a while to get to the top/ But the view was well worth it. Had a few cafes at the top which was nice. Nice to see the culture and old style buildings
Good place for walking, sightseeing and shooting photo. Near anguk station, can spend a lot of time there then visit the Gyeongbokgung palace.

This place is amazing, its located on a small hill. All the houses have big and cool doors. The funny thing is that this area looks like its been more than 100 years old, but some doors have very modern high tech locks. Most house are locked and these people dont want any disturbance. Only one house was open for public to enter and take a look. Very nice view when you walk to the top. Youtube - lolsia2000

Take a stroll down the lane to see the traditional houses. Many with home grown flowers/ plants and the great exterior. You will see many people walking the same path. It's linked to Samcheong area so enjoy a good cuppa after that.

It is a living history in the middle f a modern city. The architecture is pretty different than the ones can be seen in Europe or North America. Small houses attached to each other creates a cozy feeling. Such a peaceful area. There are also small guesthouses in this area where you can stay and enjoy the traditional Korean hospitality but you must book well in advance.
Bukchon is much like the palaces, not really old just remodeled. There are actually fine examples of old homes located in the neighborhood surrounding Bukchon.
great little artisan shops and cultural treasure activities where you can pay a small fee to make a mirror or paper mache box

On arrival at Anguk subway station we were met by an old man with a walking stick who insisted in showing us correct exit to see the village (exit 3) - such an act of kindness.  Bukchon is beautiful, the streets quaint and is really is all you expect it to be. It's busy, it's beautiful - it's great and can't imagine a trip to Seoul without visiting here.  This is not a stop on the hop on hop off, so you will have to make your own way here, but it's easy to find.
It's really a beautiful place, it would've been better if the tourists could keep their volumes down.
Bukchon Hanok Village is home to hundreds of traditional houses called 'hanok' that date back to the Joseon Dynasty.

While very crowded with tourists the village is worthwhile visiting. Friendly city guides give you information about how to walk and give you directions. It's a walk mostly uphill and then you can get a nice view over the lovely old rooftops! On our way back between Insadong and the Lotte department store area we visited the beautiful Buddhist Jogyesa temple!
I liked the small area..you can see the old korean houses..old doors but it's a small area you can finish it in 30 min max but it worths visiting

A quiet place to get away from Gangnam and Myeongdong. Nice, older style houses and some good cafes to relax.  There isn't much there, but if you just need an hour or 2 of walking and enjoying architecture, it's a good place.  It would be nice if they had some more information about the history of the area interspersed among the walking paths, but I guess that's why they have Google.

We stayed 3 nights in the Bukchon area and enjoyed the experience except for the uncomfortable sleeping arrangements in our traditional guesthouse. Young people would be fine, but as an older adult, the thin mats on a hard floor made for very long nights. We joked that the Koreans work such long hours ever day, because lazing around in bed would be too miserable. However, we ate at many delicious small restaurants, trying different kinds of food at each meal, toured palaces and wandered the streets just looking at houses and in shops.

such a fantastic cute little traditional village in the city. the traditional houses, streets and culture is well preserved. There are nice museums and workshops that you can attend in the village. I would suggest that you go to the visitor centre at the bottom of the village and get a map so you know where to go. surely not to be missed when in seoul.
Lively, but not overcrowded. Lots of little shops and restaurants, good atmosphere. Try to sneak in some little back alleys and enjoy the non commercial side of the village.

Thoroughly enjoyed wandering around the neighbourhood, with its traditional korean wooden houses, some original, others restored. Most of old seoul was destroyed either by the japanese or by the civil war somthis gives youna glimpse what seoul must have looked like. Take a map from the tourist office or the information guides posted around the area to help you navigate your way around.

Village gives you a sense of traditional living in Korea. Beautiful views, picturesque houses, try to see a small museum-house. Many thanks to Michael Kim (ultimatekoreatour@gmail.com) from UltimateKoreaTour for bringing us to the Village.
This place is so picturesque! I highly recommend going to the visitor center first to pick up a map so that u would know where to go!

Strolling through the streets of this historic and well-preserved village will simply pull at your nostalgic heartstrings. I mostly followed the recommended walking course, since it is a residential area, but took a few little twists and turns along the way to get out of the crowded zones. It was really crowded when I went, but that may have been due to it being a national holiday. It was fun to see all of the intricate details that go into each of the hanoks, right down to the locks on the window covers. If you go early enough, you'll be able to participate in some of the craft-making options available. There's a whole area dedicated to traditional crafts up at the top of the hill. Check the map you can get at the information center near the start of the journey for details!

Bukchon is amazing, because it isn't an artificial, touristy fake historical village - it is a real, vibrant neighborhood with homes, cool shops, coffee houses, craftsmen, and B&B's all using the traditional 'hanok' houses. It can get pretty busy with visitors on a nice day (which makes it hard to get good photos), but it is definitely worth a visit. To put it in perspective, Seoul is a city of 23 million, and packed into one of the highest densities on the planet. And yet they have managed to preserve this neighborhood right in the center of the city - imagine a 18th century neighborhood preserved in the center of Manhattan!

I have been here for 3 times.. but i never been bored.. this place is so cozy and feels like home.. you stop at anguk station and exit 6 after you exit you strait ahead and turn right at bukchon ilga 12 enjoy your trip..

unique and feel like back to the old day. Nice view from nice houses. Tourist map is help to find what to see and where to start. Must come early (start 10 am) so will have more time to walk up and down. Nice decoration in some house and nice wall painting in some area.

It was very accessible, though you need to walk for a few minutes. As of the houses we had seen, mostly were already restored, but still impressive. Or maybe we were just not able to see the much older ones. But we happen to stumbled upon some shooting near the Winter Sonata drama location. I just cant tell if it was for a commercial or drama or movie, and I didnt knew the actors. But goodlooking, though. :)
I was quite impress with the design. took tons of photos there. U can try on Korean traditional clothes here and snap a shoot. or maybe more than one ;)
As a huge Korean drama fan I expected more from this, but it was just ok. Very crowded on a Saturday , lots of coffee shops, and fancy souvenirs.
I love this place! Very traditional neighbourhood. Nice local artist, restaurants, houses... This is the place i like most in Seoul area.

The traditional homes here are still lived in and this is an active neighborhood. The narrow serpentine streets are very fun to wander. with many great views, the most famous is the view of the far off Namsan Tower. I really loved walking to th e top of the village and walking along Bokchon-ro-15 gil This is a road that is perched atop a high cliff/wall with great views toward Samcheong-dong and Palpan-dong, you can also get a glimpse of Gwangbokgung Palace. A great day on foot, wear comfortable shoes as some of the hills are steep.

Before this traditional housing village is banned from public access, you must go to see and walk through one of the last well preserved traditional housing areas in S Korea. There are traditional items being made with lots of cool shops and boutiques.

Quite impressed with the old Korean village, arts and crafts places in the village. Great place to stroll around and experience old Korea. However, this place is becoming a bit touristy and in spite of the signs to keep quiet it is rather difficult to control an excited crowd.
Good place to walk around.More easier if you use Seoul Walking Guide service (It's great and it's free!) so you don't have to wonder around the big area.
Stop at the tourist info center to get a detailed map of Bukchon district. Nicely restored homes and some very nice shops.

By walking through the alleyways of the Buckchon, one can only see, to appreciate it. It is best experienced and appreciated by staying in one of the hanoks in the Bukchon village. There is limited accomodation though. Then, one can experience the interior feel of residing in one of them, even if it is for a night. However, please don't bring your whole suitcase because there wont be enough space for that & dragging the suitcase will be tough in the confusing alleyways. An over-nighter bag will do. Then, one can experience the quiet & peacefulness of the village as the sun sets and enjoy meals sitting cross legged on the heated floor. It is an experience. Walking through the alley gives you photos to take-away but staying there is an experience no one can take from you.

Most associtate Bukchon with traditional houses amidst modernity. A bit more exploration and we went into Samcheong Park which extended upwards to the fortress wall over the city. I heard a lady's voice, singing operatic style from an unknown spot. Excellent place to exercise one's lungs & skills. On a good day, one could see over the city and beyond. Apparently we could join into Waryong Park but it was past closing time. Another time perhaps.

there were many many hanok houses here. And they said the government preserved it so that no one would be allowed to destroy any of their old houses or commercial companies buy the lands and destroy the houses. lovely neighborhood.

There are many boutique shops,and small restaurants, narrow side streets,there is one of places to see old traditional Korean buildings,in spite that there are many people strolling there amazing cleanness everywhere.

It's a quiet place with loads of old Korean houses and winding lanes weaving around. You may find couple volunteers in those lanes for directions and information. They also keep remind visitors to be quiet since it's a residential area.  Please respect the locals. Don't speak too loud while visiting.

Bukchon was the first place I went to visit in Seoul, great place to walk around and see the traditional housing. Nice window shopping and cute cafes. At the tourist info you can pick up a great map which plans out a 1-2hour walking tour covering the highlights.
beautiful road and houses lining the street. leads to samcheongdong .. where you can visit the nice cozy cafes!

Rows & rows of traditional Hanok houses weaving through many lanes.Very peaceful & beautiful.  It brings one back to nostalgia, that in a modern city like Seoul; one can still see the tradition being preserved by these Hanoks.  A must see when in Seoul.

We walked this historic district with a native Korean who regaled us with stories of her childhood in Seoul. This is now over touristy, but still worth the visit to see beautiful homes and some great views from the heights over Seoul. We really enjoyed it and will likely do again.
Enter this village via free tour guides from Seoul tourism website. Brings you to nice points you will not visit or think of in the village.
How nice to wander in the narrow streets of Bukchon, with their numerous little craft shops. Rather touristic of course, but some views on the old hanoks with their tiled roofs are simply fabulous,
There are some small shops and cafes along the walk. A good and pleasant experience.

They seem to be bugged enormously by the deluge of tourists visiting, and I can well believe it. We more there on a rainy day in early April and it was maybe not stampeded, but crowded enough -so imagine what it must be like on a fine day in the season. Please keep quiet! That said, it's nice. Not the kitschy fake you might expect, really authentic. Nice and well worth an extended walking tour.
Narrow streets, peaceful neighborhood would be the one to welcome you. Love the intricate details of each houses. I will definitely go back and immerse myself with this locals.

When in Korea. When in Seoul. Bukchon is a must. Traditional homes mixed with modern restaurants and shops. Take a half day and stroll the lanes and roads. Enjoy a coffee or meal at one of the many local places. Friendly locals and tourists

When I travel I always appreciate finding historic districts. Bukchon is an old neighborhood made up of mostly classic style Korean homes. You can meander down and around small alleys and there are surprises along the way. I was lucky enough to have a sweet snack being cooked in the doorway of an older man's home. Not sure what it was, but it was like a carmel cookie. Very yummy! The other good thing is that it is an easy walk from Bukchon to the Palace so if you like to walk, you can see a lot in an afternoon.

This is a wonderful walking tour of an area of Seoul that had been somewhat preserved. People still live here and there are signs everywhere asking to respect their privacy. Stop at the Bunchok information center first to get a map of the area then hit the streets with your camera. A wonderful flash from the past. Great views of traditional Korean rooftops.
Nice place to stroll around. It shows some of the Korean history. It is worth having a look around - you get away from all the busy streets of the city. On a nice sunny day you can get great photos.

They houses were great to see. Very traditional and very nice.  I found myself getting disorientated a bit but there are many info centers around that can help set you straight. The maps are good and in English and the street signs also have English.  Cute shops and some nice street food.

The main commercial thoroughfare in Bukchon has a ton of adorable shops, stores and coffee places. It's also immediately quieter from the 6 lane streets, so you can easily wander and window shop. I also loved the residential area of Bukchon but because it's a populated residential area, it is a bit awkward to be wandering with packs of other tourists around people's homes. There are a lot of signs up asking people to be respectful, and the residential area is technically only open until sundown - but most streets I turned down had several dozen people on them. It's hard to keep several dozen tourists quiet. You won't be able to wander and absorb the feel of the place easily so I'd recommend checking it out briefly and then heading back to the more commercial area to explore some intriguing alleys and shops.
For photographer and walker. I like this place. Very quiet at day and night. There is one place 'Garage coffee', roof terrace with nice view, draft beer and foreign waitress.

this is probably my favorite place in Seoul, as I went there twice in my one week of stay! you feel like you've traveled back through time and every street corner is perfect to capture some great pictures! there's also many shops and coffee places that are tucked in the little streets, it's a nice escape if you want some quiet time and walk around the old housing and tea houses- it's truly a beautiful area to visit!
one of the best places in Seoul to visit on a lazy afternoon durin winter.If you're into nostalgic and quaint-stuff, then Bukchon Village is the ideal place to visit.

A very unique experience in this place, spent half a day strolling in the alleys, observing Korean traditional houses and take a lot of photos in the process. Made our presence as quiet as possible to avoid causing disturbance for the local residents as we saw reminders on the wall.
Authentic village Seoul, with wooden houses, great view to city. You must keep silence, staff on the streets help tourists.
Despite the swarm of tourists, this is a charming area to wander and where one can experience what Seoul was like before the high rises arrived.

Visited this in July 2014. Started off from the tourist center at Bukchon. Took off on its suggested route. It is a beautiful neighbourhood. There are Tourist Helpers along the route who can speak English, Chinese and Japanese to guide the visitors. Lots to see around the neighbourhood with shops, eateries, places of interests.

We enjoyed a nice walk through this neighborhood and took many photos. Although is was packed for the Lunar New Year, we managed to escape the crowd by leaving the main path.  Great area to see how the people used to live. May photo opportunities.  Grab a map from the small tourist stalls in the area. They suggest different kind of walks and good explanations.

Get lost in the side streets and explore. The higher you go the more you can see. Narrow streets that overlook the city below. Worth hiking up the hills for a unique perspective of the architecture.  very touristy with lots of popup shops. Some homes open for a fee. I heard one say 800 won each just to go inside and look, no thanks, found a free one around the corner.  Take your time and get lost. You'll find your way back eventually.
I like those charms of traditional Korean houses and the simplicity of beauty. It was a sunny day in winter, all wonderful scenes.
The architecture is beautiful in this historic area and you really get a sense for what the city might have felt like a few hundred years ago. It was really neat.

Hanbok is the traditional Korean dress with vibrant colours. To try on it, you have to pay 7000 won including entry fee. Nice place to have fun and feeling Korean traditional culture there. You should try!

Bukchon is a lovely area, well worth exploring. Old-school Korean architecture and lots of independent cafes and restaurants serving authentic Korean cuisine. Also art galleries and shopping. Not to be missed.

Bukchon is one of the most delightful areas in Seoul to spend and hour or two comparing old Korean hanoks(not so many of them as more are being renovated every year) as they were originally built with beautifully renovated hanock for today's modern living. It is both interesting and informative to see how the modelling of these houses are enhanced with the use of pale wood panelling and modern fittings. Some hanok owners are offering home stay experiences, well worth a visit if not one or two night's stay!

Just like some of parts of Tokyo, I love the low rise, old neighbourhoods that have been renovated but have kept the charm of an Old Seoul Village. It's walkable, and a lovely combination of the old with new shops and cafés. Charming!

I went there very early in the morning thinking that there would be less people and easy to get around. I was right! It can be a bit difficult to find your way and manage to see everything, but there are maps and dirrections to help you. Even if it is a turistic area, people live there, so try to keep your voice down a bit!(just a small advice)
A nice place to visit. There are many Korean style houses which are in good condition.
It was nice to walk through an old neighborhood. So much of Korea has been modernized that it is nice to imagine what it would have been like.
Great way to spend an afternoon. Great for strolling and exploring. You can pick up a map with a suggested route at the tourist office at the foot of the neighborhood if you like.

Great area with very old architecture beside very new buildings. Great little shops with a focus on creativity and arts and crafts. Great walking around with some cardio up those hills (but then you can go down, too). Definitely a spot to go while in modern Seoul for a taste of the past.
See and take photos in this traditional hanok village in seoul. Takes a lot of walking uphill though but it's all worth it.

This is a good experience to see traditional Korean housing without leaving Seoul, but it's crammed with tourists like everywhere in Korea. However the buildings are cute and it's a nice place to spend an afternoon with good weather.  If on a limited schedule and you can't make it to Gyeongju check this out instead.

Bukchon is like a living museum, right in the middle of the city and within walking distance from the main tourist attractions in Seoul, namely Gyeongbokgung, Insadong and Gwanghwamun Square. Having said that, there are people living in the well-preserved village. Unfortunately, tourists did not think about that fact when they shouted at each other like it was an area full of residential buildings and nothing else. Because of this, there are signboards seeking tourists to keep their voices down which seemed to be ignored.  It was nice to get lost in the village but it does not hurt to get a copy of the map from the tourist information counter at the beginning of the road.  There are a plenty of hanok villages in Seoul alone. This is probably the most popular one due to its location and wonderful hilly view with photo opportunity spots you may find along the way.

Defiantly worth to visit to bukchon if you want to feel true atmosphere of Korea , especially traditional village is very lovely , gotta walk a bit but there is signage on the street in English and there is even a tourist information office to assist you when you lost your way , you can spend the whole day wondering around the area ,this is one of the best place we visited in Seoul ! If you are the type who appreciates and like to experience local attractions Bukchon is the place to visit in Seoul

I've visited Bukchon with my mom in one of the coldest winter day, but it was definitely worth all the chills! Its a must see sight if you are interested in Korean traditional culture and its old architecture style. Theres a free cultural museum/gallery along the hike so make sure to stop by and take a peek. (They sell souvenirs like postcards and magnets in there, too.) Last but not least, small tip for Catholics who visit Bukchon - Theres a cathedral nearby called Gahoe-dong Catholic Church, which is a historical place for the Catholic Church of Korea. The cathedral itself is a mixture of Korean Hanok and Western-style architecture which is worth a visit.

Its interesting to see the old style of housing and the juxtaposition of the old and new architecture in the area. We also went to the Bukchon Traditional Crafts Experience Center there and had fun doing crafts.

Located in Insa-Dong, Bukchon Hanok village is easily one of the best places we visited in Seoul. The ancient traditional Korean houses are beautiful. People still live there although commercialization has taken place where houses have been sold to be converted into shops, restaurants and cafes.  We patronised one of the cafes, not just to have a coffee break, but also to experience a hanok. We were given a room where we had to sit on the floor round a low table. The architecture is interesting and the sliding doors similar to traditional Japanese houses. The view from the balcony overlooking the village was really awesome. (The café was located at the top of the hill.)  If you are the type who appreciates and like to experience local attractions, Bukchon is the place to visit in Seoul. In fact, the entire Insa-Dong district is lovely with its Korean-themed shops that sell wares different from what you normally get at mall and even Myeong-Dong.
I LOVED THIS PLACE. You can spend the whole day wandering around this area. Traditional design buildings and cute indie craft shops and cafes a genuinely beautiful part of the city

This place is beautiful, gotta walk abit but there's signage on the streets in English. There's even a tourist information office to assist you when you lost your way. It's definitely worth the walk up the slope. A nice place to look around and take a stroll.
Definitely worthy to visit to Bukchon if you want to feel the true atmosphere of Korea. Especially the traditional vileage is very lovely.
Easy to find.. stop at anguk exit 2 so cool place and i miss to get back here next year.. many hand made store that i love the moat of Korea

The streets of Bukchon are lined with many hanoks or Korean traditional houses. These hanoks are protected against modern development so you can see and feel the aura of old-style Korea. As the place is situated on the mountain, it is rather steep and hilly so do be careful when walking around the place. The hanoks are privately-owned so people still live there. Due to that, there are many signs along the way reminding tourists to be quiet as so to mantain peace and quietness of the place. The main street of Bukchon has many hanok-styled cafes where you can grab a cup of coffee whilst soaking up the atmosphere. If you get lost, fret not because there are many tourist information staffs around the place and they'd be happy to give you directions or answer any of your questions.

We were here by Nov 2014 after we visited Changdekgong. We saw many unique and magnificent Hanok houses. Most of the Hanok had changed to guesthouse. It's good attraction to know these traditional Korean people living places. Also we can saw some wall paintings with beautiful picture, very cute and special.

This would have received five stars had we not visited similar areas in Jeonjo and near Andong. Nonetheless, it was a treat to see these traditional structures preserved and to wander about. Interesting cultural center with excellent maps. I think I would have really enjoyed the culture/art making classes at the center if had had more time or in warmer weather!

It is a great place to appreciate Korean archtectural beauty and functionality. It is also interesting to see how people actually live in these traditional structure with modern improvement.  It is hilly but worth the cardio. There are several work shops you can vist and learn some of traditional craft. It is also close to the major touristic spots (e.g., palace or Insadong or the temple).

Its really worth a pay to visit. I enjoyed walking around the area and seeing the architectural aspects of the houses and how the entire alleys are meticulously planned. Its a good example of having the old and the new.

Seoul's Bukchon Hanok Village is a traditional Korean village with a long history located not too far from the Gyeongbok Palace and Changdeok Palace and is well worth a few hours to explore and take in the culture. The traditional village is composed of lots of alleys, "hanok", and is preserved to show a 600-year-old urban environment, but it is a residential area with people living in the traditional wooden and stone houses and so you need to respect that when you walk around the hanok.  As well as the lovely architecture of the traditional homes there are plenty of shops, craft centres drinking and eating places to spend your time exploring. Pick up a map from the tourist information office as you enter the Bukchon Hanok area as this I found was a great help in navigating my way around the narrow streets. It was very popular and very busy with tourists so expect to be one of many as you walk this fabulous historic district. It is rather steep walking in places so probably not suitable for those in wheelchairs or those whom are not in great fitness.

quite boring. shops and restaurants, not much really. But! there is a free shuttle bus right at the turn where the main palace Geongbukgong and the Hyundai art gallery. There is free shuttle bus service in front of the Hyundai gallery thatvtakes you to Sam Cheng Geok, a beautiful traditional Korean residence preserved on the hills with fresh air and trails. Kuch is delicious there at the Sam Cheng Geuk but pricey.

Its a series of well-preserved village houses with some nice views at the top. Be prepared for some steep climbs along some parts of the route though. There is a tourist information office along the way so go in if you have to and get your necessary directions from inside. We took about 2 hours for the walk at a casual pace.
Do TaKe a walking trip in Bukchon. There is a tourist information booth where you can get a map for a walking tour! You might not find all routes and photospots without it.
A must see if you like to see traditional architectural homes. Need walking shoes since it is a nice area to see the sights.

Walking in Bokchon and admiring the Hanok was one of the best experiences we had in Seoul. We visited all the 8 scenery and couldn't understand why some people advised travelers to start from scenery 3. They are all so unique and beautiful.

Went there on our last day in Seoul. It was very cold but we were so glad that we managed to squeeze this itinerary in. This is just a small village but as we were rushing for time, we didn't managed to visit the Traditional Culture Centre and probably covered only about 60% of the village alleys / streets. Definitely worth a return trip.  I really enjoyed admiring the well preserved and maintained traditional houses in the area. Some streets are filled with quaint looking little cafes (unfortunately they were mostly closed, even at 11am) and various souvenir / handicraft shops. We bought some hand-painted ceramic paintings and art prints in some of the shops there.  A friend gave me a Buchon Walking Map. Not sure where she got it from, perhaps the Tourist Info Centre or the Culture Centre. You can use the map to guide you around the alleyway, focusing on your area of interest.  Do take note though that some streets are very steep, and in winter, it can get really tricky, to manage the slippery streets (due to the melting snow). My kids and I came upon this section near the top of the hill, where the street was extremely slippery. We met a group of tourists there and a few of them almost slipped, while trying to navigate up the hilly road.

We just visited the Bukchon Village last week (10/Dec) and we loved it. As we went on a weekday afternoon, the place was quite deserted and peaceful. Moreover it is chilly and nice weather for a stroll around the place taking plenty of photos.. haha.. We had a nice time moving around at a leisurely pace just getting the vibe and feel of the whole place. However in order to fully enjoy this place (in my opinion), you need to be relaxed and really like looking at the different structure of the Hanoks. We were on our own Free & Easy trip so we had no time restrictions... haha.. and go on a weekday, it seems alot of ppl will visit over the weekends... I feel sorry for the residents there over the weekends with all the crowd... Anyway be prepared to walk around and take photos...  Getting there is easy: take the Line 3 to Anguk station and exit @ Exit 2. Just go straight for about 300m and there is an information booth. Take a map and walking guide and just follow the "suggested" route.. haha..  Have fun...

I am so glad I made the trip out here. Easy to get to via subway with just a short walk. As I made my way through the windy streets I really enjoyed the care that people take to keep the streets and homes so well maintained. There are a lot of little alleys to explore and still stay oriented to where you are.  Stop by the visitor office if you care to get a quick map to help navigate the streets.

Freezing cold to walk around the village. There were some houses open for visitors to look around to get a feel of the history of the place. But other than that, I did not quite enjoy it. We were lucky we were with a private tour company that had local guides who knew how to bring us to the top of a church that had a birds eye view of the village. That was the highlight of a rather dull place. Hmmmm.... nothing else to talk about it really.....

Many traditional houses in use. And also many well-interiored shops and cafes there. Chosun dynasty is living in the very modern city, Seoul. Old royal palace and other hot points are in walking distance.
after few days shopping with friends. I enjoyed my last day in Seoul by walk around Bukchon in the morning, with coffee and dessert, nice and quiet. Nice place to take pictures.
Like the fact that it's free of charge.. and we can wear hanbok with a mere 3 dollars rent price.. picture taken in traditional house OMG I felt like in a movie...
How s d place to explore it in the winters ?Please suggest as its too chill outside ...Reviews are tempting me to visit d place

I love all the buildings and the view. Historic and amazing experiences. Tourists have to be quiet and walk slowly because of the signboards hung all over the wall that required us to be quiet as the historic and classic buildings are housing areas.
If you want to traditional houses, here is the best place. And it is also very near Insadong and Samchungdong where traditional couveniers and luxury boutique shops are located in.

The area has lots of beautiful housing that one rarely has the opportunity to see elsewhere. Most are distinct with its own character and all are beautifully designed and decorated. There were signs reminding people to keep their volume down especially from the evening onwards out of consideration for the residents. Many quaint shops and cafes in the area too. However, there are many stairs and steep slopes which might make it difficult for some.
there is really nice place!. wonderful traditional village!

Nice walk around the neighbourhood. You can see old style houses and visit some sites in the area. Get the map from the visitor centre on the main road. It's not recommended for people who cannot walk for long as there is a lot of uphill walking. We struggled to push our child's stroller. Lots of cafes and eateries at Samcheongdong and in the neighbourhood.

I've been here a couple of times and each time I was underwhelmed. The last time I visited I brought a friend who was passing through Korea, to say he was unimpressed is an understatement. It's a real shame that this area is not more interesting. It is a historic area but it feels very manufactured and sterile. You do not get the impression this is what Korea used to be like. Couple this manufactured feel with the huge crowds and it's just not a great place to visit. If I didn't live in Seoul, I probably would not have visited here. If you don't have much time to spend in Seoul, I would go other places.
really enjoyed this neighborhood. Definitely worth seeing and walking around. A Must see in my opinion.
(+) This is a village with traditional Korean houses with people still living in them so it's like a living museum.

Walking through the streets of Bukchon make you feel like you're walking through the past. It's a nice place capture the essense of the old wooden house community. Even if commercial stores have occupied some of these houses along the roads, you can still see some odd shops like a hat making shop, a tailoring shop, an old style barber shop, where the owners themselves are still making the crafts themselves. It is also nice to turn into the small alleys and see the locals going on with their daily chores.

The Bukchon village is a residential area and while we go around walking about the rows and rows of well-preserved (if not, designed & constructed) hanok style houses, we were reminded to keep noise at a minimum in order not to disturb the families that live there. You don't want a tourist peering into your house, do you? Enjoy the sights and photograph all you want but give respect to the privacy of families that reside there. We descended at Samcheondong for some food and drinks and to rest our legs.

This is a very interesting part of the city. It is like a city within a city and most of the homes are preserved with the old ways of building. Lots of shopping too! Make sure you have comfy shoes on for this tour!
This place is so cozy.. many cafe many unique store.. old houses arround you.. you can spent whole day here.. i sure you no regret to come here.. i will gonna miss this place..

Must visit if you have time, its an uphill and traditional korean housing area, very nice , tidy and clean, lots of houses to take photos with and coffee strips just below the hill. you can get maps from nearby volunteer staffs or tourism board staffs they will guide you around the place with markings on the map. Yes its in korean words but its not too bad with the map. there's an observatory somewhere around the area, where you can have a clearer look and a taste of entering traditional korean housing.

It was a very nice day when we went to Bukchon. Walking around w/ a map, while eating some red-bean manjoos, everything was going so very well. That is... Until my friends saw that we had to hike a bit to get to some of the other areas. The place was very nice and there's a tour, but you had to pay for it - We opted to go around the place on our own. The houses were very pretty and around the place, there are shops! There was one which sold little succulents and another one which sold clothes. The most interesting one is the quaint store that sold pen drawings! The details were amazing and it's done by just one person! My friends bought a few of his pieces, actually! Anyway, past the traditional houses, there's an area w/ more modern stuff - more shops and restaurants! Very nice place and the ambiance is great!

This is a must visit place if you go to Seoul. We got there by subway. Alight at Anguk station (line 3) and exit at #2. You can find a tourist information centre not far away and they will advise where are the places to visit. This place is really beautiful.

This village of traditional homes is probably the only single-family homes that you'll see in a city of high-rise living. The character is well maintained, there are good restaurants, galleries and shops, and a lovely view of the Seoul Tower. Don't forget to also walk through Insadong.
We came because we wanted to see traditional houses. It turns out to be really beautiful and clean. Wish there was more things to do around. It was a little hike and then there was all.

Bukchon is a pretty historic neighborhood in Seoul. The architecture is uniform, unique and typically Korean. Beautiful! The nice thing is, that it is not 'just' historic architecture. The area is also filled with galleries and cafes. Very cool. Read more here: http://curlytraveller.com/2014/02/bukchon-hanok-village-seoul.html

we were soooooo disappointed in visiting this place. going up is a challenge then when you reach the village all we can say is.. is that it!!!??!!?? i thought i could see the traditional old houses. not worth it! better look for other place to visit

I went because I had wanted to see a "traditional Korean village" and a friend had recommended it to me. I had me imagined a model village for tourists to see what traditional style Korean houses look like. However, upon arriving at Bukchon, it turned out to be a neighbourhood that happen to have a lot of traditional style Korean houses with real people living there in. The neighbourhood is on a hillside and so a lot of places it's quite steep. You also get some pretty amazing views and there is also an observatory that you can go to. Go in the day time so you can see the views. There are volunteer tourist guides all around that supply you with a map of the places to see in the area. Also just down the road there are some really good and inexpensive restaurants. There are some cute shops, cafes, and restaurants tucked in unexpected places.

It is a very tight place to navigate around as a tall person, and the streets would not be good if crowded, but people are still living in these places that are hundreds of years old and incredibly basic. I went mid week, and found a local guide for a few dollars who gave me a good and informative tour in English. After the megalopolis of Seoul and Gangnam, it is a simple and lovely space and a quick visit.
Nicely renovated, quite authentic, wear comfy shoes for lots of walking on narrow streets. This is a historic area where you can see how people lived before the 20th century.
There are many traditional house hotels (hostels) around that you may stay and experience Seoul's traditions and welcome.

Went there on a sunday afternoon, it was nice walking on the streets and seeing the tradutuinal Korean houses, there is also an activity center kind of thing where yoh can go and make handmade jewellery and dye some cloth in the old korean way. I think a lot of things were shut there maybe because of a sunday so olease check before going there.

You can visit Bukchon Hanok Village if you want to see Korean traditional houses in the city. Unlikely Namsangol Hanok Village, this is a real village where residents are living. You can take your time, looking around cultural centers, guesthouses, restaurants and tea houses, and at the same time feeling traditional Korean culture.

To be honest, I didn't plan to go there. My plant destination was the Changgyeonggung Palace, but it was closed (Mondays!) Hence I looked for something else and found Bukchon Hanok Village. It was certainly a good compensation for not being able to visit another Palace. I was strolling around for almost two hours. Just outstanding!

plenty to eat, see and do in Bukchon. See the traditional homes, antiques and shops, nice restaurants and coffee houses. Wonderful walking around the area. Go 'up Bukchon' towards Seongbuk-dong. Hit the old city wall. Next door is Samcheong-dong, insa-dong and the palace. Really worth your time - especially on a beautiful seoul day.

A lovely area to stroll among a remnant of the Joseon dynasty (1392-1910) where you can view restored Korean wooden homes plus galleries, cafes, and shops. Hilly streets that reminded me of San Francisco. Great views. We reached it by taking subway line 1 to Jongno 3-a, then transferring to line 3 to Anguk.
Bukchon is good place to see the traditional korean houses. and it is near samcheong-dong where you can see many boutique shops.

You don't really have to do much research to locate the best photography spots here because they have people (and a tourist information counter) placed throughout this residential area to lead tourists around with a proper Buckhon Hanok village map.  On the other hand, if you are searching for some houses which may have been used as filming locations, you will have to come prepared as these information are not disclosed (rightfully so, as to not disturb the residents of those houses).  All in all, there are a lot of tourists around the area so silence is vital to maintain its peaceful nature. Come prepared with a good pair of shoes though, as the climb can be pretty steep (especially for the elderly).

I love almost everything in Bukchon. Well except that you may need to go up the steep roads. But you'll love the view up there. I started from Samcheongdong. Less climbing than to those who started from Anguk Station.

It is a place full of korean traditional hanok houses. Most of the hanok houses are currently with residents stay inside. Therefore, you can only take picture and admire its architectural design from the outside of houses. Some houses are developed into shops such as coffee shop, tea shops, fashion shops, etc. It is a pleasant neighbourhood with nice and ancient architecture.

i stayed at bukchon during my visit at korea. the best time to visit bukchon is early in the morning before 8am cause it is not crowded. so, this is the best time for you to shoot a nice photo. then ,enjoy your delicious breakfast at bukchon area.  please get a map of bukchon from the bukchon tourism center before you walk around bukchon.  if you visit at the right time, you may enjoy their cultural monthly show for free as well. please checked the schedule before you depart.
Lovely place. In the morning very quiet and hardly trafic. Don't skip this in your visit to Seoul it is really worth it. Friendly people (all over in Korea)

It is not prevalent to see so many old (600 year-old) buildings in one place. Especially with all the gentrification and rapid urban development going on, this is a rare gem situated in the heart of the city. It is like walking back in time. I'm glad they preserve these buildings to give an insight to the past. It is good for a relaxing stroll as there are signs urging visitors to keep their voices low as it is a real residential estate.

Streets are really steep but you can have a look of another time as you walk through the streets and watch the traditional Korean Home Architecture, built of wood and with curved tiled roofs. In buckchon-ro-11 there is a traditional house that can be visited in a guided tour that cost about 10 dollars, but it is worth the visit and when you finish it they give you a cup of a really good prune tea and you can seat as long as you wish and watch the garden and verandas of the house and also the city scape.
Traditional homes and structures. Quiet alleys. Like nothing else you've seen. We stayed there a could night. Loved it but our backs protested the sleeping on floor challenge.

Not really knowing what to expect, so ended up a little disappointed. It is interesting to see traditional houses mixed with modern buildings, though. Lots of coffee shops. İt's okay visit just to chill & unwind.

Loved looking at the traditional homes there. It was a very nice sunny day and we took a slow stroll through the village. I wished that we had more time to spend there because there were interesting stores and restaurants to explore.

I felt like I spent endless hours looking for it. There were absolutely no signs, and I was shocked to see the number of other tourists who were similarly lost as I was, as the village is deemed a main point of interest in the city. That said, the neighborhood leading up to the village is charming enough that it makes up for it.

Perhaps it is because I have visited Insadong before coming to Bukchon, I did not find this area to be as interesting as anticipated. There were traditional houses everywhere and small shops along the street. The area is a lot less crowded than Myeongdong or Insandong. The hanoks are more authentic here, but it also means some need a bit more upkeep to remain beautiful. The streets could be a little steep, so you need to be careful. Also, since it's not a walking street all the time, there may be cars marching through the narrow streets. This is a nice place for a leisurely stroll and to soak in the atmosphere of a bygone era. :-)
very nice part of Seoul with pretty traditional houses (hanok). If You know Korean dramas (and like it) You can find house, which played in Personal Taste (where Gae-in lived).

Well documented, and very scenic. Reminds me of San Francisco, with a Korean spin to it. The houses, the landscape.  Beautiful, and along the tour route there will be cheap (1000-2000W) exhibits to allow you to go deeper. If you stick to the suggested route - you start from the tourist center, and take a great walk back to Insadong area. You can even visit the palaces which flank the neighbourhood.

The area preserved the traditional village setting. There are information guides wearing uniforms with hats with the letter I! These are steep hills so be prepared, better yet book a stay at a Hanoi locally and stay for an evening. Lots of restaurants, plenty of tourist shops, and there is a visitor center which can give you a map in English.
it has a nice area around with a lot of small shops and cafes. each of them very unique. nice art work to buy

The neighborhood has home with old korean architecture. Stays open from 10 am to sunset. Nearby (betweem Bukchon and Seoul Museum of Modern Art) is a small market with quaint shops and eateries. Do have this place on your itinerary!

Here the old style houses line the streets and it is a lovely stroll around this area to see them and how cool it is that they have been integrated into modern day Seoul. The buildings, carvings, decorations, dragons, architecture is amazing. The streets are so clean with boutique unique coffee shops, restaurants and clothing stores all over the place. Really enjoyed my walk around, and even went back another evening. Very convenient from the metro. Totally different from Seoul city centre.
A beautiful place where you can take some excellent photos and learn more about Korean culture. It's easy to reach by subway, there's a tourist center with information guides and maps in english.

I'm really impress with this place. Walking along this road, seems I were in Korean drama.At Gahoe-dong Alley, You can see the traditional Korean houses along with modern buildings and N Seoul Tower as the background. he traditional Korean houses are still inhabited by residents. You can catch a glimpse of residents' day-to-day life. The contrast of modern life and traditional building is the best point of this place, burglar alarms at the wall of traditional houses and modern cars.  (People who live here must be great at driving because the alleys are so twisty. I think it is really amazing ! )  You can enjoy nice and antique cafes and galleries alone the ways also.  It takes a few hours to walk all areas but it's worth.

The info desk had a nice map in English, that was helpful! The streets were a little confusing, but if you follow the other guests - you'll do fine. There are a few shops, restaurants, and guest houses on the way. It's a nice stroll. The only setback is the fact that you can't see inside the houses (at least when I was there - in the evening). Overall, it's a good afternoon activity.

Excellent. To take pictures and have a date.  Bukchon means nothern villiage. You can enjoy traditional houses, guest house, experience. Houses are real house where people lives. A little modernized. Never the less, from the hill you can see Jongro Tower and N Seoul Tour those are skyscrapers.  Tradition house with modern back ground this is really good place.

This is my favourite area in Seoul for the old feeling. From up the hill you can see both the old and the new (old hanok houses against the modern skyscrapers of the city in the backdrop). The area surrounding Bukchon is full of cute shops and boutiques. There is a hanok museum right at the top of the Buckchon village which is worth visiting to try the hanbok (the typical Korean costume) on: this requires a fee of 8000 won but when we went we were the only one there so we could take our time, take photos around the museum while wearing the hanbok and generally enjoy the experience without the crowds. If you have only time to visit one area in Seoul when in Korea then I would definitely recommend Bukchon. It is also close to two of the main palaces.

Don't really understand all the fuss. The buildings are not as old as they are advertised just built in traditional style. If you go now (August/September 2014) you can see a couple be built.  If you are new to Asia and have not seen traditional style buildings then it is worth a visit. If you've been to Asia before and seen old buildings elsewhere, especially Japan, then I think it can be missed.  Plenty of cafes and restaurants and some good touristy shopping.  Near to several other sites (palaces) that can be done all together 1 one day.

Bukchom hanok village has the most number of traditional koren houses in seoul. Although filled with shops and cafes for tourists and locals, it is still worth strolling along its narrow streets. To see real traditional korean houses, go to narrow alleys. It is advisable to try one of the quaint cafes for a quick rest.

We stopped by the Bukchon tourist information center and pick up a map. There are 8 Buckhon scenic views in total. We went to no. 4 to no. 8. Of all the view, the best ones are no. 5 and no. 6. It's the uphill and downhill view of a street between row of hanok.  It was nice walking along the street where actual people are staying but I gotta say the hanok are too modernized. If you love walks, then this is a good activity for you. Otherwise I find Jeonju Hanok Village in Jeonju has more to offer.
It was a shame, there was a lot of modernisation to the buildings and it's surrounding area, clearly themed to target tourist and there is little to no access to the so called 'historic' sights.

Picking up a tourist map from the Bukchon Information Centre we spent a few enjoyable hours following the tourist trail and admiring the traditional architecture of Korea. The views from some of the high points are impressive, as are the picturesque, narrow lanes of the village.  Whilst this residential area risks being overrun by us annoying tourists, judging by the number we passed and the 'please be quiet before 9am and after 6pm' signs, the village is well worth a visit.

Came here after reading reviews on internet about the village.  Here's a few things you can probably do: 1. Explore and admire the village + buildings 2. Sit and drink @ various cafés/restaurants 3. Walk  If you're in the area, you can just drop by. Otherwise, I feel it isn't worth the travelling.

This is the old part of Seoul with the original houses that used to run through the city. It is a steep walk up to the top however it is beautiful when you look over Seoul from the top. Great picture opportunities also from here. You can get guided tours, however we just went to the tourist information centre and got a map. The lady in there was really helpful and pointed out the best places to go and have a look. Loads of little shops and places to eat round the area also. This is really near Gyonbokgong palace, so you could do both on the same day.

if you happen to be in the area, than check it out. the nearby temples are worthwhile, but to make a specific trip here, is not worthwhile. small area, not very large, and its just a small area which is a quaint "hold" street. there is also an old school library/education center nearby

Super beautiful, recommend you to take a walk during evening and sit somewhere near the observatory to chill. There is one famous local noodle shop - 手撕面 (in chinese), it costs about 7000 won for one set. It is super good.

Spend a few hours walking about the area taking in the traditional Hanok style houses. A few nice photo opportunities. There are quite a few museum/workshop type places where you can take part in making traditional crafts. I went to the Dong Lim Knot Workshop and made a necklace.
Perhaps the taxi driver didn't take me to the best part but what I did see wasn't very impressive. Just saw a few buildings and a historic house museum which was nice.

Got here on a stroll from Insa-Dong down the road and behind the Constitutional Court Its a quaint place and has some very well maintained (though recently renovated) old Korean houses. It was a Thursday evening and the roads were deserted and I enjoyed walking in the narrow alleyways between these houses - This maybe the only photo-op a short stay Seoul visitor may get of Old Style Seoul/Korea. There is a walking tour route available with a clearly marked path.

This area of wandering narrow streets is filled with preserved older houses, many of them converted into small exhibits areas or so-called museums. It's fun to try to see how many of them you can find, based on the map distributed at information areas. It's just fun to wander, look in doorways, maybe stop at a museum or two. We saw the Gahoe Museum, Paper Doll Museum and Jewelry Museum. The latter has a somewhat high ticket price, but has a lovely collection. The views of Seoul over old tile rooftops are charming.
I wonder if the old Seoul looked like this neighborhood. Anyway there are some nice spots inside but it is almost just a residential neighborhood, and it seems to be an expensive one.

I just walked around Bukchon with the map in hand, which you can get from the tourist information centre nearby. It is a quiet residential area. The houses are all traditional korean style. one or two are kept open to tourists. There was a lady there who explained to me about the features of the house.  There are lots of small pathways in the streets so it is easy to get lost inside. But people are very nice there and will guide you if you are also nice to them.  Overall it was a nice experience.

Bukchon Hanok Village is really wonderful. Do not follow any guide or path: just walk around wherever you want and make sure to get to the highest point, so that you can get an incredible view of the whole area. PS: the area is a residential district, so keep quiet while visiting.

Bukchon Hanok Village is still a residential district- houses are well preserved and are still occupied by various generations. Head to Bukchon Information Centre to obtain a map of the walking trails and be prepared to climb steep slopes in return for a magnificent view of Seoul and Gyeongbukgung Palace
Traditional Korean living district, recommend to walk there. Be ready for lots of ups and downs - the area is mountainous.

I enjoyed my visit to Bukchon. The walk around is peaceful and quiet. You get to see the old Korean houses and the view from the hills are beautiful. If you want a break from the city, this is the place to go. Would definitely love to go back!

Way too many tourists in living areas. Visited the area with much nostalgia where I used to live as a kid. Some buildings seem to be out of the way and it does not appear to maintain the traditional Korean housing style any more. Eye sore. But it is still great to see many houses maintain the old style and receive local residents and tourists.
beautiful Korean traditional house. There are some traditional house to stay.
We visited on a Saturday morning. Very interesting to see a traditional Korean upscale neighborhood that dates back centuries but still functions as a residential area. Worth the 1-2 hours to stroll
It was interesting looking at the places where people lived. Want to try staying in a Bukchon the next time
But quite but not off the beaten track, still enjoyable. Gives a good picture of how the city used to be.

The awesome part about Bukchon, is that it is alive and utilized in compliance with its purpose - as a residential district. Inhabited traditional houses are mixed with culture centers, shops and cafes, street vendors and even a school. the district is laid-back and bustling at the same time, and every corner worth sticking your nose into =) However, if you plan a visit, please note that tourists are kindly requested to keep reasonable hours (around 10 am to sunset).

The houses and streets here are well kept and they are really beautiful. It is like going to a different city but it is located in Seoul. A place not to be missed! Get a map from the tourist center to help you go around the place easily, or ask the guides that are stationed there!
In here you can see traditional houses of korea and some handicraft that they made. You can try walking around here while eating some ice flakes. Yum ~♥

Make a turn off a busy street into this quaint neighbourhood with beautifully preserved traditional housing. There are still people living inside some of these houses while a few had been turned into galleries or shops, so there is a courtesy hour they ask people to observe (basically don't go there too early or too late). It's a steep walk with no facilities, but is worth it. If the weather is too warm or cold, get yourself a nice iced/hot coffee to-go from the little cafe right at the start of it to enjoy during your walk.
Nice afternoon spend doing arts and crafts with the locals. Kids enjoyed and had a taste of Korean crafts and culture including painting, bracelet making, jewellery box making. Time well spent!
Put on some comfortable shoes and get ready for an uphill walk. You'll love the architecture, view and stretches of cafes!

Hanging around at bukchon could easily spend you a day or couple. It's a place with rich historical stories and places there are full of Japanese accents. Little handicraft shops at reason am price are also key attraction

Bukchon traditional Village is a great walk even though you would have to walk uphill at most of the streets. You would be able to see the beautiful traditional Korean houses, if you walk uphill a little more, you will see the modern high rises. I really enjoyed this place and it do not take long time. and It is just walking distance from Insadong. Get the free map from the tourist office at the main street.

This area is definitely something travelers must go to when in Seoul. Not only can you see many examples of traditional Korean architecture with different streets lined by hanoks, but there are also various shops that focus on design along the nooks and crannies of the area. The streets from the hanok village towards Samcheongdong area are also lined with many different types of cafes and shops. There are also a lot of quirky street art, a feast for the eyes and photographers. It is a great place to stroll about, wind down, have a cup of tea, and maybe shop for eclectic items. We brought traditional Korean sweets from one shop, then a french baguette from a specialty bakery, took a break at a tea garden, gazed at the Blue House, and then window shopped at several of the boutiques in the area.

Bukchon really brings you back to the traditional old days and has a great vibe to the area. The hanok houses villages are beautiful.  Great walk in the neughbourhood make sure you bring comfy shoes as there is a lot of uphill walking.  Close by on samcheongdong road there are loads of cafés and shops which are certainly worth a visit
This is a neat area, with an older feel, to walk around in. Just take a stroll, grab a meal and do a little shopping, including a nice chocolate shop!

A lovely place to visit after you have finished the palace. The houses are all built on slope and the uniqueness in the houses take you back to ancient history. Make sure you wear good walking shoes.!

We had a good time and I loved all the little houses in the Hanock Village. However there were people EVERYWHERE. Not sure if it is that busy every day but it made it feel much less like exploring and more like everyone was just shuffling through it together. Still got some good photos and saw some interesting things though! Would probably suggest going on a weekday not in the holidays if you can to avoid the crowds!
Bukchon was great for shopping and eating, near the palaces and Insadong. Great place for traditional Korean food.

Fans of Heartstrings 넌 내게 반했어 (a.k.a You've Fallen For Me) by Jung Yong Hwa of C.N. Blue and Park Shin Hye, and Personal Taste 개인의 취향 by Lee Min-Ho and Son Ye-Jin will not be unfamiliar with the filming locations of the Korean dramas in Bukchon Hanok Village!  Bukchon Hanok Village (북촌한옥마을/北村韩屋村) is home to hundreds of traditional houses called 'hanok' that date back to the Joseon Dynasty. Many of these traditional houses are currently used as cultural centres, teahouses and restaurants.  Great for a leisurely walk. Photography lovers will enjoy the walk with the beautiful architecture.
Go here if you wanna see the country's traditional houses. You could easily stroll this place and it's for free. Take pictures everywhere!

It's worth spending an hour in the area to see the traditional Korean houses. Besides, you can also find some cute little shops that carry some unique stuff. Make sure you have comfortable shoes on when visiting there.

I would like to ask the world to come and see "Northville" before cheesy tacky commercialism takes over just like it did to Samchung and Insadong. Some people might argue it already happened, but i still believe there are independent spirits trying hard to not be swept away. This is a cool neighborhood. You dont get to see a lot of 80 year old houses in Seoul with growing kids and veggie garden. Its absolutely rare to see open sky. Young and creative artists showrooms and ateliers.Northville used to have it all but its changing. Come and see before its too late.

Split by a main road into 2 parts, the western side is larger with uphill streets lined by old houses which make for nice photo shoots. Some houses hold art displays that are free to view while others collect entrance fees. Drop by the tourist info office for a map guide before you start exploring. One is along the main road 500m south of or before the entry roads to the village. The other is about 300 m up across the road opposite the 1st office. There are several cafés which serves as rest stops and to quench your thirst after the long routes.
I walked through Bukchon on the way from Gyeongbokgung Palace to Changdeokgung Palace. It is a charming area with cute little houses, cafés, bakeries and some really nice stores such as 'Object'.
Get the feel and architecture glimpse of traditional Korea era by roaming the hallway & streets of Hanok. A village that gives you ease & an eye opening land to your heart.

This has become one of the 'must do' sights in Seoul, and deservedly so. Translated as 'northern village', this well preserved time capsule of domestic architecture sits comfortably between two of the extensive northern palaces and is becoming increasingly popular, thanks to relatively recent publicity and promotion. As an architectural conservationist, I have a few issues with the commercialisation and sanitisation of parts, but am delighted that it is being maintained and integrated with the community. Allow a few hours; take your time and savour the all-to-rare historic environment, set against the backdrop of the expanding high-rise metropolis.

It was excellent place and residential place. Please keep silent during visit at there because it was is a residential neighborhood where people actually live. Bukchon Hanok Village is a Korean traditional village, those are staying with many yangbans (people from the ruling class). From there, we can visit a lot of different types of design. It was impressive. There are also a number of museums of traditional Korean culture including the Gahoe Museum, the Han Sangsu Embroidery Museum, the Museum of Korean Art and many more to get more information about hanok.

I recommend that you have at least 2-3 hours set aside for Bukchon to meander through the streets. The Hanoks or Korean design houses are beautiful and they are found. In various corners. Meandering through the alley ways and the streets are the best way to just enjoy the architecture and the quiet neighbourhood.

The traditional giwa tiled roofs of the traditional houses (Hanoks) make this area in Seoul quite uniquely interesting. Head to the Information Center near the Jeongdok Public Library to grab a tourist map and walk at a leisurely place around. Note that the Korean Tourism organized guided walking tours are no longer provided due to complaints from the residents about crowds and noise, so be quiet and respect the people that live in the area!

Bukchon is definitely my favorite spot in Seoul.. it is a great area with narrow winding street, I find my self lost in the time, wandering what life was a long time ago.
