Go there early in the morning when the place is still quiet - less tourist.  If you are into traditional culture and heritage, love architecture and have soft feeling for old times - this is the place you need to visit in Seoul.

What a great area – narrow winding streets, small cafés, art galleries, quirky little craft shops, and brave souls living like the Koreans of old in Hanoks. Sandwiched between the palaces to the east and west, and the narrow streets of Insadong to the south filled with bars and restaurants, Bukchon is a taste of Korea that you are not going to get staying in a large hotel tower. If you can't stay, go for a walk through the streets, try some soju at the cultural centre, or marvel at the restoration work underway on the houses.

This might just be my favorite place in Seoul. The first time, we dropped by the museum, which gave a good preview of a Hanok. It was early in the morning and most of the shops were still closed. So we had to visit it again during the day and it's nice to walk around and drop by the small boutique shops. It's good to know that regular people still live there although I also feel bad for them because there could be big groups of tourists walking pass by.

Really nice hilly stroll through an older neighborhood in Seoul. I wish we could have gone into more of the homes. If you do go, you have to look carefully and research which ones are open to visitors. Make a point into going into a few. Really special experience!
The surrounding is nice and very suitable for photo shooting, having fun around, but too many people and hard to take a very nice scene. If lucky you may find some hidden view in the alley.

Great to see all the gorgeous hanok houses,had afternoon tea at one that has been turned into a cafe.Area has great atmosphere and some great fashion boutiques.Walked here after going to Changdeokgung Palace which is a 5 minute walk around the corner.

Its very informative and you're faced with beautiful buildings from the past. Some are used as shops/ restaurants but others are residential areas. So we had to be quiet so as not to disturb them. I would advise you to wear comfy shoes because there will be lots of walking and hiking!

use the subway: Line 3, Anguk Station, exit 2. Walk to the Tourist Info booth close by and pick up a map of the heritage walk. Well worth the 1-2 hour stroll, with a stop at one of the cute small cafes on the walk path. The one we went was adjacent to the Music Boxes store. Had a really small n cute outdoor seating in the courtyard surrounded by the cafe indoor seating. Had relics from the past, including a old horn type HMV gramaphone. You will see the various designs of traditional hanuk homes, with a smattering of places offering various types of workshops. Dont miss this!

You can get to experience and see traditional house here. Very nice place for people to visit and getting the feel of old traditional house. Their house are very well maintained and it's easy to get here via subway.

It's a nice stroll if you come with your partner, but there's really nothing special. Might be better and able to experience more if stay in one of the hanok hostel.  There are some unique stores selling art and crafts, nice cafés, but all are pricey.

These streets and alleys takes you away from Seoul, like to an other city. Small roads and characteristic buildings are mainly well kept. There are several wonderful coffee shops, tea houses, restaurants and small shops. You must try one of those bakeries, just delicious.
This is a great neighborhood. Take your time and stroll through all of the little alleys. There are great views of the city from some areas. The roving tourist helpers are wonderful!

I saw a lot of beautiful photos of Bukchon Traditional Homes so I expected a lot. But I was a bit disappointed as not did we walk way far from the metro station, but it was a steep climb up as well to reach the actual houses. They were awesome yes, but you can only take photos outside. Map was a bit confusing to us and there were no helpful signs along the way.

This is really an interesting part of Seoul. Get a map from the information center and head north towards Bukchon. The left side part which is Hanok is much more interesting. We really enjoyed the twisting streets and the narrow alleys and of course the traditional houses with very low roofs. There is an observation point where one can have a magnificent view of the surrounding mountains and the Gyeongbokgung palace. Nice antique and art shops specially the one close to the main entrance to Hanok village (check the photo attached)

A nice place to take photographs but have to walk quite a bit from the nearest train station. It is a worth visiting place in Seoul as it is a place where visitors can embrace the beauty of traditional Korean houses.

we took the subway to go here so it was a bit of a walk but the tourist guides (with the letter "i" on their hat) can speak good english and can guide you on which part to visit. get the map from the information center before you start the tour. it will take you 4 hours to go around bukchon but if you only want to see the spots for nice for pictures, then there is a short cut (it is marked with red line on the map) and will take you about an hour to complete. go up a little bit further and there is a great view of the traditional houses and then at the back are the modern buildings of seoul. i think the place looks better with snow but unfortunately there is no more snow when I visited. there are several gift shops in the area plus cafes and restaurants. after completing your tour here, you can go straight to insadong which is just near the area.

There are many Korean traditional house village and Buckchon is the one in Seoul. If you are going to stay just in Seoul, I recommend you to stop by here, because traditional village in Seoul is just this one. And It's next to Gyungbock goong,(royal palace) so It will be easy for you to find it. But if you are staying in R.O.K more than 1 week, I think It will be better for you to go to the countryside just like Junjoo or Andong. There are many traditional villages there and those ones are much more better and in the countryside, there is a traditional show so you can enjoy the show.
This area has some lovely old houses. Unfortunately, not all are restored and they can be an eyesore. To see these houses, though, is well worth the walk.

This area has a mix of tradition mixed with modern amenities. There are so many museums, restaurants and quiet streets to visit. It's very photo friendly if you want to create great memories of Korea and it's connected with other major attractions. Please pick up a map from the tourist info booth before trying to explore on your own ... Bring a camera!

We visited the home area and went to a tea house. This is a beautiful part for the city and very different from the big city feel.. Lots of great artistic shops. We purchased some needlework and pottery here
Bukchon is gorgeous and very atmospheric. Weekdays are uncrowded, and it's possible to go inside some of the old houses - some for free. I really recommend a walk around.

while other corner of Seoul is hype and crowded, full of cafe and make up store and fashion, this corner is very silent and the house are still well kept in Korean traditional houses. this village is still so pure and people still living inside the house so be aware to not just enter and photograph, since there is some rules for photographing people in Korea please ask permit when you want to photograph them in their house. the houses is all private and some houses offering courses on Korean traditional drink 'soju' making, knotting, painting etc. the great thing is we can go to observatory, its on the hill part of Bukchon and held by old lady, from 3rd floor we can better view this whole village with palace on the background.the place offer green tea and coffee, in winter this is the warming station after freezing discovering korean tradition. :)

This old village is a must visit. In here you will see not just the shoot locations of your favorite K-drama but also the old and traditional Korean houses. The architecture and designs of these old houses is a preview of the Korean culture. You should not miss it.
We combined this with a walk around Insadong and then back to our hotel - The Metro Hotel. It's a lovely place to take pictures.
..to see Korean traditional homes in the heart of Seoul. Nice small shops with handicrafts are nice and lovely.
Explore the romantic walks on a quiet weekend and have some hot tea in their quaint cafes. Lots of galleries are open to the artsy fartsy set.

Yesterday was frigid but we made our way up the hill and what a delight it was to view these lovely old,and or reconstructed homes is the old fashion. Most have been turned into restaurants, coffee shops or shops with varying merchandise, much of it quite ethnic and interesting looking. We were cold enough that we were finally driven into a coffee roasters where we had a divine and warming mocha latte. We took any number of photos of some of the more interesting "homes" but as darkness set in we decided that we should head back to the station. On our way downhill, we sopped to watch a gal half seated, half lying on the ground, who was heating a pot of sugar over an open flame (probably about 5 minutes) until she could pour this carmel colored "batter" onto a baking sheet where she folded it in half, cut it into 3 equal pieces, flattened each piece with a spatula, and then impressed each with a different imprint. She was selling them for 1 won each and you'd have thought she was giving away diamonds - basically just burned sugar but warm and wonderful - a sight we've not encountered before. Give it s try if you see it.

My parents, 76 and 70 years old and my self visited this village as I searched from online that its very near the place we were staying from Somerset Hotel, so with the guidance of the map and very helpful Souls of Seoul we tried to visit this village. Albeit cause the Osteoarthrtis of my father to act up, we soldiered on. We saw the famous street and its really beautiful, worth to take a photo as a memento. We chance upon one Hanok house that you need to pay 10 dollars as entrance fee, with the history of the house, guided tour and free delicious plum tea and you can stay as long as you like.if you can spare some cash , go and vist it, its worth it. You can see from the balcony the thatched roofs of the other Hanok houses, although some are residentials and people really are living there so need to be respectful of their privacy. But there are some Hanoks that can be visited just like we did and i say its worth the orice.There's a lot of interesting cafes, restaurants, stores you can broswe upon and I might say the people are very friendly.One can identify some locations from the dramas if you are a Korean drama fan.

This place is indeed a surprise. My friend was leading us to this place, saying its like a Korea cultural village. It was much more than expected. So many amazing architectures, we could not stop taking photos. Also, there are many arts and crafts lessons if you wish to partake in. My only regret was that we were there at about 2pm and most of the places close by 5pm, otherwise we could have explored more.

Went to Bukchon in the afternoon after heading to Gyeongbokgung. Walkable distance from gyeongbokgung and tosok ginseng chicken, would be good to take a day tour around the area.  There are many tourist information centres at different spots to ask questions and get maps. There are also walking information guides dressed to red who can help to give directions around. Some of the museums provide demostrations on korean culture but comes with admission fee.  Overall, a nice place to experience korea culture and see the hanok architecture.
如果你愛看漂亮的建築，如果你酷愛拍攝。。你超愛這里。。and there have very sweet shopping area uphill from 安國地鐵站，it's a bit like 自由之丘in Tokyo....all the shops are very cute....

Worth going to see the unique village and the houses. Just be aware it's basically uphill the whole way so not an easy walk.  Easy to get to from the subway station and a short walk from Insadong shopping area.

The site itself was a bit far from the train station so my mother (being a senior citizen) had a bit of a hard time walking. I had to ask for directions from a tourist stall we came across. Upon arriving at the "village", it was nice to take photos in front of the Korean houses. Lovely cultural place. The day we visited though, there were a lot of police due to a demonstration so it was kind of unnerving to be walking with all of them around.
Great houses there, very cultural I really wish to be there again, sooner or later maybe Take the pictures front of the houses
I enjoyed thus little area, quaint shops. It was snowing, and cold but places for a coffee along the way. Enjoyable atmosphere. Not an earth shattering have to do, but fun.
Basically new or refurbished homes and streets set to look old but clearly for the wealthy in Seoul. Not so great but the odd original house is worth a look.

This is actually one of those heritage places that even though goes on with their usual lives, also allows the tourists to have a peak at their culture. The whole Bukchon is spread over steep and narrow alleys that have traditional Korean houses aligned along its line and along with these houses; you also get to see lot of handicraft shops and restaurants that serve authentic Korean cuisines. The walking tour is actually the best way to see seoul in its day to day life and you could interact with the natives to learn about their culture and lifestyles. The walking tour actually comes with proper instructions and guidelines so that you do not get lost around here. The place being an active residential area requires one to be in their best behavior so as to not meddle with the daily chores of the people living around here. The whole place is very quiet and serene and has lots of attractive and impressive view.

Like this place but try to go there in the afternoon to avoid group tours in the morning. There are areas where you can take a photo with n Seoul tower on the background. It's also near chungang high school famous place where winter sonata was shoot!!!

To get there, you need to get the subway to Anguk and follow exit for the village, once out keep walking straight and you can't miss the masses the tourists. The place itself is beautiful and have breath taking views. It was a nice change from the hustle and bustle of Myeongdong and there are several street food places jotted around the outskirts if the village, wifey would recommend the pasty that looks like a fish on the outside and red bean on the inside!

Walk up the hill to get away from the biggest crowds, and slowly take in the beautiful homes up here. Some are old, some are new, and some are new but made to looks historic. Virtually without exception, all are a feast for the eyes, with terracing and architectural flourishes that demonstrate an understated Korean luxurious life.
Interesting old buildings but also many newer buildings that was constructed to replicate the old buildings charms. Too many shops and restaurants for my liking,

We did not spend much time here but I did manage to walk around the alleys and take lots of pictures of the old Korean styled houses. Perhaps it was due to the weather, extremely cold. The houses were very pretty and with the recent snow fall. Art and craft shops to visit!

Perhaps it was due to the weather, extremely cold. The houses were very pretty and with the recent snow fall. Art and craft shops should also be visited and experienced. Shopping is also interesting and actually slightly cheaper than Seoul with good quality too!
I would recommend to get the map from tourist center before start your walking trip in Bukchon. And pls be quiet!

A different feel from the usual shopping areas in Seoul as this area comprises of older architecture. Good to venture beyond the shops along the roads to see the homes on the steep hillside. Enjoyable cafes here too.

I had a free guided tour all to myself, so it was quite nice, it gives you an idea of what real hanoks looked like however, most of them were reactualised,and there is also many museums abs things to see in the area. Wear good shoes as you're there for a walk! Although it was a rainy day I enjoyed the walk and sights
make sure you didn't make a noise when entering this beautiful housing area. These tradisional house is very beautiful to feast by your eyes.Love it

It was a cold day when we took a walk in the Bukchon Hanok 'village', where there are many rebuilt houses in the traditional style. Go prepared with good walking shoes so that you can enjoy the stroll. There are ample opportunities to snack and enjoy hot drinks. Thankfully the residents do not seem to mind us tourist taking photos outside their houses and along the streets.

We did not spend much time here but I did manage to walk around the alleys and take lots of pictures of the old Korean styled houses. It is nice to find history so well preserved here and there are lots of small restaurants in the periphery if you want to grab something to eat whilst walking around. I was told by the lady at the information office that the areas marked 5 and 6 on the map that they handed out was the most picturesque.

This is a neighborhood near the 2 palaces (Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung) where sometimes houses of nobleman existed during Yi Dynasty. A lot of the traditional houses have been converted, but half or so houses still keep the traditional old flavor (and now they are unable to take them down and build modern structures). This is an area where you can experience staying in Hanok (Korean traditional houses with warm floors - Ondol), and over the years, many living national treasures have started to congregate to promote the traditional crafts and traditions. Few examples of such are: traditional artisan Soju maker, knot maker, embroidery, etc. It has become extremely easy to see this area as starting few years back, a detailed map can be obtained from tourist kiosk and follow the path.

This is a place where someone should not miss if you want to feel like coming to korea. When we venture along the village streets, we could enjoy the Korean traditional houses closely. Streets are clean and quiet and we enjoy the serenity.

Read ten things one must do when i am in korea!!! So went with low expectation with tourist trap mindset. But what a lovely surprise. I loved the small shops, and restaurants, loved the tourist shops, and loved that every corner was a surprise.  I walked for hours and had a most wonderful time. The shops were so amazing and shop keepers friendly. I would really recoomend this for all who travel to seoul.
A great walk around the streets of old Seoul. It's free and you can really see and feel the history here. A must for you Seoul trip

Worth an hours walk after seeing one/some of the nearby temples. Gives a sense of what Seoul must have been like before the concrete took over. Lots of small guest houses for the more traditional stays. Small restaurants selling a lot of cheap traditional korean food....
it's a dynamic neighborhood with lots to see - with shops and people from around the globe in the most traditional Korean atmosphere

I went to Hanok village with my mother in early November. The old houses are very well maintained as there are people staying in them. It was nice to walk through the narrow streets although there were cars parked along it. Although the roads were quite steep, my mother still enjoyed it.  Actually what I liked most was shopping around the area near hanok village. There were many eateries and shops which were busy and it was fun walking around.  It's easy to get to - take the subway and drop off at Anguk station, exit 2. Walk for 300m straight and you will be there. I went there after strolling around Insadong street which is a slightly long but manageable walk from Hanok Village.

It's a nice neighborhood to go around and take pictures in, but that's kind of it. We went on a Sunday morning, so it was..sleepier than usual, I think. Be prepared for a lot of walking. We got tired pretty quickly. Luckily, there are a bunch of small restaurants in the area.

I thought I was going to have a photographic feast in Bukchon Hanok. The houses were nice but to me, the whole area was nothing special. Only get a few nice shots because there were so many tourists flocked the houses. If you are planning to come here, you can start your walk from Insadong area, then make a stop at Ssamsigil (they have plenty of cute knick-knacks for your family back home), then continue your walk a little bit to Bukchon Hanok. There are plenty of tourist guides along the area just in case you need some directions.
We were able to check out one of the guest houses in this area. Very cute area. would love to try out the guest house the next time we visit Seoul.

Enjoyed walking through Bukchon. The houses are traditional and historical but are occupied and updated in terms of front and garage doors. Would love to see inside the homes. Walked past one where the owner was installing an outdoor light fixture and could see the modern conveniences through the open gate (yes; I was looking). Fantastic view at the top of the street. Stand on top of the cement clock/cornerstone at dusk. Beautiful! Loved the character and feel of the neighborhood. Worth a look!

Well not much feel of old Korea as when we were there, there are a lot of renovations going on there. Some of the old house you can sees it has preserve the old construction but using modern material. Example the main door entrance of the houses are using digital code lock but the door was old wooden style. :)  For photography, this is a good background view of village buildings. We took a lot of picture here. Great things here was the Korea tourism guide are standing around the corner if you need any assistance. They will point you where to take the nice picture as per their map or flyer.

this area are full with traditional korea house"hanok". my korean friend told me that all the villagers in this places were rich family who worked with goverment or have relation with the king in ancient year. this village is now recommended by unesco, hence some of the villager had to rent their house to be restaurant or to be various museums.  some of the shops such as the rice cake (toppokki) shop in front of Doo Guest House has been operated for at least 35years by using the traditional style to cook the rice cake.  i love this village and i stayed at the hanok house in this village for four days. the best way to explore the village is to have morning walk around the village and walk into the museum to experience the culture and traditional of korea.

If you don't have the opportunity to see the traditional houses (hanok) in Jeonju or in one of the folk villages, you should not miss Bukchon. There you can see these lovely old houses - and it's not a museum because people actually live there.

This area has some lovely looking houses in the traditional Korean style. The area is not hard to get to from Insadong. However, it isn't really designed to be a tourist destination. These are people's houses. They live in them. There are signs asking the tourists to stay quiet (though they are not that effective). People living there try to drive to their house and tourists are blocking the way. There are few signs so it is a bit challenging to find the best streets of houses though there are often people in red shirts directing the tourists where to go. It was an alright visit but I felt quite awkward being in a residential area.

Nice place not only it shows you 600 years history of Seoul in Bukchon, but also many nice shops established in the neighborhood. They sell hand made products. And there are some gallery and some art works placing on the street when you walk around Bukchon. The tourism develops not bad with well maintainance of Bukchon old style and the special landscape. Worth to have a day trip or a stay at traditional guesthouse at the area.
Wander around, get lost in the small streets, get into all the houses. Have coffee, tea, take your time. Discover Korean arts, Korean food. Experience Seoul away from the concrete jungle.
An active neighborhood of traditional architecture. The view down from the hill looking at the rooftops of the old buildings is interesting. It was easy to get to with the subway.

Walking though this typical old style streets you can feel the real hearth of Seul. Lovely shops and cafè make the atmosphere more enjoyable. You can find typical korean handicrafts (I have to say not very much..). Easy to reach using the Line 1 of the Metro. There are also some guesthouses.

The stretch of traditional Korean houses were very appealing to the eyes and for picture taking as well as the elaborate design of the houses were fascinating.  Houses were located at the hilly side so it is quite steep going up and down. There were like two areas where you can see the stretch of said houses. Others traditional houses were mixed with the new ones in the area hence were not exclusively traditional houses in one location or village.  The place has many restaurants, coffee shops, convenience stores. What is so great about visiting this place is that Korean Information (personnel who assists tourist locating the areas) was available in the area.  Recommending this as a must see for first timers.

Bukchon is an area where we can enjoy artwork. Also we can have a walk in the ancient wall. We can know something about ancient Seoul. But be sure to bring your passports as you have to register for safety procedure.

Homes of Nobility and High ranked government officials in the Joseon Dynasty period. Historically significant. Homes had intricate details. Just lovely. Twenty minutes is all you need. Good shoes needed for steep walk. People live in this neighborhood today. We didn't feel good imposing on their privacy.
Nice place to shop, cool cafes and nice restaurants. Some of the restaurants are private kitchens with limited menu selection but food is delicious and comforting, very home-made feel.

We saw pictures online of the place with a lot of traditional houses and activities happening. We went during Summer in Korea and Summer is extremely hot and humid. Had to walk about 300M from the subway and up and extremely steep slope to the Bukchon Village. Nothing much to see except beautiful traditional houses but that is about it. Great place to take some pictures but if you're there in the summer i'd say it isn't worth to travel all the way.

this old area of seoul is full of traditional style houses, that have been well preserved and maintained. it seems that any renovation or upgrade work is strictly controlled to maintain the look and feel of the area, which is great.  it is definitely worth spending some time walking through the narrow streets and soaking up the atmosphere.

The name "traditional Korean village" had me imagining a model village for tourists to see what traditional style Korean houses look like. However, upon arriving at Bukchon, it turned out to be a neighbourhood that happen to have a lot of traditional style Korean houses with real, live, living inhabitants in them. There are signs along the narrow roads asking tourists to keep their voices down and no photos inside the residences out of respect the the privacy of the owners. A couple of the houses actually will give you a guided tour of the interior at a fee. We didn't do that, so just walked along the lanes and looked a the houses from the exterior. The neighbourhood is on a hillside and so a lot of places it's quite steep. You do get a good view at certain points though and there are some cute shops, cafes, and restaurants tucked in unexpected places. We happen upon a little cafe that was so cute. The shops etc. are not in the same area as the traditional houses though. We wandered beyond them but I couldn't say exactly in which direction. We ended up down by the main streets and close to Gyeongbokgung Palace. The houses were pretty from the outside but I don't know if it alone was worth the trek. The view down below and the nice walk was good though.
The old but renovated building is attractive. Walking at a place which come out in the drama make me feel slightly excited.

If you like ancient architecture and buildings, you will enjoy the Bukchon Hanok Village. Don't except too much as you can only admire from the outside and not the inside as it is the actual residential area. There are also signs for you not to disturb the resident. Fair enough. Still nice to go and have a look, but I wouldn't say it is a must go.

I can say this place is one of the must-visit spots in Seoul. Specially in winter of Seoul, try to visit after snowing even though it can be freezingly cold. The village is on a hill so the view of Seoul from there is wonderful,,,you can feel the unusual mixture of standing in the middle of the traditional village with a view of modern buildings ahead.
good walk with volunteers in red speaking both Mandarin and English to guide you if you are lost.Policemen are very polite and courteous.

Walk down the streets, have a coffee and waffle ( the one I recommend will be C I- 2 Cafe ) the waffle with green tea ice cream is great ! Visit the art gallery and check out the local designers accessories. I can spent a full day here and not feel bored. It is a must see place in Seoul. I cannot describe the feeling. Walking along the street you see a mix of building of old and new. The overseas chain of coffee as well as the local chain. Of course the local chain of coffee wins the market share. It is suitable place for families, couples and for singles and friends who want shopping , window or buying, gather for chit chat and have a slow afternoon.

The highlight of my trip this July! The Bukchon is a cluster of traditional Korean houses, small shops and musuems. Try to avoid Mondays as most museums are closed and even the Tourist Information office is closed! If you see young people in RED T-shirts standing in a street junction, they are in fact mobile TI and they will point you to the right directions They spoke good English and Mandarin too. Do ask for directions as signage is not adequate in the area and you will easily miss a turn and you will never find the traditional houses.

Interesting to have a wander through this hillside area. The houses are mostly private homes and the locals do not want to be bothered by intrusive tourists. Clusters of houses converted to restaurants and cafes, and some interesting little cottage museums, like the Embroidery Museum.

Its a traditional village architecture in the middle of seoul. Interesting architecture & good for great picture. Walking thru the place makes me feel like walking thru the old days of Korea. Its not easy to take great nice picture due to the people walking thru the alley.  You need to walk up the hill thru the alley with 3 kids. Tiring but its worth it. There're some shops, cafe's at the end of the alley where you can clear the thirst. We found 2 tourism representative where you can get pamphlet & info's with regards to the place.

Village with some restaurants, small shops, and private homes built in a traditional style.  Prepare to do LOTS of walking. Good for people who have have plenty of time to spend in Seoul. If not, you can skip this place. It was just okay.
I would suggest walking the neighborhood. The place reminds me of the old Seoul that I used to know as a child. There are a few restaurants around here but nothing special.

The most impressive feature of Bukchon Village is that it is nestled in the heart of a global metropolis. You will be amazed that such a traditional village exists and wow just about everything you see. A truly must see for anyone coming to Seoul.

This is a lovely neighborhood, with private houses more than a century old. It's nice to stroll the narrow streets, avoiding the tourists groups,that annoy the locals so much. Signs are placed in many walls, reminding the visitors these are family homes and asking for silence. A couple of such houses allow guided visits to admire the interiors. The lack of furniture there is to see is compensated with an intresting and versitle distribution. Take the time to visit one of this houses.
Love the charm of this place, like walking through the"old Korean time". Do plan to drop by Bukchon Hanok Village when in Seoul

If you want to see small houses on a very steep hill with lots of time to kill, here is a suitable place. This used to be a rundown and cramped lower middle class area which failed to draw attention by the destroy-anything-old syndrome of the 1970's and 80's building craze in Seoul. Most of the grand mansions down below on more habitable flat ground were long gone even before that period. Now there are only two homes worth mentioning in the area. One belonged to former President Yun--a 99-unit home in traditional Korean style. The other is at the summit of Bukchon--a genuine Victorian home. In any case, both homes are privately owned and not open to the public.  The small houses in Bukchon are also privately owned and are not possible to visit inside. Those few that are open to the public, you have to pay an entrance fee! Why on earth would anyone be interested in visiting a claustrophobic home that somehow avoided demolition decades ago? Bear in mind, they may be well-maintained now but are not homes built two, three centuries ago. It is shameful and embarrassing that there isn't a single area of grand old residential homes surviving in Seoul.  If quaint charm is what you are looking for, try Hannoversch Münden in Germany with homes more than 600 years old. Or Dinkelsbühl. Or San Gimignano in Italy. A bigger city? Try Florence. Bigger? There is always Paris.
A very short walk from the Folk Museum, this suburb is wonderfully scenic, though small. Stop at the tourist information centre for a more detailed map and directions. They are multilingual.
Loved walking around this area. We went into one of the traditional hanok village building and did a stamp rubbing and had some tea. Really interesting place to see.
Bukchon is a lovely place to walk around. It's not as big as I expected after visiting the hanok maeul in Jeonju, but it's pretty (great views from the tops of hills) and has lots of little shops.

Bukchon Hanok village is an interesting place in the middle of Seoul. It nestled between the 2 main Palaces, Changdeokgung and Gyeongbokgung. Walking distance away from the first, its originally a housing complex for High Ranking Official during the Joseon Dynasty. Now most of the hanok had been turned into museum or cafe but some were still occupied by families. Find a small but beautiful museum here that offers experience in trying out Hanbok, korean traditional costumes. Ended up spending most of our visit to the village taking picture of ourselves in multicolour Hanbok..haha! Unforgettable souvenir from Seoul.
We were able to have a private tea in the presidents previous residence which is now a high end bed and breakfast. Truly amazing. The entire area is residential but tourists were swarming all over
I love this neighborhood. Absolutely adorable and the best place to see traditional Korean houses. Walk around the alleys to soak in "korean style" of living. please budget 2 hours.

A nice glimpse into what Seoul used to look like, but with paved roads and presumably cleaned up considerably. This is a great place to spend an afternoon walking around taking pictures, etc.  Lots of cafes in the surrounding area, and on the roads leading up to the neighborhood. Most of them are independent cafes, which is pretty odd because most of Seoul's cafes are the same handful of brands.
After decades of war there wasn't much left of the city but in this place you can still catch a glimps of what it must have been like.
Experience architectural traditional building. Start off the walk by going through some well maintained hanok reaching the top you can see the samcheongdong and gukbyeonggung

It was a wonderful area to explore. The view is great, but the walk is steep and winding. Many people have turned their homes into museums, like the Owl Museum. The area below the hill is also great for resting and getting a bite to eat. It was picturesque, historical, interesting and fun. Could be crowded on weekends and holidays in good weather.
Preserved homes and lovely walk through the area. Definitely worth a visit. A better tourist map would help.

This is the historic Bukchon Hanok village where some traditional Korean residences have been preserved. Village isn’t quite the term I would give it, as it’s really just a residential district. It may occupy you for an hour or so. The houses may interest you from an architectural and photographic point of view but there’s little else. If you’re in this area then you may as well visit the nearby Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung palaces.
Loved looking at the old style homes of Korea. Beautiful architecture and awesome cafe's, restaurants and great shopping. Neat boutiques and stores galore. All outside.

Located North east of the main palace I love how this area has renovated and offers lots of shops, restaurants and cafes while at the same time retaining much of it's traditions. Definitely worth checking out

If you wanna lost yourself in the hide and seek of a old village inside the city. Escape to Bukchon. First get yourself a guided map at the Bukchon cultural center then seek out the treasures. Its a maze.

We spent an hour here just wandering about and having lunch after we visited Gyeongbokgung. It was easy to get here and once you are on the main road you are immediately surrounded by lots of other tourists. The first tourist information booth we saw gave us a walking map which we followed. This was as good a way as any to see the area and get some scenic photo shots. Since we were there on a Sunday, most of the shops/houses that were not on the main road were closed. I was a bit disappointed by the whole thing since it didn't really feel like an 'old town' (in the European sense at least) but DH was very keen to get the photo and video shots so it was worth it for that. Overall, the area is overun by tourists all doing the same thing (heading for photo spots to snap away). If you like that kind of shopping it appeared to have lots of small boutique like shops around the main road which my teenage daughter found quite interesting. Otherwise, it lends itself to just walking around aimlessly taking in the atmosphere. Since it is located right between two palaces, it also makes for a good 'bridging attraction' between the two. Just don't underestimate (like we did) how long it can take to visit Gyeokbokgung. By the time we finished there, looked around Bukchon and had lunch we had missed the timing for the English tour at Changdeokgung.

We found this a very peaceful area of town that was nice to walk around in the morning. We stayed at a wonderful traditional Korean homestay (hanok), and Bukchon was an excellent base for visiting other sights in Seoul. We easily walked to Insadong and Myeongdong from this area. Taking the subway is also very easy as well. As for Bukchon itself, there are lovely traditional wooden houses here and there as well as some interesting western style buildings. We found it an excellent neighborhood to stay in since we were mostly interesting in visiting the palaces in Korea along with some of the shopping districts.

Go back in time and experience the feel of heavy wooden doors and low ceilinged houses. Be impressed with the cobblestone paths and intricate details of the dainty houses. A map may be provided at the tourist information center near the subway exit. They also have English speaking personnel in the area in case yo needed assistance with the Directions. This is a great place to visit if you have 1-2 hours availability.

We went to the Traditional crafts experience center in Bukchon and my daughters enjoyed the workshops they are providing their guests. They tried the dollmaking, dancheong accessory and the jewelry box making.

It's easy. You can stop by the Bukchon Traditional Cutural Center as we did-empty and lifeless when we were there-and pick up a map, or just take a stroll. Poke down alleyways to find galleries and artists workshops. We stopped in the Bukchon Arts & Culture Museum. Interesting collection but the docent couldn't be bothered. in great contrast, very helpful staff at the Asian Art Museum and the brand new branch of the Kokdu Museum located in a traditional Korean house (hanok) at 48/48, 11-gil, Bukchon-ro, Jongno-gu. Three dollar entry fee, a delightful collection of carved figurines that come from funeral biers, and the pleasure of being in one of these old houses-which is why you came to Bukchon in the first place.
Maybe I just didnt find the right part, but it didnt seem like there was a huge amount of old architecture there
This might be a little hard to find, and many might not find it worth it after you see it, but it's very interesting to see this traditional housing and how they are built.

When we were walking along Bukchon (the start of which is about 500meters from the Anguk Station exit 2), you start to feel that you really are in Korea as you see the traditional houses around you. We went there during the weekend and there were some very helpful tourist guides stationed in certain areas to direct you to the different spots with the best views.
The most beautiful place in Seoul, I think. You can feel the traditional beauty of Korea with the traditional houses in 북촌. I love there and I go there sometimes for a photo shoot.

I got a map from Seoul tourism office and walk around this unique neighborhood. There are 8 photo stops and lots of supposedly traditional crafts exhibition. It is great to take pictures outside but a lot of times I have to be careful not to be run over by cars. Since people still live in this area.
the view is awesome. we just walked around and it was strange; contrast between the high scrapers and the old village. It is very beautiful.

Lots of good food in this area. They don't speak english but they have pictures of the food and brief description and the prices are posted. Here you can see traditional korean houses and can try/wear their traditional outfit called Hanbok. Up to the top at the end of the main street, you'll find the Private School as seen on the famous K-drama, Winter Sonata. A few teahouses and guesthouses in the area too,

You can get a free travel guide from the seoul tourist office or walk around yourself in this quaint residential area that showcases the preserved old korean houses even cobbled paths. It is quite interesting and admirable that they have chosen to preserve this community amidst the unceasing urbanisation of seoul

This is a nice place to visit for a quick walk around and some sight seeing. We spend all of about an hour here, but it was nice to walk around the streets and see the old houses (hanoks) framed against the skyscrapers in the background.  There are a few hanoks that operate as tea houses and B&Bs now, so there is an option to get inside if you like (we did not).  I'd recommend not driving through here. It's tight and crowded with tourists. We saw one car get quite damaged trying to turn around.

You can get a free travel guide from the seoul tourist office or walk around yourself in this quaint residential area that showcases the preserved old korean houses even cobbled paths. It is quite interesting and admirable that they have chosen to preserve this community amidst the unceasing urbanisation of seoul

ok, this is a small neighborhood up on top of a hill that is full of traditional korean homes. They are very nice with amazing wood work. the homes are set up around a central courtyard, and several offer tours for a small fee, dont miss out on at least one of the tours, and dont skip this attraction because of the steps, it will be worth walking up all the steps for sure.

quite ok for those who like to see the traditional houses however, we did read about the history and etc about this houses at the museum before entering the area....its ok if you didnt choose to look at the houses.. all sorts of information can be found at the mueseum we walked quite a distance from end to end of this area its a great experience nonetheless.. there are tourism staff available to assist you should you face difficulties in finding the houses down the hill...is an array of boutiques, cafes and etc lotsa coffee shops/cafes...
Nice but a bit disspointed as there isnt much to see. There are some good houses and residents are well off judgibg by their cars etc. Fairly commercialised

It was relatively easy to navigate to the Bukchon Hanok area from the subway station, because there were helpful tourist info helpers along the way who provided maps and pointed us in the right directions. It is an extremely lovely and pleasant area to walk around, and do visit one of those hanok-converted museums to learn more about the hanoks.

I want to call this area 'cute' but that seems patronizing, but I do think the old houses and buildings are quite cute. There are many new buildings in this area as well, as well as shopping and food.
Long street with plenty of boutiques, jewellery shops and cafes selling coffee & waffles. Apparently eating waffles is a romantic Korean thing to do these days. Very quaint!
Interesting place to relive how traditional Seoul was like. Pretty near from Gyeongbukgong, it would have been more fun if we stayed there, or took some of the classes.

Entering Bukchon I was initially disappointed. It is a western influenced part of town owing to the wealth there. After passing umpteen coffee and waffle shops along a street with obvious European influence, we moved up the hill. There the residential quiet along with the gorgeous views of the city and the fall colors took over. The actual "traditional houses" are largely either renovated or reconstructed to look old, but they are charming, especially when you come across a lane of them together. When there isn't a tour group or a late model luxury sedan nearby, you can almost imagine what the area might have been like for a rich Seoulite a century ago.

If you want some good light for photographs, definitely go for a look around dusk. I have some amazing pictures of Bukchon Hanok Village. This area is really the sort of place where you can wander around for a couple of hours and just get lost in the maze of streets. One thing I was disappointed with was the advertised Bukchon Hanok lookout... it was at the top of a persons' house on their balcony and was around 5000 Won. Not worth it! There is another panoramic view you can check out not far from there, it's just a little lower, that's all.

We went on a walking tour with the Royal Asiatic Society. The guide was well informed and gave a lot of interesting info about the place. It was very pleasant to walk through this part of Seoul and well worth it if you are a resident of tourist...

I found the Bukchon Hanok village to be rewarding soley for its nifty handicraft classes. The area is dotted with different "museums" where you can practice everything from Korean calligraphy to knot-tying. You can find some truly unique gifts here that are superior to anything I have seen in Insadong. However, if you are not shopping, I suggest visiting other areas. I feels a little tourist trappy.

Nestled behind the imposing and majestic Kyeong-Buk palace and a stones throw away from the president's residence 'the Blue House', Samcheong dong really is Seoul's best kept secret. Although it has an exclusive feel, it is very easy to get to: just follow the road which hugs the right side of the palace (if you stand at the entrance). Art galleries line the right side of the road and soon you will hit a feast of little artisan shops selling jewelry, shoes, clothes and other goodies. You would be forgiven if you got slightly confused as to whether you were in Europe or Asia. If your feet get tired, you can enjoy Korea's thriving cafe culture with a warming coffee and perhaps that cafe's special snacks and cakes. There are some very high quality restaurants on the main road which typically specialise in only one or two main dishes. You may think that you have seen enough on the main road, but do take the time to get lost in all the little alleyways. Don't worry, they all lead back to each other but it is in these tributaries where the true spirit of Samcheongdong can be discovered. You will see wall art, quirky shaped buildings, vintage clothes shops, ceramic wares for sale. You might even get to see a craftsman at work. I don't want to name specific places because the whole point is to go and find things for yourself with a blank canvas and open mind, but if you are fortunate enough to find the tiny alley cafe that sells patbingsoo, don't be put off by the fact that the waiting list is already an a4 side long....that's a quiet day! Samcheongdong is a refreshing celebration of creativity, self expression and talent. It's on my must-do list every time I go back and if you've never been, my question to you is...why ever not?!!!!

One of the best place you must see if you want to feel an authentic Korea traditional house.Terrific place with an awesome view and tt is nice to walk through the street to visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace.

This is a very fascinating area, and a definite visit if in Seoul to get a sense of culture, history and tradition. The Bukchon Hanok Village is nestled between the Gyeongbokgung Palace and the Changdeokgung Palace. It is located in the Insadong area of Seoul and an easy walk from the Angkuk subway station. The history of the village goes back 600 years, but the area has been preserved and reconstructed to the way it was. The narrow streets and the walls are all brick. Many winding hilly paths, and great views of the old Korean residential neighborhoods. There are still people living in these houses and also some people still working their businesses out of these houses. The problem is if you start on one path and continue, you my not see what is in the other direction. There really is no specific course to take so it is pretty much on your own instincts. There will be modern structures also as you go thru the area, maybe a place for a meal or drink and of course souvenirs, but not in a tacky way. It is a great picture taking attraction.
The Korean tourist office put out an excellent walking map of this area - do the walk late afternoon and stay on for dinner in Samcheong

This neighborhood is quaint, looks and feels like traditional Korea, and has been taken good care of. It's simply a delight to walk down the streets and check out the various shops and buildings. If you want the complete Korean experience, stay in a guest house!
the bukchon hanok village was interesting and we could see how the traditional korean houses looked like. some points also had views of the city!
It's like living in Korea long before western influence dominated the skyline.Typically a korean village set in a long forgotten era of kings. noblemen, and commoners.

If you are visiting this place, do also set aside some time for the nearby Samcheong-dong Bukchon area, which has quaint cafes and street shopping. Over here in Bukchon, you get to see the traditional look of the villages. My feel is that while the facade has been perserved to some extend, you cannot help but feel that that is all that is there.  The neighbourhood is actually quite a wealthy people place. While you walk around, just be considerate, do not make too must noise, and try not to intrude into areas you are not suppose to go into. The view from the top is quite nice showing the old houses with the city view in the distance.  You will also notice it's quite "touristy" - meaning many tourists will pay this place a visit, so just don't expect it to be exclusively just you and the place with great quiet. Nevertheless, you can try visiting on weekdays, hopefully it will exclude more locals from the visitor count :)

Bukchon Hanok Village is a neighborhood of old houses on top of a hill overlooking downtown modern Seoul. To reach here you can go to Anguk station. The houses themselves are lovely to look at, with their old architecture style. Some of the houses are still occupied by residents but most of them have been turned into museums, craft shops, or cafes. It is a great way to spend an afternoon walking through the narrow alleyways and taking photographs along the way. We booked a walking tour of this neighborhood which I strongly recommend. Our guide took us to see 8 spots in the village and each one had a different history. This village is situated between the 2 major palaces of Seoul so arrange to see at least one of them after you visit the village. Afterwards you can have lunch in one of the local restaurants along Samcheongdong. After lunch we walked through Insadong, then we walked along Cheonggyecheon stream which is lovely (and we decided to return to it the next day and walk along its length) and then we walked to Myeongdong. A lovely walk through old and new Seoul.
This is located on top the streets of SamCheong-dong. You will see stairs leading up the hill when U r walking along Samcheong-dong. Climb them & viola! U r at the Bukchon Village.

Made it to Samcheong-dong by accident. My sisters and I were walking around Bukchon, when we realized that we're lost. Somehow getting lost was fun because we came across this dainty street. Samcheong-dong is parallel to Bukchon so it was nice to see two cultures that Seoul offers: traditional and modern. Samcheong-dong is lined with low rise buildings that are well thought off. The paintings on the wall, water hydrants that has designs and cute little shops make walking and taking pictures around Samcheong-dong worth visiting.
For the real experience, stay in a Buckchon. Else you just walk the small corridors, but you don't get the real feel for the place.

Just like much of the old Korean architecture, most of Seoul was destroyed in the Korean war and in rebuilding, several areas were rebuilt to dimensions of the old style villages that Seoul originally began as. There are a plethora of small shops, museums and art centers. Weekends are the time to visit, as the areas are residential and more are open on the weekends. Interesting, but not more then other Korean sites.
go there on sundays. walk around, shop for great souvenirs, food and delights, rest in a coffee shop, buy great tea to bring home. don't forget your camera.

When you think how Seoul was flattened in the Korean War and how modern times results in conformity in dress, architecture and lifestyles, be certain you don't miss this village for a sample of traditional Korean house architecture.

The Village is like a museum exhibit, only later will you realize that the houses there are actually lived-in. I like the various art shopes in the fringes of the Village. A must visit area after a stroll in Insadong, has a good view of the Korean Folk Village Museum and Gyeokbokgung Palace.

You have to visit this place. There are so many little corners to explore and the old Hanok structures gave us a great old feeling vibe. It also feels very trendy here. Look out for the uphills and downhills.

I enjoyed my short time here. The locals are trendy and there are so many things to see. My girlfriend and I found a little coffee house nestled at the corner of one alley way. They served up awesome waffles with coffee. We chose to sit outside to experience the Autumn breeze. It reminded me of those romantic Korean movies that I used to watch. Of course people watching here is great too.
It's good place if you would like to see some traditional houses in Seoul but you won't stay long there as the houses are not open to public. Just take some pictures will do :)

i was here on Monday and the information center was closed,but there were a lot of walking information provider which are wearing a red jacket.you can get the bukchon map from them so you can plan the route that you will like to go.I only visit the 5 photospot out of the 8 as not much time i have,if you are really good stamina and have more time,give here a visit for looking at the traditional hanok.
A few small traditional houses. After seeing the palace nearby, this wasn't too impressive. Just a narrow street on a hill.

good to take a walk within bukchon hanok village and down the hill have many nice cafe , restaurant and boutique, hand craft boutique and art shop.. it is truely a wonderful oasis in a bustling city, up the hill point you could get a view of the city and mountain. must visit.

This wonderful oasis of quiet in a bustling city features reconstructed traditional Korean houses, demonstrations of Korean hand crafts, such as basket and shoe making, Korean dancing (check times for shows on bulletin board at village), and a shop selling art work and a bit-better-than-average souvenirs.  We did not take the free walking tour offered by Seoul Tourism; however, we had been to other traditional villages throughout S. Korea, and could make comparisons. If your visit is only to Seoul, I'd recommend this village as a good place to see how Koreans lived in the past.  There are some steps at this village but also wide, open spaces where wheelchairs can go (albeit a bit bumpily). It's not a huge place, so walking should not be a problem.
It's hard to see those old fashion houses in big city so please enjoy a walk here. Not to make too much noise here as this is a residential area.
It not so interesting place to visit as it normal village to explore and it locate up in the hill for us to explore.Only there was show for us to see with open air and if sunshine we feel warm.

I took a morning stroll along the small hillslope of the village. The area is very clean and the fresh morning air makes the place very nostalgic. I went into the only house that is available to be visited and opened to visitors (for a small fee of course). The house is beautiful and well maintained. We were served with a very nice plum juice before we left. Good to visit early morning when the air is cool and fresh. Take your time to appreciate its beauty.

a different perspective to the bustling city. what a refreshing change to see that a place like this exist and that the village is an actual residential neighborhood vs a tourist trap. we had to ensure that we behaved appropriately and contained ourselves from prying into homes!

There's not much here apart from pretty houses and people taking photographs. But, the pretty houses are very pretty! And walking up the hill to get to the viewing point is a nice way to walk off a meal ^^
Really nice pedestrianized area with examples of traditional Korean architecture and crafts. Good coffee shops, very friendly people.

The place is located on top of a hill from which you can see a good part of the royal palace. It is worth a visit but do not expect much more than sightseeing. It is good if you want to spend 1 hour trying to figure out how old houses were. In the surrounding many small restaurants.

The houses in this village are hanok style and it gives a glimpse of olden days korea among the modern days building. It gives a feeling of going back to the past. Some of the streets in this village gives a very beautiful view of Chandeokgung,

It is an area where there's concentration of heritage houses. It's paved with pebble stones. It's full of traditional colour and ambiance. There can be lots of tourists that to take a photo without traffic is almost impossible.

Walking along small roads, looking at people's houses. Not so entertaining. There are some nice corners but this is only a residential area. not a nice place to go expecially during hot summer or rainy season.

Just the walking tour itself is good. The tourist office provides a detailed map to follow, which was good. The buildings themselves are very quaint and picturesque. However any of the attractions, such as the knot workshop, art shop etc are require a fee. Depends how much you really want to see them. Otherwise just strolling around is a pretty way to spend an hour or two

This might sound ridiculous but I couldn't stop looking at the walls and roofs of the houses on this ancient town, great place to spend a morning and eat traditional Korean food, just be careful when ordering and make sure you are ordering for one person or you'll end with a lot of drinks and food.

What a time we had trying to find the place! Once there we could talk to the red uniformed guides (at tourst places around the city and always in pairs) who spoke English and were friendly. One house was available at 10,000 won to go inside but not much to see other than exteriors unless you took the invitation.
I believe it is number one must do in S Korea, go there take some pics of traditional houses.

I spent two weeks in Seoul and 6 nights in this general area or close to it (being Anguk metro station). So I had 3 separate relaxed wanders through the area, including spending two nights in a hanok room (what's with the Hakok spelling TripAdvisor??). Mind you with a shorter timeframe and a detailed map it is probably only an afternoon for the committed tourist.  It has become not uncommon for such "old" traditional areas in inner cities to become rediscovered and maintained in their original form. Given that so much of Seoul has been concreted and glassed over thank goodness for that. The walk up some of the steep streets will give you a contrasting vista over the more so-called "modern" Seoul - thank goodness for the old wood and stone!  A reasonable mix of coffee shops/places to snack and traditional businesses along with some quirky boutique shops.
you can walk in great atmosphere and great view. but very crowded. you should visit here in early morning. you can use English guide.

We visited Bukchon Hanok Village for an afternoon. It has extremely beautiful traditional architecture and is in the middle of the city so you get an amazing contrast between modern and traditional. It is this contrast that, for me, epitomises Seoul as a city. The most interesting part of the village is that the homes have been restored and are actually inhabited. There are interesting restaurants and coffee shops (and a museam) on the way up to the village from the station and back down again. Seoul volunteers that help tourists make it easy to navigate your way around the place. The downside is that whilst it is nice visiting the village, there is actually not much to do there (unless you sit down at one of the restaurants for a meal or coffee).
We went up and down the hills to see the views and the traditional housing areas, plus the crafts. There are lots of little gems hidden all over for a camera enthusiast.

This is a gem up the hill but well worth the walk, about 10min from Anguk station. It has a nice garden/front porch and a 2-level house. What caught my attention was the coffee roasting machine at the entrance which produces the perfect aroma. The rest of the decor is tasty and simplistic. A bit of retro as well. The waffle with chocolate ice cream is to kill for. The double expresso did not disappoint either.

Nothing more than a common city block. Traditional house are all private own and you can go in to look inside. Take photo to the roof is the only option. Road is slope and deep high, not recommend for elder and small child

If you walk the small allies of the village, you can feel of 1980's Seoul. most of Korean "well-living" class used to live those kinds of houses. You can also have a look inside of Korean guest houses where many tourists stay to have cultural experiences.
Not as interesting as what you see on film or picture. However still worth a visit.
Hard to find, not mentioned on the map in the subway. A few nice houses, but lost in the middle of unremarkable buildings. Go if you have time, only.

Possibly one of my fave spots in Seoul. It's a suburb that mixes the old with the relatively new and the result: awesome.  Be prepared to see some old school buildings as well as trendy vintage and retro decors. Getting pricier too, but oh so pretty! Check out pictures on my blog: http://www.girlwhodoeslunch.com/2012/05/just-typical-mid-week-lunch.html
Definiely take the time to spend an hour or so strolling through this village. The are lots of very interesting buildings and many fabulous restaurants and coffee shops.
We wish we can stay longer to tour around the Hanok area but since it was raining and we were basically drenched, we have to make our tour short.

We came here also as tourists, but we were mindful that this is a residential area and that people live here, and so we respected their environment and were quiet, but the majority of people, including a lot of school children, were not and they were very noisy, treating it like an amusement park. It is an interesting part of Seoul full of beautiful buildings and history, with great views.
I went there with my senior of Hanyangdae. that street was clean and peaceful. Waffle is not half bad...Delicious. Nice!

It's quite interesting neighborhood, because I think it's the only one neighborhood left which are still in old traditional houses. We didn't wander thoroughly since I got really tired. Here, you can also learn some of their customs and learn a few traditional Korean skills.

Very nice walk to see the hanok village. Visit the tourist information booth and you will be given a map showing the 8 photogenic places to catch good shots of the area. There are guides all around the Bukchon area so you will never be lost. They wear red shirt and will approach you automatically.

Finding the place is a little bit challenge, good thing that tourist information center is available around the areas. It is up a small hill so the walk is tiring but viewing the old traditional houses along the alleys are very relaxing.
Much better spending your time in the village streets and shops around the Hakok village, which was in itself disappointing. Found delicious ice cream, crazy art and an ice museum!
u'll find beautiful traditional house.. be prepared with comfortable shoes :)

Dont expect mush going to this place or choose to stay in a Hanok, because you chose to stay in an old house hahaha. There isnt good restaurant around the area. But if you want an experience, just stay in Hanok for 1 night, the second nite will be horrible. Trust me!

This was the most disappointing attraction of all the ones we visited. To be fair it may be that we were here on Easter Sunday and the majority of the craft shops were closed but I did not gain what I expected from this visit.
A good pair of walking shoes is necessary. Lots of up and downhill. The walking tour gives a good insight to the traditional and cultural of korea. Suggest you spent at least a night in a hanok.

This is a great part of town to walk around. The Bukchon village is a village of traditional Korean homes set on a mountain in the northwest part of Seoul. The roads are steep and twisty, turns, which add to the excitement of exploring this village. At certain points you can get some great photos of the village with the city views in the background. Highly recommended. It is also close to several other tourist destinations in that part of the city, so you can include several other stops during your day.

This is a real residential area. The signs say not to disturb the people who live there. However, I saw some signs that invite strangers into people's houses for a charge. The map is not very good, but the views are excellent. Very crowded (I went with 2 other people on some Sunday). A lady from my hotel said this village has some tea ceremony, and a lunch break around 12noon-1:30pm, but I did not see where either would be happening. People just live their rich quiet lives there.

This was the first thing we visited on our first day in Seoul. Travel a bit early if you want to avoid the crowd. Walking around the village gives you that sense of the old Korea. The hanoks look beautiful and well preserved. A must-see for travelers!
On the all, Seoul is, like Berlin before, not a beautiful city, it is chaotic. Bukchon Hakok Village is the place where you would like to live, small houses, friendly people...
Just walk and eat and drink tea and eat and walk and enjoy a sunny day lost in time.

This is a well preserved and maintained precinct of heritage domestic dwellings in central Seoul, close to the palaces and other sites of interest. People live in the houses and there are lots of small shops and coffee houses. There are suggested photo spots along pictuesque streets and over the amazing rooftops.
This is a very interesting place, but make sure to pick up a map before you go.
It was really worth the hype. Plus, with all the cool cafes around, I believe I can stay there for the whole day and still enjoy myself to the fullest.

Samchung-dong is one of the best place in Seoul for foreign residents!!! Here we could enjoy the harmony of traditional Korean-style houses and modern building (i.e. a lot of modern art galleries are located on the same street). There are many alleys in Samchung-dong and you can find affordable street foods (like Hotteok) and small accessory shops. Most people who work here are 'okay'(..) with English.  You can watch our video for the full details of the visually stunning streets!! :-) "http://youtu.be/R8Rb_XzF2kA"
Unfortunately there not much of old Seoul to visit so definitely a must.
Its nice to walk around. also nice looking coffee shops, restaurant. Must visit!
Going this place is really a cultural walk. The houses are the Hanok style architecture which is a native in Korean. amazing how these houses are kept well.
peaceful and quiet place for afternoon tea. There are numerous cafes and tea houses along the street to choose from

I saw the Korean traditional house and small back street. You can walk to Samcheong Garden in 5 minutes. You can walk to observatory spot which is on the city old wall in 20 minutes. The view is good. It is good tour to try.

Spent Sunday afternoon there. Lots of nice cafe and gallery in converted traditional Korean houses. Very interesting to see how they preserve the old distric yet to make use it for new modern activities.
The shops and restaurants were lovely and charming.  The walk from the station to Samcheong-Dong was a little long though.
